ediff.center

Module: ediff.center

Find the center of a 2D diffraction pattern.

  • The center determination may be surprisingly tricky in certain cases.
  • Nevertheless, the user just calls the CenterLocator class as shown below.
>>> # Example: How to use CenterLocator and get results?
>>> import ediff as ed
>>>
>>> center = ed.center.CenterLocator(
>>>    input_image='some_diffractogram.png',
>>>    determination='intensity',
>>>    refinement='sum',
>>>    messages=False, final_replot=True)
>>>
>>> print('Determined center coordinates:', center.x1, center.y1)
>>> print('Refined center coordinates   :', center.x2, center.y2)

   1'''
   2Module: ediff.center
   3--------------------
   4Find the center of a 2D diffraction pattern.
   5
   6* The center determination may be surprisingly tricky in certain cases.
   7* Nevertheless, the user just calls the CenterLocator class as shown below.
   8
   9>>> # Example: How to use CenterLocator and get results?
  10>>> import ediff as ed
  11>>>
  12>>> center = ed.center.CenterLocator(
  13>>>    input_image='some_diffractogram.png',
  14>>>    determination='intensity',
  15>>>    refinement='sum',
  16>>>    messages=False, final_replot=True)
  17>>>
  18>>> print('Determined center coordinates:', center.x1, center.y1)
  19>>> print('Refined center coordinates   :', center.x2, center.y2)

  52class CenterLocator:
  53    '''
  54    CenterLocator object - determine and refine a diffractogram center.
  55
  56    Parameters
  57    ----------
  58    input_image : str, path, or numpy.array
  59        The input image representing a 2D diffraction pattern, either as a 
  60        file path or a NumPy array.
  61    determination : str or None, optional, default is None
  62        The method used for the initial center determination.
  63        Options include:
  64        - 'manual': Manual detection - user defines 3 points
  65          on selected diffraction ring.
  66        - 'hough': Auto-detection - Hough transform for circle detection.
  67        - 'intensity': Auto-detection - intensity center in central region.
  68    refinement : str or None, optional, default is None
  69        The method used for the final center refinement.
  70        Options include:
  71        - 'manual': Manual adjustment - user adjust the position
  72          of the selected diffration ring.
  73        - 'sum': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring
  74          with maximal sum of intensities.
  75        - 'var': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring
  76          with minimal variance of intensities.
  77    in_file : str, optional, default is None
  78        Filename of the text file
  79        for saving the center coordinates.
  80    out_file : str, optional, default is None
  81        Filename of the text file
  82        for loading the previously saved center coordinates.
  83    heq : bool, optional, default is False
  84        Flag to indicate whether to perform histogram equalization 
  85        on the input image.
  86        The equalization is done internally,
  87        the image on the screen remains unchanged.
  88    icut : float, optional, default is None
  89        Cut-off intensity level for processing the image.
  90    cmap : str, optional, default is 'gray'
  91        Colormap to be used for displaying the image. 
  92    csquare : int, optional, default is 50
  93        Size of the central square,
  94        within which we will search the intensity center.
  95    cintensity : float, optional, default is 0.8
  96        Threshold intensity
  97        for finding the intensity center.
  98        Pixels with a (relative) intensity lower than cintensity are ignored.
  99    messages : bool, optional, default is False
 100        Flag to enable or disable informational messages during processing. 
 101    print_sums : bool, optional, default is False
 102        If True, prints the sum of intensity values for the refined circle 
 103        after each adjustment, relevant only for manual methods of center 
 104        determination and refinement.
 105    final_print : bool, optional, default is True
 106        If True, print determined and refined coordinates to stdout.
 107 
 108    Returns
 109    -------
 110    None
 111        The center coordinates are stored in instance variables
 112        (x1,y1) for the determined center and
 113        (x2,y2) for the refined center.
 114        Look at the initial example at the top of this module
 115        to see how to use CenterLocator class.
 116            
 117    Technical notes
 118    ---------------
 119    * The class initializes (and runs) two sub-classes (= processes),
 120      CenterDetermination and CenterRefinement.
 121    * The two sub-classes/processes are hidden to common user,
 122      altough they could be run separately.
 123    '''
 124    
 125    
 126    def __init__(self,
 127                 input_image, 
 128                 determination = None, 
 129                 refinement = None,
 130                 in_file = None,
 131                 out_file = None,
 132                 heq = False, 
 133                 icut = None,
 134                 cmap = 'gray',
 135                 csquare=50,
 136                 cintensity=0.8,
 137                 messages = False,
 138                 print_sums = False,
 139                 final_print = True):
 140        
 141        ######################################################################
 142        # PRIVATE FUNCTION: Initialize CenterLocator object.
 143        # The parameters are described above in class definition.
 144        ######################################################################
 145
 146        ## (0) Initialize input attributes
 147        
 148        # Input image = diffraction pattern
 149        # (it can be either image file or numpy array
 150        self.input_image = input_image
 151        
 152        # Methods of center determination and center refinement
 153        self.determination = determination
 154        self.refinement = refinement
 155        # For reproducibility, convert the method names to lowercase
 156        if determination is not None:
 157            self.determination = determination.lower()
 158        if refinement is not None:
 159            self.refinement = refinement.lower()
 160        
 161        # Text files for reading/saving center coordinates
 162        self.in_file = in_file
 163        self.out_file = out_file
 164        
 165        # Additional parameters
 166        self.heq = heq
 167        self.icut = icut
 168        self.cmap = cmap
 169        self.csquare = csquare
 170        self.cintensity = cintensity
 171        self.messages = messages
 172        self.print_sums = print_sums
 173        self.final_print = final_print
 174        
 175        ## (1) Initialize new attributes
 176        
 177        self.to_refine = []
 178        self.dText = []
 179        self.rText = []
 180        
 181        # The value of the following attribute can be adjusted
 182        self.marker_size = 100          
 183
 184        ## (2) Read input image
 185        
 186        # The input image can be numpy.array (ndarray) or image file (path/str)
 187        if isinstance(input_image, np.ndarray):
 188            self.image = input_image
 189        else:
 190            self.image = ediff.io.read_image(self.input_image)
 191            
 192        ## (3) Read center coordinates
 193        
 194        # * The center coordinates may have been determined
 195        #   in a previous run of the program and saved to a text file.
 196        # * We can Load coordinates from an input file if specified,
 197        #   this is done by the following commant.
 198        # * As the saved coordinates can be used INSTEAD of CenterDetermination
 199        #   we will read them here.
 200        if self.in_file is not None: self.load_results()  
 201        
 202        ## (4) Run CenterDetermination
 203        
 204        # (4a) Initialize/run CenterDetermination
 205        self.center1 = CenterDetermination(self,
 206                self.input_image,
 207                self.determination,
 208                self.heq,
 209                self.icut,
 210                self.cmap,
 211                self.csquare,
 212                self.cintensity,
 213                self.messages,
 214                self.print_sums)
 215        
 216        # (4b) Find radius of a circle/diffraction ring,
 217        #      which is needed for the next step = CenterRefimenement.
 218        if self.determination != "manual":
 219            self.center1.r = self.center1.get_radius(
 220                self.image, 
 221                self.center1.x, 
 222                self.center1.y, 
 223                disp=False)
 224
 225        ## (5) Initialize/run CenterRefinement
 226        
 227        self.center2 = CenterRefinement(self,
 228            self.input_image, 
 229            self.refinement,
 230            self.in_file,
 231            self.out_file,
 232            self.heq, 
 233            self.icut,
 234            self.cmap,
 235            self.messages,
 236            self.print_sums)
 237        
 238        ## (6) Collect results from CenterDetermination + CenterRefinement
 239        self.x1 = self.center1.x
 240        self.y1 = self.center1.y
 241        
 242        if self.refinement is not None:
 243            self.x2 = self.center2.xx
 244            self.y2 = self.center2.yy
 245        else: 
 246            self.x2 = self.center1.x
 247            self.y2 = self.center1.y
 248            self.center2.xx = self.center1.x
 249            self.center2.yy = self.center1.y
 250            self.center2.rr = self.center1.r
 251        
 252        ## (7) Switch coordinates if necessary
 253        if (self.determination == "intensity"):
 254                self.x1, self.y1 = self.convert_coords(self.x1, self.y1)
 255                self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2)  
 256        
 257        if (self.determination =="hough" and self.refinement == "manual"):
 258            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2)  
 259
 260        ## (8) Print the coordinates if required
 261        if self.final_print:
 262            self.dText=str(self.dText)
 263            self.rText=str(self.rText)
 264            
 265            print("----------------------------------------------------------")
 266            print(self.dText.format(float(self.x1),float(self.y1)))
 267            
 268            if self.refinement is not None:
 269                print(self.rText.format(float(self.x2),float(self.y2)))
 270                        
 271        ## (9) Save results to a .txt file if specified
 272        if out_file is not None:
 273            self.save_results()
 274
 275    
 276    def output(self):
 277        """
 278        Return the final results of center determination and refinement. 
 279        
 280        Returns
 281        -------
 282        x1 : float
 283            x-coordinate of the center from *determination* method
 284        y1 : float
 285            y-coordinate of the center from *determination* method
 286        x2 : float
 287            x-coordinate of the center from *refinement* method
 288        y2 : float
 289            y-coordinate of the center from *refinement* method
 290            
 291        Technical note
 292        --------------
 293        * The function always returns four parameters.
 294        * In most cases, the output are four coordinates (x1,y1,x2,y2).
 295        * If the *refinement* method was None, the output is (x1,y1,x1,y1);
 296          i.e. the *determined* and *refined* center coordinates are the same.
 297        """
 298        
 299        # (1) Refinement method was not None => prepare (x1,y1,x2,y2)
 300        if self.center2.ret == 1:
 301            # Convert to float
 302            if type(self.x1) != float:
 303                self.x1, self.y1, self.x2, self.y2 = \
 304                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1, self.y1, 
 305                                                self.x2, self.y2)]
 306        # (2) Refinement method was None => prepare (x1,y1) = (x2,y2)                      
 307        else:
 308            # Convert to float
 309            if type(self.x1) != float:
 310                self.x1, self.y1 = \
 311                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1,self.y1)]
 312            # Define x2,y2 = x1,y1
 313            self.x2 = self.x1
 314            self.y2 = self.y1
 315            
 316        # (3) Return (rounded) values of center coordinates
 317        return (np.round(self.x1,1), np.round(self.y1,1), 
 318                np.round(self.x2,1), np.round(self.y2,1))  
 319
 320    
 321    def save_results(self):
 322        '''
 323        Save the current results to a specified file. The results are formatted 
 324        to four decimal places for clarity.
 325
 326        
 327        This method checks if a file path has been provided through 
 328        the `in_file` attribute. 
 329        
 330        - If the specified file exists, the method appends the results 
 331        (x1, y1, x2, y2) to the end of the file. 
 332        - If the file does not exist, it creates a new file and writes 
 333        the results to it.
 334        
 335        
 336        Parameters
 337        ----------
 338        None
 339        
 340        Returns
 341        -------
 342        None
 343        
 344        Notes
 345        -----
 346        - The results are written in the format:
 347            x1: <value>, y1: <value>
 348            x2: <value>, y2: <value>
 349        '''
 350        
 351        if self.out_file is not None:
 352            # Check if the specified file exists
 353            if os.path.isfile(self.out_file):
 354                # Append results to in_file
 355                with open(self.out_file, 'a') as f:  # Open in append mode
 356                    f.write(f"x1: {self.x1:.4f}, y1: {self.y1:.4f}\n")
 357                    f.write(f"x2: {self.x2:.4f}, y2: {self.y2:.4f}\n")
 358            else:
 359                # If the file does not exist, create it and write results
 360                with open(self.out_file, 'w') as f:  # Open in write mode
 361                    f.write(f"x1: {self.x1:.4f}, y1: {self.y1:.4f}\n")
 362                    f.write(f"x2: {self.x2:.4f}, y2: {self.y2:.4f}\n")
 363
 364
 365    def load_results(self):
 366        '''
 367        Load results from a specified text file.
 368    
 369        This method reads the coordinates from a text file defined by the 
 370        `out_file` attribute. It extracts pairs of coordinates (x1, y1) and 
 371        (x2, y2) from each line in the file. The extracted values are stored in 
 372        lists, allowing for the retrieval of multiple results.The most recent 
 373        values of x1, y1, x2, and y2 can be stored as instance variables
 374        for easy access.
 375    
 376        Parameters
 377        ----------
 378        None
 379    
 380        Returns
 381        -------
 382        None
 383    
 384        Notes
 385        -----
 386        - The results are expected to be in the format:
 387            x1: <value>, y1: <value>
 388            x2: <value>, y2: <value>
 389        - If multiple sets of coordinates are found, they are stored in lists,
 390        and only the last set can be accessed as instance variables.
 391        '''        
 392        
 393        if self.in_file is not None and os.path.isfile(self.in_file):
 394            with open(self.in_file, 'r') as f:
 395                lines = f.readlines()
 396                
 397                # Initialize lists to hold multiple values
 398                x1_values = []
 399                y1_values = []
 400                x2_values = []
 401                y2_values = []
 402    
 403                for line in lines:
 404                    # Strip and split each line to get the coordinates
 405                    parts = line.strip().split(',')
 406                    if len(parts) == 2:
 407                        # Extract x1 and y1 or x2 and y2 based on line content
 408                        if 'x1' in parts[0]:
 409                            x1 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
 410                            y1 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
 411                            x1_values.append(x1)
 412                            y1_values.append(y1)
 413                        elif 'x2' in parts[0]:
 414                            x2 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
 415                            y2 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
 416                            x2_values.append(x2)
 417                            y2_values.append(y2)
 418    
 419                # Store the last set of values as instance variables 
 420                self.x1 = x1_values
 421                self.y1 = y1_values
 422                self.x2 = x2_values
 423                self.y2 = y2_values
 424    
 425                # Store the last loaded values:
 426                if x1_values and y1_values and x2_values and y2_values:
 427                    self.x1 = x1_values[-1]
 428                    self.y1 = y1_values[-1]
 429                    self.x2 = x2_values[-1]
 430                    self.y2 = y2_values[-1]
 431    
 432        else:
 433            print("Error reading text file with center coordinates!")
 434
 435
 436    def get_circle_pixels(self, xc, yc, radius, num_points=360):
 437        '''         
 438        Get coordinates of pixels defining circle border
 439    
 440        Parameters
 441        ----------
 442        self.image_path : str
 443            direct path to a image with diffraction patterns
 444        xc : float64
 445            x-coordinate of the detected center
 446        yc : float64
 447            y-coordinate of the detected center
 448        radius : float64
 449            radius of the detected center
 450        num_points : float64 
 451            number of border points. The default is 360
 452        
 453        Returns
 454        -------
 455        x : array of float64
 456            x-coordinates of pixels from circle border
 457        y : array of float64
 458            y-coordinates of pixels from circle border
 459            
 460        '''
 461        
 462        # Generate angles from 0 to 2*pi
 463        theta = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, num=num_points)  
 464                
 465        # Calculate x,y-coordinates of points on the actual circle border
 466        x_actual = xc + radius * np.cos(theta)
 467        y_actual = yc + radius * np.sin(theta)
 468        
 469        return x_actual, y_actual
 470          
 471    
 472    def intensity_sum(self, image, px, py, pr):
 473        ''' 
 474        Summation of intensity values of pixels of a diffraction pattern.
 475
 476        Parameters
 477        ----------
 478        image : array of uint8
 479            image from which the diffraction pattern has been detected.
 480        px : float64
 481            x-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
 482        py : float64
 483            y-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
 484        pr : float64
 485            radius of the diffraction pattern.
 486
 487        Returns
 488        -------
 489        s : float64
 490            intensity sum
 491
 492        '''
 493        # Extract pixels on the circle border
 494        pxc, pyc = self.get_circle_pixels(px, py, pr)
 495        pxc = np.array(pxc, dtype=int)
 496        pyc = np.array(pyc, dtype=int)
 497        
 498        # Calculate sum using the filtered values
 499        s = np.sum(image[pyc, pxc])/len(pxc)
 500
 501        return s
 502    
 503    
 504    def intensity_variance(self, image, px, py, pr):
 505        ''' 
 506        Variance of intensity values of pixels of a diffraction pattern.
 507
 508        Parameters
 509        ----------
 510        image : array of uint8
 511            image from which the diffraction pattern has been detected.
 512        px : float64
 513            x-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
 514        py : float64
 515            y-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
 516        pr : float64
 517            radius of the diffraction pattern.
 518
 519        Returns
 520        -------
 521        s : float64
 522            intensity variance
 523
 524        '''
 525        # Extract pixels on the circle border
 526        pxc, pyc = self.get_circle_pixels(px, py, pr)
 527        pxc = np.array(pxc, dtype=int)
 528        pyc = np.array(pyc, dtype=int)
 529        
 530        # Calculate sum using the filtered values
 531        s = np.var(image[pxc, pyc])
 532        return s
 533    
 534    
 535    def convert_coords(self, x, y):
 536        """
 537        Convert coordinates between numpy and matplotlib systems.
 538    
 539        Parameters:
 540        ----------
 541        x : int or float
 542            The x-coordinate in the numpy (column index) format.
 543        y : int or float
 544            The y-coordinate in the numpy (row index) format.
 545    
 546        Returns:
 547        -------
 548        tuple of (int or float, int or float)
 549            The converted coordinates in matplotlib format, where:
 550            - First element corresponds to y (new x in matplotlib).
 551            - Second element corresponds to x (new y in matplotlib).
 552        """
 553        return y, x
 554
 555
 556    def visualize_results(self, csquare=None):
 557        '''
 558        Visualize diffractogram and its center after
 559        center determination + refinement.
 560    
 561        Parameters
 562        ----------
 563        csquare : int, optional, default is None
 564            If csquare argument is given,
 565            only the central square of the diffractogram will be plotted;
 566            the size of the central square will be equal to csquare argument.
 567    
 568        Returns
 569        -------
 570        None
 571            The output is the image of the diffractogram
 572            showing also the central coordinates and refinement ring.
 573        '''
 574        
 575        # (0) Collect center coordinates and radii
 576        # x1,y1,r1 = coordinates and radius of the determined circle/ring
 577        # x2,y2,r2 = coordinates and radius of the refined circle/ring
 578        x1, y1 = (self.x1, self.y1)
 579        r1 = self.center1.r
 580        x2, y2 = (self.x2, self.y2)
 581        r2  = self.center2.rr
 582        
 583        # (1) Prepare the image of the diffractogram
 584        # ...copy diffractogram image
 585        image = np.copy(self.to_refine)
 586        # ...cut image intensity if required
 587        if self.icut is not None:
 588            im = np.where(image > self.icut, self.icut, image)
 589        else:
 590            im = np.copy(image)
 591            
 592        # (2) Calculate intensity sum or intensity variance
 593        if self.refinement == "var":
 594            # Refinement was based on minimizing the intensity variance
 595            dvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x1, y1, r1)
 596            rvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x2, x2, r2)
 597            labeld = (
 598                f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]'
 599                + '\n' + f'int-var: {dvar:.1f}')
 600            labelr = (
 601                f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]'
 602                + '\n' + f'int-var: {rvar:.1f}')
 603        else:
 604            # All other cases: manual refinement or maximixing intensity sum
 605            dsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x1, y1, r1)
 606            rsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x2, x2, r2)
 607            labeld = (
 608                f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]'
 609                + '\n' + f'int-sum: {dsum:.1f}')
 610            labelr = (
 611                f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]'
 612                + '\n' + f'int-sum: {rsum:.1f}')
 613            
 614        # (3) Calculate xy-limits if we want to see only the central square
 615        # (if csquare argument was given, we will plot only the central square
 616        # (to achieve this, we pre-calculate params for ax.set_xlim/set_ylim
 617        # (the precalculated parameters will be used below during plotting
 618        if csquare is not None:
 619            xmin,xmax = (0, image.shape[0])
 620            ymin,ymax = (0, image.shape[1])
 621            edge = (xmax-csquare) // 2
 622            xmin = xmin + edge
 623            xmax = xmax - edge
 624            ymin = ymin + edge
 625            ymax = ymax - edge
 626    
 627        # (4) Final plot: show the diffractogram + refinement results
 628        # ...prepare figure
 629        fig, ax = plt.subplots()
 630        # ...show diffraction pattern
 631        ax.imshow(im, cmap=self.cmap, origin="upper")
 632        # ...set the title of the whole figure
 633        ax.set_title(
 634            f'Center Location ({self.determination}/{self.refinement})')
 635        # ...add initial center (after CenterDetermination)
 636        ax.scatter(x1, y1,
 637                   label=labeld, color='red', marker='x', s=60, lw=1)
 638        # ...add initial circle (after CenterDetermination)
 639        c0 = plt.Circle((x1, y1), r1,
 640                        color='red', fill=False, label='detected', lw=1)
 641        ax.add_patch(c0)    
 642        # ...add final center coordinates (after CenterRefinement)
 643        ax.scatter(x2, y2,
 644                   label=labelr, color='springgreen', marker='x', lw=1, s=60)
 645        # ...add final cirlce (after CenterRefinement)
 646        c1 = plt.Circle((x2,y2), r2,
 647                        color='springgreen', fill=False, label='refined', lw=1)
 648        ax.add_patch(c1)
 649        # ...move legend to the top right next to the image
 650        ax.legend(loc='upper left', frameon=False, #fontsize=10,
 651                  handler_map={Circle: HandlerCircle()}, ncol=1,
 652                  bbox_to_anchor=(.98, 1.01), 
 653                  bbox_transform=ax.transAxes)
 654        # ...set xlim/ylim if we want to see only the central square
 655        if csquare is not None:
 656            ax.set_xlim(xmin,xmax)  # the xmin/xmax were pre-calculated above
 657            ax.set_ylim(ymin,ymax)  # the ymin/ymax were pre-calculated above
 658        # ...do not hide axis decorations = labels, spines, ticks...
 659        ax.axis('on')
 660        # ...show the plot
 661        plt.show(block=False)
 662
 663    
 664
 665class CenterDetermination:
 666    '''
 667    CenterDetermination object - initial detection of a diffractogram center.
 668
 669    This class is responsible for identifying the center coordinates of 
 670    a 2D diffraction pattern image using various detection methods specified 
 671    by the user. It initializes with the input image and other parameters
 672    that influence the center detection process.
 673
 674    Parameters
 675    ----------
 676    parent : CenterLocator
 677        Reference to the parent CenterLocator object, allowing access 
 678        to shared attributes and methods.
 679    input_image : str, path, or numpy.array
 680        The input image representing a 2D diffraction pattern, provided as 
 681        a file path or a NumPy array.
 682    determination : str or None, optional, default is None
 683        The method used for the initial center determination.
 684        Options include:
 685        - 'manual': Manual detection - user defines 3 points
 686          on selected diffraction ring.
 687        - 'hough': Auto-detection - Hough transform for circle detection.
 688        - 'intensity': Auto-detection - intensity center in central region.
 689    in_file : str, optional
 690        Filename of the text file from which to load previously saved 
 691        center coordinates.
 692    out_file : str, optional
 693        Filename of the text file to which the detected center coordinates 
 694        will be saved.
 695    heq : bool, optional
 696        Flag to indicate whether to perform histogram equalization on the 
 697        input image. Default is False.
 698    icut : float, optional
 699        Cut-off intensity level for processing the image. Default is None.
 700    cmap : str, optional
 701        Colormap to be used for displaying the image. Default is 'gray'.
 702    csquare : int, optional
 703        Size of the square for processing. Default is 50.
 704    cintensity : float, optional
 705        Threshold intensity for detecting features in the image. Default is
 706        0.8.
 707    messages : bool, optional
 708        Flag to enable or disable informational messages during processing. 
 709        Default is False.
 710    print_sums : bool, optional
 711        If True, prints the sum of intensity values for the detected circle
 712        after each adjustment, relevant only for manual detection methods.
 713
 714
 715    Returns
 716    -------
 717    None
 718
 719    Notes
 720    -----
 721    - The class preprocesses the input image and then applies the specified 
 722      center detection method.
 723    - The detected center coordinates are stored in instance variables
 724      `x`, `y`, and `r`, representing the center's x-coordinate, 
 725      y-coordinate, and radius, respectively.
 726    '''
 727    
 728    def __init__(self, parent,
 729                 input_image,
 730                 determination = None, 
 731                 in_file = None,
 732                 out_file = None,
 733                 heq = False, 
 734                 icut = None,
 735                 cmap = 'gray',
 736                 csquare=50,
 737                 cintensity=0.8,
 738                 messages = False,
 739                 print_sums = False):
 740        
 741        ######################################################################
 742        # PRIVATE FUNCTION: Initialize CenterLocator object.
 743        # The parameters are described above in class definition.
 744        ######################################################################
 745        
 746        ## (0) Initialize input attributes
 747        self.parent = parent
 748        
 749        ## (1) Initialize new attributes
 750        self.step=0.5
 751        
 752        ## (2) Run functions
 753        # (2a) Preprocess data
 754        self.preprocess(preInit=1)
 755        
 756        # (2b) Center detection methods
 757        if determination.lower() == "manual":
 758            self.x, self.y, self.r = self.detection_3points()
 759        elif determination.lower() == "hough":
 760            self.x, self.y, self.r = self.detection_Hough()
 761        elif determination.lower() == "intensity":
 762            self.x, self.y, self.r = self.detection_intensity(
 763                self.parent.csquare, 
 764                self.parent.cintensity
 765                )
 766                
 767        else: 
 768            print("Selected determination method does not exist.")
 769            sys.exit()
 770
 771
 772    ## Functions::
 773    def preprocess(self,preInit=0,preHough=0,preManual=0,
 774                   preVar=0,preSum=0,preInt=0):  
 775        """ FOR AUTOMATIC METHODS OPTIMIZATION AND MORE UNIVERSAL SOLUTIONS
 776        Function for input image preprocessing based on the methods 
 777        defined in the class initialization - self.detection_method, 
 778        self.correction_method.
 779
 780        Parameters
 781        ----------
 782        preInit : bool, optional
 783            Perform preprocessing of the input image (when using icut or heq). 
 784            This is called automatically every time, if no preprocessing
 785            specified, the detection and refinement will be performed on 
 786            original image. The default is 0.
 787        preHough : bool, optional
 788            Perform preprocessing for automatic detection via Hough transform. 
 789            
 790
 791        Returns
 792        -------
 793        manu : NumPy array
 794            Pre-processed image for the manual detection method
 795        edges : array of bool
 796            Detected edges via Canny detector for automatic Hough transform
 797        """
 798        
 799        # Flags
 800        control_print = 1
 801        
 802        # Load original image
 803        if len(self.parent.image.shape)!=2:
 804            self.parent.image = np.mean(self.parent.image,axis=2)
 805            
 806        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
 807        
 808        ### After initialization: perform an image enhancement if specified
 809        if preInit == 1:
 810            # Enhance diffraction pattern to make it more visible
 811            if self.parent.heq == 1:
 812                if self.parent.messages:
 813                    print("Histogram equalized.")
 814                image = sk.exposure.equalize_adapthist(image)
 815
 816                
 817            # # Edit contrast with a user-predefined parameter
 818            # if self.parent.icut is not None:
 819            #     if self.parent.messages:
 820            #         print("Contrast enhanced.")
 821            #     image = np.where(image > self.parent.icut, 
 822            #                      self.parent.icut, 
 823            #                      image)
 824                
 825
 826            self.parent.to_refine = image
 827            return
 828        
 829        ### Hough transform: perform pre-processing necessary for the detection
 830        if preHough == 1:           
 831            if self.parent.heq == 0:
 832                csq = self.central_square(self.parent.to_refine, csquare=80)   
 833                
 834                # Beam stopper present in image
 835                if np.median(csq)<100 and np.median(csq) > 0:
 836                    if self.parent.messages:
 837                        print('Beamstopper removed.')
 838                    max_indices=np.where(self.parent.to_refine>np.median(csq))
 839        
 840                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
 841                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
 842        
 843                    self.parent.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0    
 844                    
 845                    max_indices = \
 846                        np.where(self.parent.to_refine < 0.8*np.median(csq))
 847                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
 848                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
 849        
 850                    self.parent.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0   
 851                    
 852                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
 853                    edges = sk.feature.canny(self.parent.to_refine, 
 854                            sigma=0.2, 
 855                            low_threshold=2.5*np.median(self.parent.to_refine), 
 856                            high_threshold=3*np.median(self.parent.to_refine))
 857                    
 858                    # Dilate the edges to connect them
 859                    selem = sk.morphology.disk(5)
 860                    dilated_edges = sk.morphology.dilation(edges, selem)
 861                    
 862                    # Erode the dilated edges to reduce thickness and smooth the contour
 863                    connected_edges=sk.morphology.erosion(dilated_edges,selem)
 864
 865                    if control_print == 1:
 866                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
 867                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.parent.image, origin="upper")
 868                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
 869                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.parent.to_refine, origin="upper")
 870                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
 871                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
 872                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
 873                        ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges, origin="upper")
 874                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
 875                        plt.tight_layout()
 876                        plt.show(block=False)
 877                        
 878                # No beam stopper in image
 879                else:
 880                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
 881                    print('No beamstopper.')
 882                    edges = sk.feature.canny(self.to_refine, 
 883                                             sigma=0.2, 
 884                                             low_threshold=80, 
 885                                             high_threshold=100)
 886                    
 887                    # Dilate the edges to connect them
 888                    selem = sk.morphology.disk(10)
 889                    dilated_edges = sk.morphology.dilation(edges, selem)
 890                    
 891                    # Erode the dilated edges to reduce thickness and smooth the contour
 892                    connected_edges=sk.morphology.erosion(dilated_edges,selem)
 893                    connected_edges = sk.morphology.remove_small_objects(
 894                        connected_edges, 
 895                        min_size=100)
 896                    
 897                    if control_print == 1:
 898                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
 899                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
 900                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
 901                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
 902                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
 903                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper",)
 904                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
 905                        ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges,origin="upper")
 906                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
 907                        plt.tight_layout()
 908                        plt.show(block=False)
 909                
 910            elif self.heq == 1: 
 911                # Central square extraction
 912                csq = self.central_square(self.to_refine, csquare=80)   
 913
 914                # Beam stopper present in image
 915                if 0.4 <= np.median(csq) <= 0.6:
 916                    
 917                    max_indices = \
 918                        np.where(self.to_refine > 2*np.median(self.to_refine))
 919    
 920                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
 921                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
 922    
 923                    self.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0 
 924                                                     
 925                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
 926                    edges = sk.feature.canny(
 927                        self.to_refine, 
 928                        sigma=0.2, 
 929                        low_threshold=1.5*np.median(self.to_refine), 
 930                        high_threshold=3*np.median(self.to_refine))
 931
 932                    
 933                    if control_print == 1:
 934                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
 935                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
 936                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
 937                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
 938                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
 939                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
 940                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
 941                      #  ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges)
 942                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
 943                        plt.tight_layout()
 944                        plt.show(block=False)
 945                    
 946                # No beam stopper in image
 947                else:
 948                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
 949                    edges = sk.feature.canny(
 950                        self.to_refine, 
 951                        sigma=0.2, 
 952                        low_threshold=2.5*np.median(self.to_refine), 
 953                        high_threshold=3*np.median(self.to_refine))
 954
 955                    
 956                    if control_print == 1:
 957                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
 958                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
 959                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
 960                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
 961                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
 962                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
 963                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
 964                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
 965                        plt.tight_layout()
 966                        plt.show(block=False)
 967            
 968            return edges
 969        
 970    
 971    def detection_intensity(self, csquare, cintensity, plot_results=0):
 972        '''
 973        Find center of intensity/mass of an array.
 974        
 975        Parameters
 976        ----------
 977        arr : 2D-numpy array
 978            The array, whose intensity center will be determined.
 979        csquare : int, optional, default is 20
 980            The size/edge of the square in the (geometrical) center.
 981            The intensity center will be searched only within the central square.
 982            Reasons: To avoid other spots/diffractions and
 983            to minimize the effect of possible intensity assymetry around center. 
 984        cintensity : float, optional, default is 0.8
 985            The intensity fraction.
 986            When searching the intensity center, we will consider only
 987            pixels with intensity > max.intensity.
 988            
 989        Returns
 990        -------
 991        xc,yc : float,float
 992            XY-coordinates of the intensity/mass center of the array.
 993            Round XY-coordinates if you use them for image/array calculations.
 994        '''  
 995        
 996        # (1) Get image/array size
 997        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
 998        
 999                
1000        arr = np.copy(image)
1001        xsize,ysize = arr.shape
1002        
1003        # (2) Calculate borders around the central square
1004        xborder = (xsize - csquare) // 2
1005        yborder = (ysize - csquare) // 2
1006        
1007        # (3) Create the central square,
1008        # from which the intensity center will be detected
1009        arr2 = arr[xborder:-xborder,yborder:-yborder].copy()
1010        
1011        # (4) In the central square,
1012        # set all values below cintenstity to zero
1013        arr2 = np.where(arr2>np.max(arr2)*cintensity, arr2, 0)
1014        
1015        # (5) Determine the intensity center from image moments
1016        # see image moments in...
1017        # skimage: https://scikit-image.org/docs/dev/api/skimage.measure.html
1018        # wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_moment -> Centroid
1019        # ---
1020        # (a) Calculate 1st central moments of the image
1021        M = moments(arr2,1)
1022        # (b) Calculate the intensity center = centroid according to www-help
1023        (self.x, self.y) = (M[1,0]/M[0,0], M[0,1]/M[0,0])
1024        # (c) We have centroid of the central square
1025        # but we have to recalculate it to the whole image
1026        (self.x, self.y) = (self.x + xborder, self.y + yborder)
1027        # (d) Radius of a diffraction ring is hardcoded to 100 here
1028        self.r = 100
1029        
1030        # (6) User information (if required)
1031        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
1032            self.parent.dText = "Center Determination (IntensityCenter): ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1033
1034
1035        # (7) Plot results (if required)
1036        if plot_results == 1:
1037           self.visualize_center(self.x, self.y, self.r) 
1038                
1039        # (8) Return the results:
1040        # a) XY-coordinates of the center
1041        # b) radius of the circle/diff.ring,
1042        #    from which the center was determined
1043        # ! radius of the circle is just hardcoded here - see TODO note above
1044        return(self.x, self.y, self.r)
1045    
1046
1047    def detection_Hough(self, plot_results=0):
1048        '''        
1049        Perform Hough transform to detect center of diffraction patterns.
1050        This is a method to automatically detect circular diffraction patterns
1051        
1052        Parameters
1053        ----------
1054        plot_results : int, binary
1055            Plot the pattern determined by pixels selected by the user.
1056            Default is 1. To cancel visualization, set plot_results = 0.
1057
1058        Returns
1059        -------
1060        self.x : float64
1061            x-coordinate of the detected center
1062        self.y : float64
1063            y-coordinate of the detected center
1064        self.r : float64
1065            radius of the detected center
1066                                    
1067        '''
1068        ## Image preprocessing
1069        im = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1070        
1071        # if the brightness of the image is small enough, pixel values greater
1072        # than 50 will be set to 0 -- removal of the beam stopper influence
1073        
1074        if self.parent.heq == 0:
1075            if sum(sum(im)) < 150000:
1076                    max_indices = np.where(im > 50)
1077        
1078                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
1079                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
1080        
1081                    im[row_idx, col_idx] = 0    
1082                
1083            # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1084            edges = sk.feature.canny(im, 
1085                                     sigma=0.2, 
1086                                     low_threshold=80, 
1087                                     high_threshold=100)
1088        elif self.heq == 1:
1089            if sum(sum(im)) > 40000:
1090                max_indices = np.where(im > 50)
1091
1092                row_idx = max_indices[0]
1093                col_idx = max_indices[1]
1094
1095                im[row_idx, col_idx] = 0    
1096            
1097            # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1098            edges = sk.feature.canny(im, 
1099                                     sigma=0.2, 
1100                                     low_threshold=0.80, 
1101                                     high_threshold=1)
1102        
1103        
1104        # Define the radii range for the concentric circles
1105        # (set empirically based on the available pictures)
1106        min_radius = 40
1107        max_radius = 200
1108        radius_step = 10
1109        radii = np.arange(min_radius, max_radius + radius_step, radius_step)
1110
1111        ### Perform the Hough transform to detect circles
1112        # Circle detection involves converting edge pixels into parameter space, 
1113        # where each point represents a possible circle center and radius. 
1114        # The circles are then identified as peaks in the parameter space, 
1115        # enabling accurate detection of circular shapes in the image.
1116        hough_res = hough_circle(edges, radii)
1117
1118        # Extract the circle peaks
1119        _, self.x, self.y, self.r = hough_circle_peaks(hough_res, 
1120                                                            radii, 
1121                                                            total_num_peaks=1)
1122        
1123        
1124        # User information:
1125        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
1126            self.parent.dText = "Center Determination (HoughTransform) : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1127        
1128        self.x, self.y, self.r = \
1129            float(self.x[0]), float(self.y[0]), float(self.r[0])
1130
1131        # (7) Plot results (if required)
1132        if plot_results == 1:
1133           self.visualize_center(self.x, self.y, self.r) 
1134           
1135        # Return results, convert coordinates to float
1136        return self.x, self.y, self.r
1137
1138   
1139    def detection_3points(self, plot_results=0):
1140        '''         
1141        In the input image, select manually 3 points defining a circle using
1142        a key press event 
1143            - press '1' to select a point
1144                
1145        If the user is not satisfied with the point selection, it can be
1146        deleted using a key press event:
1147            - press '2' to delete the most recent
1148            - press '3' to delete the point closest to the cursor
1149        
1150        If the user is satisified with the points selected, the rest 
1151        of the program will be executed 
1152            - press 'd' to proceed >DONE<
1153        
1154        Coordinates of the center and radius will be calculated automatically
1155        using method self.calculate_circle()
1156        
1157        In addition, the user will be able to manually adjust the original
1158        center position by using pre-defined keys.
1159        
1160        Parameters
1161        ----------
1162        plot_results : int, binary
1163            Plot the pattern determined by pixels selected by the user.
1164            Default is 1. To cancel visualization, set plot_results = 0.
1165        
1166        Returns
1167        -------
1168        self.x : float64
1169            x-coordinate of the detected center
1170        self.y : float64
1171            y-coordinate of the detected center
1172        self.r : float64
1173            radius of the detected center
1174            (if available, othervise returns None)
1175                                    
1176        '''
1177        
1178        # Load image
1179        im = self.parent.to_refine
1180        
1181        # Edit contrast with a user-predefined parameter
1182        if self.parent.icut is not None:
1183            if self.parent.messages:
1184                print("Contrast enhanced.")
1185            im = np.where(im > self.parent.icut, 
1186                              self.parent.icut, 
1187                              im)
1188            
1189        # Create a figure and display the image
1190        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 12))
1191        
1192        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
1193        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
1194        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
1195 
1196        plt.title("Select 3 points defining one of diffraction circles", 
1197                  fontsize = 20)
1198        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
1199        ax.axis('off')
1200
1201        # User information:
1202        instructions = dedent(
1203            """
1204            CenterDetermination :: ThreePoints (semi-automated method)
1205            Select 3 points to define a diffraction circle using keys:
1206              - '1' : define a point at current cursor position
1207              - '2' : delete the last point
1208              - '3' : delete the point closest to the cursor
1209              - 'd' : done = finished = go to the next step
1210            Close the figure to terminate. No center will be detected.
1211            """)
1212
1213        if self.parent.messages:
1214            print(instructions)
1215       
1216        # Enable interactive mode
1217        # (figure is updated after every plotting command
1218        # (so that calling figure.show() is not necessary
1219        plt.ion()
1220 
1221        # Initialize the list of coordinates
1222        self.coords = [] 
1223        
1224        # Initialize all flags and counters
1225        calculate_circle_flag = False          # press 'd' event
1226        termination_flag = False               # close window event
1227        point_counter = 0                      # number of selected points
1228        
1229        ### Define the event handler for figure close event
1230        def onclose(event):
1231            nonlocal termination_flag
1232            termination_flag = True
1233            if self.parent.messages:
1234                print('Execution terminated.')
1235                print("------------------------------------------------------------")
1236
1237 
1238        # Connect the event handler to the figure close event
1239        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('close_event', onclose)
1240        
1241        
1242        ### Define the callback function for key press events
1243        def onkeypress(event):
1244            # nonlocal to modify the flag variable in the outer scope
1245            nonlocal calculate_circle_flag, point_counter, termination_flag
1246            
1247            # Store the zoom level
1248            current_xlim = ax.get_xlim()
1249            current_ylim = ax.get_ylim()
1250 
1251            ## Delete points -- the closest to the cursor
1252            if event.key == '3':
1253                point_counter -= 1
1254                if len(self.coords) > 0:
1255                    pointer_x, pointer_y = event.xdata, event.ydata
1256                    distances = [
1257                        np.sqrt((x - pointer_x)**2 + (y - pointer_y)**2)
1258                        for x, y in self.coords]
1259                    closest_index = np.argmin(distances)
1260                    del self.coords[closest_index]
1261    
1262                    ## Redraw the image without the deleted point
1263                    ax.clear()
1264                    ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
1265                              origin="upper")
1266                    for x, y in self.coords:
1267                        ax.scatter(x, y, 
1268                                   c='r', marker='x', 
1269                                   s=self.parent.marker_size)
1270
1271                    my_plot_title = (
1272                        "Select 3 points to define "
1273                        "one of diffraction circles.")
1274                    plt.title(my_plot_title, fontsize=20)
1275                    
1276                    # Retore the previous zoom level
1277                    ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
1278                    ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
1279                    ax.axis('off')
1280                    
1281                    fig.canvas.draw()
1282                else:
1283                    print("No points to delete.")
1284    
1285            # Delete recent point (last added) -- independent on the cursor
1286            if event.key == '2':
1287                # Check if there are points to delete
1288                if point_counter > 0:  
1289                    point_counter -= 1
1290                    if len(self.coords) > 0:
1291                        # Delete the last point in the list
1292                        del self.coords[-1]
1293    
1294                        # Redraw the image without the deleted point
1295                        ax.clear()
1296                        ax.imshow(im, cmap=self.parent.cmap,
1297                                  origin="upper")
1298                        for x, y in self.coords:
1299                            ax.scatter(x, y,
1300                                       c='r', marker='x', 
1301                                       s=self.parent.marker_size)
1302
1303                        my_plot_title = (
1304                            "Select 3 points to define "
1305                            "one of diffraction circles.")
1306                        plt.title(my_plot_title)
1307                        
1308                        # Retore the previous zoom level
1309                        ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
1310                        ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
1311                        ax.axis('off')
1312
1313                        fig.canvas.draw()
1314                else:
1315                    print("No points to delete.")
1316                    
1317            ## Select points 
1318            elif event.key == '1':
1319                # Only allow selecting up to three points
1320                if point_counter < 3:  
1321                    # Save the coordinates of the clicked point
1322                    new_point = (event.xdata, event.ydata)
1323                    
1324                    if new_point in self.coords:
1325                        # Do not allow multiple selection of one point
1326                        print("The selected point already exists.")
1327                    else:
1328                        # Add selected point
1329                        self.coords.append(new_point)
1330    
1331                        # Visualize the selected point on the image
1332                        ax.scatter(event.xdata, event.ydata, 
1333                                   c='r', marker='x', 
1334                                   s=self.parent.marker_size)
1335
1336                        # Restore the previous zoom level
1337                        ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
1338                        ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
1339                        ax.axis('off')
1340
1341                        fig.canvas.draw()
1342    
1343                        point_counter += 1
1344
1345    
1346                if len(self.coords) == 3:
1347                    # Turn off interactive mode
1348                    plt.ioff()
1349    
1350
1351    
1352            # Calculate circle or terminate
1353            elif event.key == 'd':
1354                if len(self.coords) == 3:
1355                    calculate_circle_flag = True
1356 
1357                else:
1358                    print("Select exactly 3 points to calculate the circle.")
1359                    fig.canvas.draw()
1360    
1361        # Connect the callback function to the key press event
1362        cid0 = fig.canvas.mpl_connect('key_press_event', onkeypress)
1363
1364        # Show the plot
1365        plt.tight_layout()
1366        ax.axis('off')
1367
1368        plt.show(block=False)
1369      
1370        # Wait for 'd' key event or close the figure if no points are selected
1371        while not calculate_circle_flag and not termination_flag:
1372 
1373            try:
1374                plt.waitforbuttonpress(timeout=0.1)
1375                # Store the zoom level
1376                current_xlim = ax.get_xlim()
1377                current_ylim = ax.get_ylim()
1378 
1379                # Plot detected diffraction pattern
1380                if calculate_circle_flag:
1381 
1382                    self.calculate_circle(plot_results=0)
1383                    
1384                    ax.clear()
1385                    ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
1386                              origin="upper")
1387                    # Retore the previous zoom level
1388                    ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
1389                    ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
1390                 
1391                    circle = plt.Circle(
1392                        (self.x, self.y), self.r, color='r', fill=False)
1393                    ax.add_artist(circle)
1394        
1395                    # Plot center point
1396                    center, = ax.plot(self.x, self.y, 'rx', markersize=12)
1397                    plt.title('Manually adjust the position of the center using keys.')
1398        
1399                    # Display the image
1400                    plt.draw()
1401                    ax.axis('off')
1402
1403                    plt.show(block = False)
1404
1405            except KeyboardInterrupt:
1406                print("Execution manually interrupted by user.")
1407                break
1408            except ValueError as e:
1409                print("ValueError:", e)
1410                break
1411           
1412        # If the termination_flag is True, stop the code
1413        if termination_flag: 
1414             print("No points selected. Returned None values.")
1415             sys.exit()
1416             return None, None, None
1417        
1418        # Disconnect key press events
1419        fig.canvas.mpl_disconnect(cid0) 
1420        
1421        # local variables save
1422        self.center = center
1423        
1424        self.backip = [self.x, self.y, self.r]
1425        # Manually adjust the calculated center coordinates
1426        self.x, self.y, self.r = self.adjustment_3points(fig, circle, center)
1427
1428        # Return the results:
1429        # a) XY-coordinates of the center
1430        # b) radius of the circle/diff.ring,
1431        #    from which the center was determined
1432        return(self.x, self.y, self.r)
1433    
1434    
1435    def adjustment_3points(self, fig, circle, center, plot_results=0) -> tuple:
1436        '''
1437        Adjustment of the center position calculated from 3 points.
1438        Interactive refinement using keys:
1439
1440        The user can change the position of the center of the diffraction
1441        pattern and also the radius of the detected pattern using keys:
1442            - left / right / top / down arrows : move left / right / top / down
1443            - '+' : increase radius
1444            - '-' : decrease radius
1445            - 'd' : done, termination of the refinement
1446
1447        If the interactive figure is closed without any modifications,
1448        the function returns input variables and the proccess terminates.
1449        
1450        Parameters
1451        ----------
1452        fig : figure.Figure object
1453            interactive figure in which a diffraction pattern has been
1454            manually detected.
1455        circle : patches.Circle object
1456            circle defined via 3 points manually delected
1457        center : tuple
1458            calculated center of the input circle.
1459        plot_results : boolean
1460            visualize results. The default is 1 (plot detected center).
1461
1462        Returns
1463        -------
1464        xy : tuple
1465            x,y-coordinates of the center of the diffraction pattern.
1466        r : integer
1467            radius of the diffraction pattern.
1468
1469        '''            
1470        # Remove default left / right arrow key press events
1471        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].remove('left')
1472        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].remove('right')
1473        
1474        if self.parent.messages:
1475            instructions = dedent(
1476            """
1477            CenterDetermination :: ThreePoints (interactive adjustment)
1478            Use these keys:
1479              - '←' : move left
1480              - '→' : move right
1481              - '↑' : move up
1482              - '↓' : move down
1483              - '+' : increase circle radius
1484              - '-' : decrease circle radius
1485              - 'b' : increase step size
1486              - 'l' : decrease step size
1487              - 'd' : refinement done
1488                  
1489            DISCLAIMER: For the purpose of the center position adjustment, 
1490                        the default shortcuts for arrows were removed.
1491            """)
1492            print(instructions)
1493        
1494        if self.parent.print_sums:
1495            print("Intensity sums during refinement:")
1496            
1497        # Initialize variables and flags
1498        self.backip = np.array((self.x, self.y))
1499        xy = np.array((self.x, self.y))
1500        r = np.copy(self.r)
1501        termination_flag = False
1502        
1503        plt.title("Manually adjust the center position.", fontsize=20)
1504
1505        plt.ion()
1506          
1507        ### Define the event handler for figure close event
1508        def onclose(event):
1509            nonlocal termination_flag
1510            termination_flag = True
1511
1512        # Connect the event handler to the figure close event
1513        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('close_event', onclose)
1514        
1515        # Define the callback function for key press events
1516        def onkeypress2(event):
1517            # Use nonlocal to modify the center position in the outer scope
1518            nonlocal xy, r, termination_flag
1519        
1520            # OTHER KEYS USED IN INTERACTIVE FIGURES
1521            #   event.key == '1': select a point in self.detection_3points()
1522            #   event.key == '2': delete the last point in self.detection...
1523            #   event.key == '3': delete a point in self.detection...
1524            #   event.key == '+': increase circle radius
1525            #   event.key == '-': decrease circle radius           
1526            #   event.key == 'b': increase the step size (big step size)
1527            #   event.key == 'l': decrease the step size (little step size)
1528            #   event.key == 'd': proceed in self.detection_3points()
1529        
1530            if event.key in ['up', 'down', 'left', 'right', '+', '-']:                    
1531                if event.key in ['+', '-']:
1532                    r += 1 if event.key == '+' else -1
1533                else:
1534                    # Perform shifts normally
1535                    if event.key == 'up':
1536                        xy[1] -= self.step
1537                    elif event.key == 'down':
1538                        xy[1] += self.step
1539                    elif event.key == 'left':
1540                        xy[0] -= self.step
1541                    elif event.key == 'right':
1542                        xy[0] += self.step
1543                    
1544                    # Print sum only for arrow keys
1545                    if self.parent.print_sums:
1546                        s = self.parent.intensity_sum(self.parent.to_refine, 
1547                                                      xy[0], xy[1], r)
1548                        print(f'{s:.2f}')
1549            
1550            # Terminate the interactive refinement with 'd' key
1551            if event.key == 'd':
1552                termination_flag = True
1553        
1554            # Change step size 
1555            if event.key == 'b':
1556                self.step = self.step * 5
1557        
1558            if event.key == 'l':
1559                self.step = self.step / 5
1560                if self.step < 0.5:
1561                    self.step = 0.5
1562        
1563            # Update the plot with the new center position
1564            circle.set_center((xy[0], xy[1]))  # circle
1565            circle.set_radius(r)               # radius
1566            center.set_data([xy[0]], [xy[1]])  # center
1567        
1568            plt.title("Manually adjust the center position.", fontsize=20)
1569        
1570            # Update the plot
1571            plt.draw()
1572
1573                
1574        # Disconnect the on_key_press1 event handler from the figure
1575        fig.canvas.mpl_disconnect(fig.canvas.manager.key_press_handler_id)
1576        
1577        # Connect the callback function to the key press event
1578        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('key_press_event', onkeypress2)
1579
1580        # Enable interaction mode
1581        plt.ion() 
1582               
1583        # Wait for 'd' key press or figure closure
1584        while not termination_flag:
1585            try:
1586                plt.waitforbuttonpress(timeout=0.1)
1587            except KeyboardInterrupt:
1588                # If the user manually closes the figure, terminate the loop
1589                termination_flag = True
1590                
1591        # Turn off interactive mode
1592        plt.ioff()
1593        
1594        # Display the final figure with the selected center position and radius
1595        plt.tight_layout()
1596
1597        plt.show(block=False)
1598        
1599        # If the termination_flag is True, stop the code
1600        if termination_flag: 
1601            plt.close()  # Close the figure
1602
1603        # User information:
1604        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
1605            self.parent.dText = "Center Determination (ThreePoints)    : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1606        
1607    
1608        return xy[0], xy[1], r
1609    
1610       
1611    def calculate_circle(self, plot_results:int)->tuple[
1612            float,float,float,tuple[float,float], plt.Circle]:
1613        ''' 
1614        Calculates coordinates of the center and radius of a circle defined via
1615        3 points determined by the user. Plots the calculated circle, detected 
1616        points and marks the center.
1617        
1618        Parameters
1619        ----------
1620        plot_results : int, binary
1621            Plot the calculated center and circle. To cancel visualization, 
1622            set plot_results = 0.
1623        self.coords : array of float64
1624            Coordinates of 3 manually selected points
1625        
1626        Returns
1627        -------
1628        self.x : float64
1629            x-coordinate of the detected center
1630        self.y : float64
1631            y-coordinate of the detected center
1632        self.r : float64
1633            radius of the detected center
1634                                    
1635        '''
1636        # Extract the coordinates of the points        
1637        x = [self.coords[0][0], self.coords[1][0], self.coords[2][0]]
1638        y = [self.coords[0][1], self.coords[1][1], self.coords[2][1]]
1639        
1640        # Compute the radius and center coordinates of the circle
1641            # a: the squared length of the side between the second 
1642            #    and third points (x[1], y[1]) and (x[2], y[2]).
1643            # b: the squared length of the side between the first 
1644            #    and third points (x[0], y[0]) and (x[2], y[2]).
1645            # c: the squared length of the side between the first 
1646            #    and second points (x[0], y[0]) and (x[1], y[1]).
1647            # s: the twice the signed area of the triangle formed by 3 points
1648            
1649        c = (x[0]-x[1])**2 + (y[0]-y[1])**2
1650        a = (x[1]-x[2])**2 + (y[1]-y[2])**2
1651        b = (x[2]-x[0])**2 + (y[2]-y[0])**2
1652        s = 2*(a*b + b*c + c*a) - (a*a + b*b + c*c) 
1653        
1654        # coordinates of the center
1655        self.x = (a*(b+c-a)*x[0] + b*(c+a-b)*x[1] + c*(a+b-c)*x[2]) / s
1656        self.y = (a*(b+c-a)*y[0] + b*(c+a-b)*y[1] + c*(a+b-c)*y[2]) / s 
1657        
1658        # radius
1659        ar = a**0.5
1660        br = b**0.5
1661        cr = c**0.5 
1662        self.r = ar*br*cr/((ar+br+cr)*(-ar+br+cr)*(ar-br+cr)*(ar+br-cr))**0.5
1663        
1664        # # Print results
1665        # if self.parent.messages:
1666        #     print("CenterEstimator :: manual center detection")
1667        #     print(f"Center coordinates: {self.x:.2f} {self.y:.2f}")
1668                    
1669        if plot_results==1:
1670            # Create and manage the figure
1671            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1672            manager = plt.get_current_fig_manager()
1673            manager.window.showMaximized()
1674            ax.imshow(self.parent.image, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
1675                      origin="upper")
1676            
1677            # Plot center and points
1678            center, = plt.plot(self.x, self.y, 
1679                     'rx', 
1680                     label='Center', 
1681                     markersize=12)
1682            plt.scatter(x,y, 
1683                        marker='x', 
1684                        color='palevioletred', 
1685                        label = 'Circle points')
1686            plt.title('Circle found using 3 manually detected points')
1687            
1688            # Circle visualization
1689            circle = plt.Circle((self.x,self.y), 
1690                                self.r, 
1691                                color='palevioletred', 
1692                                fill=False,
1693                                label = 'pattern')
1694            ax.add_artist(circle)
1695            
1696            # Set the aspect ratio to equal to have a circular shape
1697            plt.axis('equal')
1698            
1699            plt.legend(loc='lower center', 
1700                       ncol=2, 
1701                       bbox_to_anchor=(0.5,-0.1), 
1702                       mode='expand', 
1703                       frameon=False)
1704            plt.axis('off')
1705            plt.tight_layout()
1706            plt.show(block=False)
1707
1708        
1709        self.center = (self.x, self.y)
1710        self.circle = plt.Circle((self.x,self.y),self.r)
1711        
1712
1713        return self.x, self.y, self.r, self.center, self.circle
1714
1715
1716    def get_radius(
1717            self, im:np.ndarray, x:float, y:float, disp:bool=False) -> float:
1718        """
1719        Calculate the radius of a circle based on intensity profiles along 
1720        horizontal and vertical axes.
1721    
1722        Parameters
1723        ----------
1724        im : np.ndarray
1725            The 2D image array containing the circle.
1726        x : float
1727            The x-coordinate of the circle's center.
1728        y : float
1729            The y-coordinate of the circle's center.
1730        disp : bool, optional
1731            If True, visualizes the detected intensity profiles and peaks 
1732            (default is False).
1733    
1734        Returns
1735        -------
1736        float
1737            The estimated radius of the circle. Defaults to 100 if no valid 
1738            radius is detected.
1739        """
1740        
1741        def match_peaks(arr):
1742            """
1743            Finds the most similar values across the left and right halves of 
1744            an array, omitting the highest value. If exactly two peaks are 
1745            detected, they are returned as the best pair.
1746            """
1747            if len(arr) < 2:  # Not enough values to compare
1748                if self.parent.messages:
1749                    print("Not enough values to find similar pairs.")
1750                return None, None
1751    
1752            # Special case: if there are exactly 2 peaks, return them
1753            if len(arr) == 2:
1754                if self.parent.messages:
1755                    print("Exactly two peaks detected. Returning them as the best pair.")
1756                return 0, 1
1757    
1758            # Find the index of the highest value
1759            center_idx = np.argmax(arr)
1760    
1761            # Split into left and right halves, excluding the highest value
1762            left = arr[:center_idx]
1763            right = arr[center_idx + 1:]
1764            left_indices = np.arange(center_idx)
1765            right_indices = np.arange(center_idx + 1, len(arr))
1766    
1767            if len(left) == 0 or len(right) == 0:  # Check for empty halves
1768                if self.parent.messages:
1769                    print("One of the halves is empty.")
1770                return None, None
1771    
1772            # Initialize variables for tracking the smallest difference
1773            smallest_diff = np.inf
1774            best_pair = (None, None)
1775    
1776            # Compare each value in the left with every value in the right
1777            for i, l_val in enumerate(left):
1778                for j, r_val in enumerate(right):
1779                    diff = abs(l_val - r_val)
1780                    if diff < smallest_diff:
1781                        smallest_diff = diff
1782                        best_pair = (left_indices[i], right_indices[j])
1783    
1784            return best_pair
1785    
1786        self.xpeaks, self.ypeaks = None, None
1787        self.xyvals, self.yyvals = None, None
1788    
1789        x_line = im[int(x), :]
1790        y_line = im[:, int(y)]
1791    
1792        # Define threshold for peak detection
1793        x_thr = 0.5 * max(x_line)
1794        y_thr = 0.5 * max(y_line)
1795    
1796        # Find peaks with dynamic height thresholds
1797        self.xpeaks, _ = find_peaks(x_line, 
1798                                    height=x_thr, 
1799                                    prominence=1, 
1800                                    distance=30)
1801        self.xyvals = x_line[self.xpeaks]
1802        self.ypeaks, _ = find_peaks(y_line, 
1803                                    height=y_thr, 
1804                                    prominence=1, 
1805                                    distance=30)
1806        self.yyvals = y_line[self.ypeaks]
1807    
1808        # Define half the length of the image
1809        half_length_x = x_line.shape[0] / 2
1810        half_length_y = y_line.shape[0] / 2
1811    
1812        # Check the additional condition for xpeaks
1813        if len(self.xpeaks) == 2 and (
1814            (self.xpeaks[0]<half_length_x and self.xpeaks[1]<half_length_x) or
1815            (self.xpeaks[0]>half_length_x and self.xpeaks[1]>half_length_x)):
1816            if self.parent.messages:
1817                print("xpeaks condition met: Both peaks are on the same side of the center.")
1818            self.pairX = None
1819        else:
1820            self.pairX = match_peaks(self.xyvals)
1821    
1822        # Check the additional condition for ypeaks
1823        if len(self.ypeaks) == 2 and (
1824            (self.ypeaks[0]<half_length_y and self.ypeaks[1]<half_length_y) or
1825            (self.ypeaks[0]>half_length_y and self.ypeaks[1]>half_length_y)):
1826            if self.parent.messages:
1827                print("ypeaks condition met: Both peaks are on the same side of the center.")
1828            self.pairY = None
1829        else:
1830            self.pairY = match_peaks(self.yyvals)
1831    
1832        # Determine radius based on available pairs
1833        if self.pairX is None or None in self.pairX:
1834            rx_x = None
1835        else:
1836            x1 = self.xpeaks[self.pairX[0]]
1837            x2 = self.xpeaks[self.pairX[1]]
1838            rx_x = abs(x1 - x2) / 2
1839    
1840        if self.pairY is None or None in self.pairY:
1841            rx_y = None
1842        else:
1843            y1 = self.ypeaks[self.pairY[0]]
1844            y2 = self.ypeaks[self.pairY[1]]
1845            rx_y = abs(y1 - y2) / 2
1846    
1847        if rx_x is not None and rx_y is not None:
1848            rx = np.mean([rx_x, rx_y])
1849        elif rx_x is not None:
1850            rx = rx_x
1851        elif rx_y is not None:
1852            rx = rx_y
1853        else:
1854            if self.parent.messages:
1855                print("No valid pairs detected for radius calculation.")
1856            return 100  # Default radius or error handling
1857    
1858        if disp:
1859            # Plot xline with peaks
1860            plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
1861    
1862            # Plot for xline
1863            plt.subplot(2, 1, 1)
1864            plt.plot(x_line, label='xline')
1865            plt.plot(self.xpeaks, self.xyvals, "ro", label='Peaks')
1866            plt.title('Peaks in xline')
1867            plt.xlabel('Index')
1868            plt.ylabel('Value')
1869            plt.legend()
1870    
1871            # Plot for yline
1872            plt.subplot(2, 1, 2)
