1873            plt.plot(y_line, label='yline')
1874            plt.plot(self.ypeaks, self.yyvals, "ro", label='Peaks')  
1875            plt.title('Peaks in yline')
1876            plt.xlabel('Index')
1877            plt.ylabel('Value')
1878            plt.legend()
1879    
1880            plt.tight_layout()
1881            plt.show()
1882    
1883        return rx
1884
1885        
1886    def visualize_center(self, x: float, y: float, r: float) -> None:
1887        '''         
1888        Visualize detected diffraction patterns and mark the center.
1889        
1890        Parameters
1891        ----------
1892        tit : string
1893            name of the method used for circle detection
1894        x : float64
1895            x-coordinate of the detected center
1896        y : float64
1897            y-coordinate of the detected center
1898        r : float64
1899            radius of the detected center
1900        
1901        Returns
1902        -------
1903        None.
1904                            
1905        '''
1906        # Load image
1907        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1908    
1909        if self.parent.icut is not None:
1910            im = np.where(image > self.parent.icut, self.parent.icut, image)
1911        else:
1912            im = np.copy(image)
1913            
1914        # Create a figure and display the image
1915        fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1916        
1917        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
1918        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
1919        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
1920 
1921        plt.title("Detected center")
1922        ax.axis('off')
1923
1924        # Plot center point
1925        ax.scatter(x,y,
1926                label= f'center:  [{x:.1f}, {y:.1f}]',
1927                marker='x', color="red", s=60)
1928
1929        plt.legend(loc='upper right')
1930        
1931        # Display the image
1932        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
1933        plt.axis('off')
1934        plt.tight_layout()
1935        plt.show(block=False)
1936
1937
1938
1939class CenterRefinement:
1940    '''
1941    CenterRefinement object - final refinement of a diffractogram center.
1942
1943    This class is responsible for refining the center coordinates of a 
1944    diffraction pattern based on the selected refinement method. It 
1945    initializes with the input image and other parameters that influence 
1946    the refinement process.
1947
1948    Parameters
1949    ----------
1950    parent : CenterLocator
1951        Reference to the parent CenterLocator object, allowing access to 
1952        shared attributes and methods.
1953    input_image : str, path, or numpy.array
1954        The input image representing a 2D diffraction pattern, provided as 
1955        a file path or a NumPy array.
1956    refinement : str or None, optional, default is None
1957        The method used for the final center refinement.
1958        Options include:
1959        - 'manual': Manual adjustment - user adjust the position
1960          of the selected diffration ring.
1961        - 'sum': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring
1962          with maximal sum of intensities.
1963        - 'var': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring
1964          with minimal variance of intensities.
1965    out_file : str, optional
1966        Filename of the text file to which the refined center coordinates 
1967        will be saved.
1968    heq : bool, optional
1969        Flag to indicate whether to perform histogram equalization on the
1970        input image. Default is False.
1971    icut : float, optional
1972        Cut-off intensity level for processing the image. Default is None.
1973    cmap : str, optional
1974        Colormap to be used for displaying the image. Default is 'gray'.
1975    messages : bool, optional
1976        Flag to enable or disable informational messages during processing. 
1977        Default is False.
1978    print_sums : bool, optional
1979        If True, prints the sum of intensity values for the refined circle 
1980        after each adjustment, relevant only for manual refinement methods.
1981
1982    Returns
1983    -------
1984    None
1985
1986    Notes
1987    -----
1988    - The class refines the detected center coordinates based on the 
1989      specified refinement method.
1990    - The refined coordinates are stored in instance variables
1991      `xx`, `yy`, and `rr`, representing the refined center's x-coordinate, 
1992      y-coordinate, and radius, respectively.
1993    - If an unsupported refinement method is specified, the class will print 
1994      an error message and exit.
1995    '''
1996    
1997    def __init__(self, parent,
1998                 input_image, 
1999                 refinement = None,
2000                 in_file = None,
2001                 out_file = None,
2002                 heq = False, 
2003                 icut = None,
2004                 cmap = 'gray',
2005                 messages = False,
2006                 print_sums = False):
2007        
2008        ######################################################################
2009        # PRIVATE FUNCTION: Initialize CenterLocator object.
2010        # The parameters are described above in class definition.
2011        ######################################################################
2012        
2013        ## (0) Initialize input attributes
2014        self.parent = parent
2015        
2016        ## (1) Initialize new attributes
2017        self.step=0.5
2018        
2019        ## (2) Run functions
2020        if refinement is not None:
2021            self.ret = 1
2022            par_short = self.parent.center1
2023        
2024            if refinement == "manual":
2025                # Manual refinement method
2026                if parent.determination == 'manual':
2027                    self.xx, self.yy, self.rr = \
2028                        par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r
2029                    par_short.x, par_short.y = \
2030                        par_short.backip[0], par_short.backip[1]
2031                    if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
2032                        self.parent.rText = \
2033                            "Center Refinement (Interactive)       : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
2034                elif parent.determination == 'intensity':
2035                    self.yy, self.xx, self.rr = self.ref_interactive(
2036                        par_short.y, par_short.x, par_short.r)
2037                else:
2038                    self.yy, self.xx, self.rr = self.ref_interactive(
2039                        par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r)
2040        
2041            elif refinement == "var":
2042                # Intensity variance refinement
2043                self.xx, self.yy, self.rr = self.ref_var(
2044                    par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r)
2045        
2046            elif refinement == "sum":
2047                # Intensity sum refinement
2048                self.xx, self.yy, self.rr = self.ref_sum(
2049                    par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r)
2050        
2051            else:
2052                print("Selected refinement method is not supported.")
2053                sys.exit()
2054                        
2055        else: 
2056            self.ret = 2
2057            
2058           
2059    def ref_interactive(self, px, py, pr):
2060        ''' 
2061        Manual refinement of the detected diffraction pattern via one of 
2062        the methods provided in the class CircleDetection.
2063        
2064        The user can change the position of the center of the diffraction
2065        pattern and also the radius of the detected pattern using keys:
2066            - left / right / top / down arrows : move left / right / top / down
2067            - '+' : increase radius
2068            - '-' : decrease radius
2069            - 'b'/'l' : increase/decrease step size")
2070            - 'd' : done, termination of the refinement
2071
2072        If the interactive figure is closed without any modifications,
2073        the function returns input variables and the proccess terminates.
2074        
2075        The results are shown in a figure when the refinement is successful.
2076
2077        Parameters
2078        ----------
2079        px : float64
2080            x-coordinate of the center
2081        py : float64
2082            y-coordinate of the center
2083        pr : float64
2084            radius of the circular diffraction pattern
2085
2086        Returns
2087        -------
2088        x : float64
2089            new x-coordinate of the center
2090        y : float64
2091            new y-coordinate of the center
2092        r : float64
2093            new radius of the circular diffraction pattern
2094        '''
2095        
2096        # Load original image
2097        im = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
2098
2099        # Edit contrast with a user-predefined parameter
2100        if self.parent.icut is not None:
2101            if self.parent.messages:
2102                print("Contrast enhanced.")
2103            im = np.where(im > self.parent.icut, 
2104                              self.parent.icut, 
2105                              im)
2106            
2107        
2108        # Initialize variables and flags
2109        xy = np.array((px, py))
2110        r = np.copy(pr)
2111        termination_flag = False
2112
2113        # User information:
2114        if self.parent.messages:
2115            instructions = dedent("""
2116            
2117            Interactive refinement. Use these keys:
2118                  - '←' : move left
2119                  - '→' : move right
2120                  - '↑' : move up
2121                  - '↓' : move down
2122                  - '+' : increase circle radius
2123                  - '-' : decrease circle radius
2124                  - 'b' : increase step size
2125                  - 'l' : decrease step size
2126                  - 'd' : refinement done
2127                  
2128            DISCLAIMER: For the purpose of the center shift, the default
2129            shortcuts for left and right arrows were removed.
2130            """)
2131            print(instructions)
2132        
2133        if self.parent.print_sums:
2134            print("Intensity sums during refinement:")
2135            
2136        # Create a figure and display the image
2137        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 12))
2138        
2139        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
2140        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
2141        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
2142        
2143        circle = plt.Circle(
2144            (px, py), pr, color='r', fill=False)
2145        ax.add_artist(circle)
2146
2147        # Plot center point
2148        center, = ax.plot(px, py, 'rx', markersize=12)
2149                    
2150
2151        plt.title('Manually adjust the center position.', 
2152                  fontsize=20)
2153
2154        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
2155        ax.axis('off')
2156        
2157        # Enable interactive mode
2158        plt.ion()
2159        
2160
2161        # Display the image
2162        # fig.set_size_inches(self.fig_width, self.fig_height)
2163        plt.show(block=False)
2164        
2165        ### Define the event handler for figure close event
2166        def onclose(event):
2167            nonlocal termination_flag
2168            termination_flag = True
2169 
2170        # Connect the event handler to the figure close event
2171        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('close_event', onclose)
2172
2173        # Define the callback function for key press events
2174        def onkeypress2(event):
2175            # Use nonlocal to modify the center position in the outer scope
2176            nonlocal xy, r, termination_flag
2177        
2178            # OTHER KEYS USED IN INTERACTIVE FIGURES
2179            #   event.key == '1': select a point in self.detection_3points()
2180            #   event.key == '2': delete the last point in self.detection...
2181            #   event.key == '3': delete a point in self.detection...
2182            #   event.key == '+': increase circle radius
2183            #   event.key == '-': decrease circle radius           
2184            #   event.key == 'b': increase the step size (big step size)
2185            #   event.key == 'l': decrease the step size (little step size)
2186            #   event.key == 'd': proceed in self.detection_3points()
2187        
2188            if event.key in ['up', 'down', 'left', 'right', '+', '-']:                    
2189                if event.key in ['+', '-']:
2190                    r += 1 if event.key == '+' else -1
2191                else:
2192                    # Perform shifts normally
2193                    if event.key == 'up':
2194                        xy[1] -= self.step
2195                    elif event.key == 'down':
2196                        xy[1] += self.step
2197                    elif event.key == 'left':
2198                        xy[0] -= self.step
2199                    elif event.key == 'right':
2200                        xy[0] += self.step
2201                    
2202                    # Print sum only for arrow keys
2203                    if self.parent.print_sums:
2204                        s = self.parent.intensity_sum(self.parent.to_refine, 
2205                                                      xy[0], xy[1], r)
2206                        print(f'{s:.2f}')
2207            
2208            # Terminate the interactive refinement with 'd' key
2209            if event.key == 'd':
2210                termination_flag = True
2211        
2212            # Change step size 
2213            if event.key == 'b':
2214                self.step = self.step * 5
2215        
2216            if event.key == 'l':
2217                self.step = self.step / 5
2218                if self.step < 0.5:
2219                    self.step = 0.5
2220        
2221            # Update the plot with the new center position
2222            circle.set_center((xy[0], xy[1]))  # circle
2223            circle.set_radius(r)               # radius
2224            center.set_data([xy[0]], [xy[1]])  # center
2225        
2226            plt.title("Manually adjust the center position.", fontsize=20)
2227        
2228            # Update the plot
2229            plt.draw()
2230
2231            
2232        # Disconnect the on_key_press1 event handler from the figure
2233        fig.canvas.mpl_disconnect(fig.canvas.manager.key_press_handler_id)
2234        
2235        # Connect the callback function to the key press event
2236        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('key_press_event', onkeypress2)
2237
2238        # Enable interaction mode
2239        plt.ion() 
2240               
2241        # Wait for 'd' key press or figure closure
2242        while not termination_flag:
2243            try:
2244                plt.waitforbuttonpress(timeout=0.1)
2245            except KeyboardInterrupt:
2246                # If the user manually closes the figure, terminate the loop
2247                termination_flag = True
2248         
2249        # Turn off interactive mode
2250        plt.ioff()
2251        
2252        # Display the final figure with the selected center position and radius
2253        plt.tight_layout()
2254
2255        plt.show(block=False)
2256        
2257        # If the termination_flag is True, stop the code
2258        if termination_flag: 
2259            plt.close()  # Close the figure
2260
2261        # User information:
2262        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
2263            self.parent.rText = "Center Refinement (Interactive)       : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
2264
2265        return xy[0], xy[1], r    
2266        
2267    
2268    def ref_var(self, px, py, pr, plot_results=0):
2269        '''         
2270        Adjust center coordinates of a detected circular diffraction pattern.
2271        The center adjustment is based on variance minimization.
2272        
2273        The 8-neighbourhood pixels (x) of the current center (o) 
2274        will be tested regarding the minimization:
2275    
2276        - x x x : (px - dx, py + dy) (px, py + dy) ( px + dx, py + dy)
2277    
2278        - x o x : (px - dx, py)      (px, py)      (px + dx, py)
2279    
2280        - x x x : (px - dx, py - dy) (px, py - dy) (px + dx, py - dy)
2281        
2282
2283        Parameters
2284        ----------
2285        self.image : array of uint8
2286            Input image in which the diffraction pattern is to be found
2287        px : float64
2288            x-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted
2289        py : float64
2290            y-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted
2291        pr : float64
2292            radius of the detected center
2293        plot_results : integer (default = 1)
2294            Plot Detected center. The default is 1.
2295        
2296        Returns
2297        -------
2298        px : array of int32
2299           corrected x-coordinates of pixels from circle border
2300        py : array of int32
2301            corrected y-coordinates of pixels from circle border
2302        pr : array of int32
2303            radius of the detected center
2304            
2305        '''
2306        
2307        # Store input for plot
2308        bckup = [np.copy(px), np.copy(py), np.copy(pr)]
2309        
2310        # Load image
2311        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
2312
2313        # Starting values to be modified 
2314        init_var = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, px, py, pr)
2315        min_intensity_var = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, px, py, pr)
2316        best_center = (np.copy(px), np.copy(py))
2317        best_radius = np.copy(pr)
2318    
2319        # Convergence criterion for termination of gradient optimization 
2320        # (1) small positive value that serves as a threshold to determine 
2321        #     when the optimization process has converged
2322        convergence_threshold = 0.1*min_intensity_var
2323        
2324        # (2) maximum number of iterations of optimization
2325        max_iterations = 10
2326        
2327        # (3) keep track of the number of consecutive iterations where there 
2328        #     is no improvement in the objective function beyond 
2329        #     the convergence threshold
2330        no_improvement_count = 0
2331    
2332    
2333        # iterative refinement of the center of a circle while keeping
2334        # the radius constant.
2335        step = 0.3
2336        neighbors = [(float(dx), float(dy))
2337            for dx in np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)
2338            for dy in np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)]
2339        
2340        for iteration in range(max_iterations):    
2341            # Refine center while keeping radius constant
2342            curr = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, 
2343                                      best_center[0], 
2344                                      best_center[1], 
2345                                      best_radius) 
2346            # Store intensity sums of the current center's neighborhood
2347            curr_intensity_var = []
2348            for dx, dy in neighbors:
2349                nx, ny = best_center[0] + dx, best_center[1] + dy
2350                # Check if the point is within the expanded search radius
2351                curr_intensity_var.append(
2352                    self.parent.intensity_variance(image, nx, ny, best_radius))
2353            
2354            # Find the minimum value coordinates within curr_intensity_var
2355            cx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmin(curr_intensity_var),
2356                                     [len(curr_intensity_var),1])
2357                    
2358            # Check for improvement of criterion -- in each iteration just once,
2359            # as the algorithm checks the neighbourhood of the best center (in
2360            # each iteration, the center is updated if possible)
2361            if min(curr_intensity_var) <= min_intensity_var:                           
2362                min_intensity_var = max(curr_intensity_var)
2363                
2364                # Calculate the new best coordinates of the center
2365                n = neighbors[cx]
2366                (nx, ny) = tuple(map(lambda x, y: float(x) + float(y), 
2367                                     best_center, n))
2368                best_center = px, py = (np.copy(nx), np.copy(ny))
2369                
2370            # Update maximum intensity sum 
2371            min_intensity_var = self.parent.intensity_var(image, 
2372                                                    best_center[0], 
2373                                                    best_center[1], 
2374                                                    best_radius) 
2375            
2376            # Refine radius if necessary while keeping the center position 
2377            # constant. It iterates through different radius adjustments to find
2378            # a radius that maximizes the intensity sum of pixels
2379            
2380            radi_intensity_var = []
2381            radii = np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)
2382            for dr in radii:
2383                new_radius = best_radius + dr
2384                radi_intensity_var.append(self.parent.intensity_var(image, 
2385                                                             best_center[0], 
2386                                                             best_center[1], 
2387                                                             new_radius))
2388                
2389            # Find the minimum value coordinates within curr_var
2390            rx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmin(radi_intensity_var),
2391                                      [len(radi_intensity_var),1])
2392            
2393            # Check for improvement of criterion
2394            if max(radi_intensity_var) < min_intensity_var:
2395                min_intensity_var = max(radi_intensity_var)
2396                
2397                n = radii[rx]
2398                nr = best_radius+n
2399                
2400                best_radius = pr = np.copy(nr)
2401
2402            
2403            # Check for convergence and improvement (termination conditions)
2404            impr = abs(min_intensity_var - curr)
2405            if impr < convergence_threshold:
2406                no_improvement_count += 1
2407                if no_improvement_count == 5:
2408                    break
2409        
2410        # Avoid incorrect/redundant refinement
2411        ## (1) swapped coordinates
2412        if ((bckup[0] > bckup[1] and not best_center[0] > best_center[1])
2413            or  (bckup[0] < bckup[1] and not best_center[0] < best_center[1])):
2414            best_center = best_center[::-1]
2415        
2416        ## (2) worsened final maximum intensity sum than the initial one
2417        if np.round(init_var,-2) < np.round(min_intensity_var,-2):
2418            print("Refinement redundant.")
2419            best_center = np.copy(bckup)
2420    
2421        # Print results
2422        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
2423            self.parent.rText = "Center Refinement (IntensityVar)      : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
2424                                  
2425        return best_center[0], best_center[1], best_radius
2426    
2427    
2428    def ref_sum(self, px, py, pr, plot_results=0):
2429        ''' 
2430        Adjust center position based on gradient optimization method
2431        via maximization of intensity sum.
2432        
2433        The 8-neighbourhood pixels (x) of the current center (o) 
2434        will be tested regarding the maximization:
2435    
2436        - x x x : (px - dx, py + dy) (px, py + dy) ( px + dx, py + dy)
2437    
2438        - x o x : (px - dx, py)      (px, py)      (px + dx, py)
2439    
2440        - x x x : (px - dx, py - dy) (px, py - dy) (px + dx, py - dy)
2441        
2442    
2443        Parameters
2444        ----------
2445        px : float64
2446            x-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted.
2447        py : float64
2448            y-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted.
2449        pr : float64
2450            radius of the detected center.
2451        plot_results : int, optional
2452            Plot Detected center. 
2453            The default is 1.
2454    
2455        Returns  
2456        -------
2457        best_center[0] : float64
2458            Adjusted x-coordinate of the center.
2459        best_center[1] : float64
2460            Adjusted y-coordinate of the center.
2461        best_radius : float64
2462            The adjusted radius of the circular diffraction pattern.
2463        '''
2464        # Store input for plot via self.visualize_refinement()
2465        bckup = [np.copy(px), np.copy(py), np.copy(pr)]
2466
2467        # Image in which the center is refined
2468        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
2469
2470        # Starting values to be modified 
2471        init_sum = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, px, py, pr)
2472        max_intensity_sum = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, px, py, pr)
2473        best_center = (np.copy(px), np.copy(py))
2474        best_radius = np.copy(pr)
2475        
2476        # Convergence criterion for termination of gradient optimization 
2477        # (1) small positive value that serves as a threshold to determine 
2478        #     when the optimization process has converged
2479        convergence_threshold = 0.05*max_intensity_sum
2480        
2481        # (2) maximum number of iterations of optimization
2482        max_iterations = 100
2483        
2484        # (3) keep track of the number of consecutive iterations where there 
2485        #     is no improvement in the objective function beyond 
2486        #     the convergence threshold
2487        no_improvement_count = 0
2488         
2489        # iterative refinement of the center of a circle while keeping
2490        # the radius constant.
2491        step = 0.2
2492        neighbors = [(float(dx), float(dy))
2493            for dx in np.arange(-1.0, 1.0 + step, step)
2494            for dy in np.arange(-1.0, 1.0 + step, step)]
2495
2496        for iteration in range(max_iterations):    
2497            # Refine center while keeping radius constant
2498            curr = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
2499                                      best_center[0], 
2500                                      best_center[1], 
2501                                      best_radius)
2502            
2503            # Store intensity sums of the current center's neighborhood
2504            curr_intensity_sum = []
2505            for dx, dy in neighbors:
2506                nx, ny = best_center[0] + dx, best_center[1] + dy
2507                # Check if the point is within the expanded search radius
2508                curr_intensity_sum.append(self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
2509                                                        nx, ny, 
2510                                                        best_radius))
2511            
2512            # Find the maximum value coordinates within curr_sum
2513            cx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(curr_intensity_sum),
2514                                     [len(curr_intensity_sum),1])
2515                    
2516            # Check for improvement of criterion -- in each iteration just once,
2517            # as the algorithm checks the neighbourhood of the best center (in
2518            # each iteration, the center is updated if possible)
2519            if max(curr_intensity_sum) > max_intensity_sum:                           
2520                max_intensity_sum = max(curr_intensity_sum)
2521                
2522                # Calculate the new best coordinates of the center
2523                n = neighbors[cx]
2524                (nx, ny) = tuple(map(lambda x, y: float(x) + float(y), 
2525                                     best_center, n))
2526                best_center = px, py = (np.copy(nx), np.copy(ny))
2527    
2528            # Update maximum intensity sum 
2529            max_intensity_sum = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
2530                                                    best_center[0], 
2531                                                    best_center[1], 
2532                                                    best_radius)
2533
2534        
2535            # Refine radius if necessary while keeping the center position 
2536            # constant. It iterates through different radius adjustments to find
2537            # a radius that maximizes the intensity sum of pixels
2538            
2539            radi_intensity_sum = []
2540            radii = np.arange(-1.0, 1.0 + step, step)
2541            for dr in radii:
2542                new_radius = best_radius + dr
2543                radi_intensity_sum.append(self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
2544                                                            best_center[0], 
2545                                                            best_center[1], 
2546                                                            new_radius))
2547                
2548            # Find the maximum value coordinates within curr_sum
2549            rx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(radi_intensity_sum),
2550                                      [len(radi_intensity_sum),1])
2551
2552            # Check for improvement of criterion
2553            if max(radi_intensity_sum) > max_intensity_sum:
2554                max_intensity_sum = max(radi_intensity_sum)
2555                
2556                n = radii[rx]
2557                nr = best_radius+n
2558                
2559                best_radius = pr = np.copy(nr)
2560                
2561            
2562            # Check for convergence and improvement (termination conditions)
2563            impr = abs(max_intensity_sum - curr)
2564            if impr < convergence_threshold:
2565                no_improvement_count += 1
2566                if no_improvement_count == 25:
2567                    break
2568                
2569
2570        
2571        # Avoid incorrect/redundant refinement
2572        # ## (1) swapped coordinates
2573        # if ((bckup[0] > bckup[1] and not best_center[0] > best_center[1])
2574        #     or  (bckup[0] < bckup[1] and not best_center[0] < best_center[1])):
2575        #     best_center = best_center[::-1]
2576        
2577        ## (2) worsened final maximum intensity sum than the initial one
2578        if np.round(init_sum,-2) > np.round(max_intensity_sum,-2):
2579            print("Refinement redundant.")
2580            best_center = np.copy(bckup)
2581    
2582        # Print results
2583        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
2584            self.parent.rText = \
2585                "Center Refinement (IntensitySum)      : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
2586                
2587        return best_center[0], best_center[1], best_radius
2588

2591class HandlerCircle(HandlerBase):
2592    """
2593    Helper class for creating circular markers in matplotlib legends.
2594
2595    This class customizes the legend to display circular markers instead of the 
2596    default. It is intended for internal use within the module and not 
2597    for general use.
2598
2599    Methods:
2600    --------
2601    create_artists(legend, 
2602                   orig_handle, 
2603                   xdescent,
2604                   ydescent, 
2605                   width, 
2606                   height, 
2607                   fontsize, 
2608                   trans):
2609        Creates a circular marker for the legend based on the original handle's 
2610        properties.
2611
2612    Parameters for `create_artists`:
2613        legend : matplotlib.legend.Legend
2614            The legend instance where the custom marker will be used.
2615        orig_handle : matplotlib.artist.Artist
2616            The original handle containing the marker properties 
2617            (e.g., facecolor, edgecolor).
2618        xdescent : float
2619            Horizontal offset adjustment for the marker.
2620        ydescent : float
2621            Vertical offset adjustment for the marker.
2622        width : float
2623            Width of the legend entry.
2624        height : float
2625            Height of the legend entry.
2626        fontsize : float
2627            Font size of the legend text.
2628        trans : matplotlib.transforms.Transform
2629            Transformation applied to the marker's coordinates.
2630
2631    Returns:
2632    --------
2633    list of matplotlib.patches.Circle
2634        A list containing a single circular marker artist.
2635    """
2636
2637    def create_artists(self, legend, orig_handle, xdescent, ydescent, 
2638                       width, height, fontsize, trans):
2639        # Calculate the center and radius of the circle
2640        x = width / 2
2641        y = height / 2
2642        r = min(width, height) / 2
2643
2644        # Create a circular marker using the properties of the original handle
2645        marker = Circle((x, y), r,
2646                        facecolor=orig_handle.get_facecolor(),
2647                        edgecolor=orig_handle.get_edgecolor(),
2648                        linewidth=orig_handle.get_linewidth(),
2649                        transform=trans)
2650
2651        return [marker]

2653
2654class IntensityCenter: 
2655    '''
2656    Simple center determination for a symmetric diffractogram.
2657    
2658    * The center is determined as a center of intensity.
2659    * This works well for simple, symmetric diffraction patters, which are:
2660      (i) without beamstopper, (ii) pre-centered, and (iii) powder-like.
2661    * A real-life example of a simple symmetric diffractogram:
2662      a good powder electron diffraction pattern from STEMDIFF software.
2663    * This class is a legacy from previous EDIFF versions;
2664      it is kept mostly for backward compatibility.
2665      The functions in this class can be (and should be)
2666      replaced by a simple call of ediff.center.CenterLocator object.
2667      
2668    >>> # Center determination in a simple symmetric diffraction pattern
2669    >>> # (center = just center_of_intensity, no refinement
2670    >>>
2671    >>> # (1) Old way = this (old, legacy) IntensityCenter class:
2672    >>> xc,yc = ediff.center.IntensityCenter.center_of_intensity(
2673    >>>     arr, csquare=30, cintensity=0.8)
2674    >>>
2675    >>> # (2) New way = newer (and more universal) CenterLocator class:
2676    >>> xc,yc = ediff.center.CenterLocator(
2677    >>>     arr, detection_method='intensity', csquare=30, cintensity=0.8)
2678    '''
2679    
2680    @staticmethod
2681    def center_of_intensity(arr, csquare=20, cintensity=0.8):
2682        '''
2683        Find center of intensity/mass of an array.
2684        
2685        Parameters
2686        ----------
2687        arr : 2D-numpy array
2688            The array, whose intensity center will be determined.
2689        csquare : int, optional, default is 20
2690            The size/edge of the square in the (geometrical) center.
2691            The intensity center is searched only within the central square.
2692            Reasons: To avoid other spots/diffractions and
2693            to minimize the effect of an intensity assymetry around center. 
2694        cintensity : float, optional, default is 0.8
2695            The intensity fraction.
2696            When searching the intensity center, we will consider only
2697            pixels with intensity > max.intensity.
2698            
2699        Returns
2700        -------
2701        xc,yc : float,float
2702            XY-coordinates of the intensity/mass center of the array.
2703            Round XY-coordinates if you use them for image/array calculations.    
2704        '''
2705        # Get image/array size
2706        xsize,ysize = arr.shape
2707        # Calculate borders around the central square
2708        xborder = (xsize - csquare) // 2
2709        yborder = (ysize - csquare) // 2
2710        # Create central square = cut off the borders
2711        arr2 = arr[xborder:-xborder,yborder:-yborder].copy()
2712        # In the central square, set all values below cintenstity to zero
2713        arr2 = np.where(arr2>np.max(arr2)*cintensity, arr2, 0)
2714        # Calculate 1st central moments of the image
2715        M = sk.measure.moments(arr2,1)
2716        # Calculate the intensity center = centroid according to www-help
2717        (xc,yc) = (M[1,0]/M[0,0], M[0,1]/M[0,0])
2718        # We have centroid of the central square => recalculate to whole image
2719        (xc,yc) = (xc+xborder,yc+yborder)
2720        
2721        ## Return the final center
2722        return(xc,yc)
2723
2724

2729
class CenterLocator: 
 53class CenterLocator:
 54    '''
 55    CenterLocator object - determine and refine a diffractogram center.
 56
 57    Parameters
 58    ----------
 59    input_image : str, path, or numpy.array
 60        The input image representing a 2D diffraction pattern, either as a 
 61        file path or a NumPy array.
 62    determination : str or None, optional, default is None
 63        The method used for the initial center determination.
 64        Options include:
 65        - 'manual': Manual detection - user defines 3 points
 66          on selected diffraction ring.
 67        - 'hough': Auto-detection - Hough transform for circle detection.
 68        - 'intensity': Auto-detection - intensity center in central region.
 69    refinement : str or None, optional, default is None
 70        The method used for the final center refinement.
 71        Options include:
 72        - 'manual': Manual adjustment - user adjust the position
 73          of the selected diffration ring.
 74        - 'sum': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring
 75          with maximal sum of intensities.
 76        - 'var': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring
 77          with minimal variance of intensities.
 78    in_file : str, optional, default is None
 79        Filename of the text file
 80        for saving the center coordinates.
 81    out_file : str, optional, default is None
 82        Filename of the text file
 83        for loading the previously saved center coordinates.
 84    heq : bool, optional, default is False
 85        Flag to indicate whether to perform histogram equalization 
 86        on the input image.
 87        The equalization is done internally,
 88        the image on the screen remains unchanged.
 89    icut : float, optional, default is None
 90        Cut-off intensity level for processing the image.
 91    cmap : str, optional, default is 'gray'
 92        Colormap to be used for displaying the image. 
 93    csquare : int, optional, default is 50
 94        Size of the central square,
 95        within which we will search the intensity center.
 96    cintensity : float, optional, default is 0.8
 97        Threshold intensity
 98        for finding the intensity center.
 99        Pixels with a (relative) intensity lower than cintensity are ignored.
100    messages : bool, optional, default is False
101        Flag to enable or disable informational messages during processing. 
102    print_sums : bool, optional, default is False
103        If True, prints the sum of intensity values for the refined circle 
104        after each adjustment, relevant only for manual methods of center 
105        determination and refinement.
106    final_print : bool, optional, default is True
107        If True, print determined and refined coordinates to stdout.
108 
109    Returns
110    -------
111    None
112        The center coordinates are stored in instance variables
113        (x1,y1) for the determined center and
114        (x2,y2) for the refined center.
115        Look at the initial example at the top of this module
116        to see how to use CenterLocator class.
117            
118    Technical notes
119    ---------------
120    * The class initializes (and runs) two sub-classes (= processes),
121      CenterDetermination and CenterRefinement.
122    * The two sub-classes/processes are hidden to common user,
123      altough they could be run separately.
124    '''
125    
126    
127    def __init__(self,
128                 input_image, 
129                 determination = None, 
130                 refinement = None,
131                 in_file = None,
132                 out_file = None,
133                 heq = False, 
134                 icut = None,
135                 cmap = 'gray',
136                 csquare=50,
137                 cintensity=0.8,
138                 messages = False,
139                 print_sums = False,
140                 final_print = True):
141        
142        ######################################################################
143        # PRIVATE FUNCTION: Initialize CenterLocator object.
144        # The parameters are described above in class definition.
145        ######################################################################
146
147        ## (0) Initialize input attributes
148        
149        # Input image = diffraction pattern
150        # (it can be either image file or numpy array
151        self.input_image = input_image
152        
153        # Methods of center determination and center refinement
154        self.determination = determination
155        self.refinement = refinement
156        # For reproducibility, convert the method names to lowercase
157        if determination is not None:
158            self.determination = determination.lower()
159        if refinement is not None:
160            self.refinement = refinement.lower()
161        
162        # Text files for reading/saving center coordinates
163        self.in_file = in_file
164        self.out_file = out_file
165        
166        # Additional parameters
167        self.heq = heq
168        self.icut = icut
169        self.cmap = cmap
170        self.csquare = csquare
171        self.cintensity = cintensity
172        self.messages = messages
173        self.print_sums = print_sums
174        self.final_print = final_print
175        
176        ## (1) Initialize new attributes
177        
178        self.to_refine = []
179        self.dText = []
180        self.rText = []
181        
182        # The value of the following attribute can be adjusted
183        self.marker_size = 100          
184
185        ## (2) Read input image
186        
187        # The input image can be numpy.array (ndarray) or image file (path/str)
188        if isinstance(input_image, np.ndarray):
189            self.image = input_image
190        else:
191            self.image = ediff.io.read_image(self.input_image)
192            
193        ## (3) Read center coordinates
194        
195        # * The center coordinates may have been determined
196        #   in a previous run of the program and saved to a text file.
197        # * We can Load coordinates from an input file if specified,
198        #   this is done by the following commant.
199        # * As the saved coordinates can be used INSTEAD of CenterDetermination
200        #   we will read them here.
201        if self.in_file is not None: self.load_results()  
202        
203        ## (4) Run CenterDetermination
204        
205        # (4a) Initialize/run CenterDetermination
206        self.center1 = CenterDetermination(self,
207                self.input_image,
208                self.determination,
209                self.heq,
210                self.icut,
211                self.cmap,
212                self.csquare,
213                self.cintensity,
214                self.messages,
215                self.print_sums)
216        
217        # (4b) Find radius of a circle/diffraction ring,
218        #      which is needed for the next step = CenterRefimenement.
219        if self.determination != "manual":
220            self.center1.r = self.center1.get_radius(
221                self.image, 
222                self.center1.x, 
223                self.center1.y, 
224                disp=False)
225
226        ## (5) Initialize/run CenterRefinement
227        
228        self.center2 = CenterRefinement(self,
229            self.input_image, 
230            self.refinement,
231            self.in_file,
232            self.out_file,
233            self.heq, 
234            self.icut,
235            self.cmap,
236            self.messages,
237            self.print_sums)
238        
239        ## (6) Collect results from CenterDetermination + CenterRefinement
240        self.x1 = self.center1.x
241        self.y1 = self.center1.y
242        
243        if self.refinement is not None:
244            self.x2 = self.center2.xx
245            self.y2 = self.center2.yy
246        else: 
247            self.x2 = self.center1.x
248            self.y2 = self.center1.y
249            self.center2.xx = self.center1.x
250            self.center2.yy = self.center1.y
251            self.center2.rr = self.center1.r
252        
253        ## (7) Switch coordinates if necessary
254        if (self.determination == "intensity"):
255                self.x1, self.y1 = self.convert_coords(self.x1, self.y1)
256                self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2)  
257        
258        if (self.determination =="hough" and self.refinement == "manual"):
259            self.x2, self.y2 = self.convert_coords(self.x2, self.y2)  
260
261        ## (8) Print the coordinates if required
262        if self.final_print:
263            self.dText=str(self.dText)
264            self.rText=str(self.rText)
265            
266            print("----------------------------------------------------------")
267            print(self.dText.format(float(self.x1),float(self.y1)))
268            
269            if self.refinement is not None:
270                print(self.rText.format(float(self.x2),float(self.y2)))
271                        
272        ## (9) Save results to a .txt file if specified
273        if out_file is not None:
274            self.save_results()
275
276    
277    def output(self):
278        """
279        Return the final results of center determination and refinement. 
280        
281        Returns
282        -------
283        x1 : float
284            x-coordinate of the center from *determination* method
285        y1 : float
286            y-coordinate of the center from *determination* method
287        x2 : float
288            x-coordinate of the center from *refinement* method
289        y2 : float
290            y-coordinate of the center from *refinement* method
291            
292        Technical note
293        --------------
294        * The function always returns four parameters.
295        * In most cases, the output are four coordinates (x1,y1,x2,y2).
296        * If the *refinement* method was None, the output is (x1,y1,x1,y1);
297          i.e. the *determined* and *refined* center coordinates are the same.
298        """
299        
300        # (1) Refinement method was not None => prepare (x1,y1,x2,y2)
301        if self.center2.ret == 1:
302            # Convert to float
303            if type(self.x1) != float:
304                self.x1, self.y1, self.x2, self.y2 = \
305                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1, self.y1, 
306                                                self.x2, self.y2)]
307        # (2) Refinement method was None => prepare (x1,y1) = (x2,y2)                      
308        else:
309            # Convert to float
310            if type(self.x1) != float:
311                self.x1, self.y1 = \
312                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1,self.y1)]
313            # Define x2,y2 = x1,y1
314            self.x2 = self.x1
315            self.y2 = self.y1
316            
317        # (3) Return (rounded) values of center coordinates
318        return (np.round(self.x1,1), np.round(self.y1,1), 
319                np.round(self.x2,1), np.round(self.y2,1))  
320
321    
322    def save_results(self):
323        '''
324        Save the current results to a specified file. The results are formatted 
325        to four decimal places for clarity.
326
327        
328        This method checks if a file path has been provided through 
329        the `in_file` attribute. 
330        
331        - If the specified file exists, the method appends the results 
332        (x1, y1, x2, y2) to the end of the file. 
333        - If the file does not exist, it creates a new file and writes 
334        the results to it.
335        
336        
337        Parameters
338        ----------
339        None
340        
341        Returns
342        -------
343        None
344        
345        Notes
346        -----
347        - The results are written in the format:
348            x1: <value>, y1: <value>
349            x2: <value>, y2: <value>
350        '''
351        
352        if self.out_file is not None:
353            # Check if the specified file exists
354            if os.path.isfile(self.out_file):
355                # Append results to in_file
356                with open(self.out_file, 'a') as f:  # Open in append mode
357                    f.write(f"x1: {self.x1:.4f}, y1: {self.y1:.4f}\n")
358                    f.write(f"x2: {self.x2:.4f}, y2: {self.y2:.4f}\n")
359            else:
360                # If the file does not exist, create it and write results
361                with open(self.out_file, 'w') as f:  # Open in write mode
362                    f.write(f"x1: {self.x1:.4f}, y1: {self.y1:.4f}\n")
363                    f.write(f"x2: {self.x2:.4f}, y2: {self.y2:.4f}\n")
364
365
366    def load_results(self):
367        '''
368        Load results from a specified text file.
369    
370        This method reads the coordinates from a text file defined by the 
371        `out_file` attribute. It extracts pairs of coordinates (x1, y1) and 
372        (x2, y2) from each line in the file. The extracted values are stored in 
373        lists, allowing for the retrieval of multiple results.The most recent 
374        values of x1, y1, x2, and y2 can be stored as instance variables
375        for easy access.
376    
377        Parameters
378        ----------
379        None
380    
381        Returns
382        -------
383        None
384    
385        Notes
386        -----
387        - The results are expected to be in the format:
388            x1: <value>, y1: <value>
389            x2: <value>, y2: <value>
390        - If multiple sets of coordinates are found, they are stored in lists,
391        and only the last set can be accessed as instance variables.
392        '''        
393        
394        if self.in_file is not None and os.path.isfile(self.in_file):
395            with open(self.in_file, 'r') as f:
396                lines = f.readlines()
397                
398                # Initialize lists to hold multiple values
399                x1_values = []
400                y1_values = []
401                x2_values = []
402                y2_values = []
403    
404                for line in lines:
405                    # Strip and split each line to get the coordinates
406                    parts = line.strip().split(',')
407                    if len(parts) == 2:
408                        # Extract x1 and y1 or x2 and y2 based on line content
409                        if 'x1' in parts[0]:
410                            x1 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
411                            y1 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
412                            x1_values.append(x1)
413                            y1_values.append(y1)
414                        elif 'x2' in parts[0]:
415                            x2 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
416                            y2 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
417                            x2_values.append(x2)
418                            y2_values.append(y2)
419    
420                # Store the last set of values as instance variables 
421                self.x1 = x1_values
422                self.y1 = y1_values
423                self.x2 = x2_values
424                self.y2 = y2_values
425    
426                # Store the last loaded values:
427                if x1_values and y1_values and x2_values and y2_values:
428                    self.x1 = x1_values[-1]
429                    self.y1 = y1_values[-1]
430                    self.x2 = x2_values[-1]
431                    self.y2 = y2_values[-1]
432    
433        else:
434            print("Error reading text file with center coordinates!")
435
436
437    def get_circle_pixels(self, xc, yc, radius, num_points=360):
438        '''         
439        Get coordinates of pixels defining circle border
440    
441        Parameters
442        ----------
443        self.image_path : str
444            direct path to a image with diffraction patterns
445        xc : float64
446            x-coordinate of the detected center
447        yc : float64
448            y-coordinate of the detected center
449        radius : float64
450            radius of the detected center
451        num_points : float64 
452            number of border points. The default is 360
453        
454        Returns
455        -------
456        x : array of float64
457            x-coordinates of pixels from circle border
458        y : array of float64
459            y-coordinates of pixels from circle border
460            
461        '''
462        
463        # Generate angles from 0 to 2*pi
464        theta = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, num=num_points)  
465                
466        # Calculate x,y-coordinates of points on the actual circle border
467        x_actual = xc + radius * np.cos(theta)
468        y_actual = yc + radius * np.sin(theta)
469        
470        return x_actual, y_actual
471          
472    
473    def intensity_sum(self, image, px, py, pr):
474        ''' 
475        Summation of intensity values of pixels of a diffraction pattern.
476
477        Parameters
478        ----------
479        image : array of uint8
480            image from which the diffraction pattern has been detected.
481        px : float64
482            x-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
483        py : float64
484            y-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
485        pr : float64
486            radius of the diffraction pattern.
487
488        Returns
489        -------
490        s : float64
491            intensity sum
492
493        '''
494        # Extract pixels on the circle border
495        pxc, pyc = self.get_circle_pixels(px, py, pr)
496        pxc = np.array(pxc, dtype=int)
497        pyc = np.array(pyc, dtype=int)
498        
499        # Calculate sum using the filtered values
500        s = np.sum(image[pyc, pxc])/len(pxc)
501
502        return s
503    
504    
505    def intensity_variance(self, image, px, py, pr):
506        ''' 
507        Variance of intensity values of pixels of a diffraction pattern.
508
509        Parameters
510        ----------
511        image : array of uint8
512            image from which the diffraction pattern has been detected.
513        px : float64
514            x-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
515        py : float64
516            y-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
517        pr : float64
518            radius of the diffraction pattern.
519
520        Returns
521        -------
522        s : float64
523            intensity variance
524
525        '''
526        # Extract pixels on the circle border
527        pxc, pyc = self.get_circle_pixels(px, py, pr)
528        pxc = np.array(pxc, dtype=int)
529        pyc = np.array(pyc, dtype=int)
530        
531        # Calculate sum using the filtered values
532        s = np.var(image[pxc, pyc])
533        return s
534    
535    
536    def convert_coords(self, x, y):
537        """
538        Convert coordinates between numpy and matplotlib systems.
539    
540        Parameters:
541        ----------
542        x : int or float
543            The x-coordinate in the numpy (column index) format.
544        y : int or float
545            The y-coordinate in the numpy (row index) format.
546    
547        Returns:
548        -------
549        tuple of (int or float, int or float)
550            The converted coordinates in matplotlib format, where:
551            - First element corresponds to y (new x in matplotlib).
552            - Second element corresponds to x (new y in matplotlib).
553        """
554        return y, x
555
556
557    def visualize_results(self, csquare=None):
558        '''
559        Visualize diffractogram and its center after
560        center determination + refinement.
561    
562        Parameters
563        ----------
564        csquare : int, optional, default is None
565            If csquare argument is given,
566            only the central square of the diffractogram will be plotted;
567            the size of the central square will be equal to csquare argument.
568    
569        Returns
570        -------
571        None
572            The output is the image of the diffractogram
573            showing also the central coordinates and refinement ring.
574        '''
575        
576        # (0) Collect center coordinates and radii
577        # x1,y1,r1 = coordinates and radius of the determined circle/ring
578        # x2,y2,r2 = coordinates and radius of the refined circle/ring
579        x1, y1 = (self.x1, self.y1)
580        r1 = self.center1.r
581        x2, y2 = (self.x2, self.y2)
582        r2  = self.center2.rr
583        
584        # (1) Prepare the image of the diffractogram
585        # ...copy diffractogram image
586        image = np.copy(self.to_refine)
587        # ...cut image intensity if required
588        if self.icut is not None:
589            im = np.where(image > self.icut, self.icut, image)
590        else:
591            im = np.copy(image)
592            
593        # (2) Calculate intensity sum or intensity variance
594        if self.refinement == "var":
595            # Refinement was based on minimizing the intensity variance
596            dvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x1, y1, r1)
597            rvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x2, x2, r2)
598            labeld = (
599                f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]'
600                + '\n' + f'int-var: {dvar:.1f}')
601            labelr = (
602                f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]'
603                + '\n' + f'int-var: {rvar:.1f}')
604        else:
605            # All other cases: manual refinement or maximixing intensity sum
606            dsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x1, y1, r1)
607            rsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x2, x2, r2)
608            labeld = (
609                f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]'
610                + '\n' + f'int-sum: {dsum:.1f}')
611            labelr = (
612                f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]'
613                + '\n' + f'int-sum: {rsum:.1f}')
614            
615        # (3) Calculate xy-limits if we want to see only the central square
616        # (if csquare argument was given, we will plot only the central square
617        # (to achieve this, we pre-calculate params for ax.set_xlim/set_ylim
618        # (the precalculated parameters will be used below during plotting
619        if csquare is not None:
620            xmin,xmax = (0, image.shape[0])
621            ymin,ymax = (0, image.shape[1])
622            edge = (xmax-csquare) // 2
623            xmin = xmin + edge
624            xmax = xmax - edge
625            ymin = ymin + edge
626            ymax = ymax - edge
627    
628        # (4) Final plot: show the diffractogram + refinement results
629        # ...prepare figure
630        fig, ax = plt.subplots()
631        # ...show diffraction pattern
632        ax.imshow(im, cmap=self.cmap, origin="upper")
633        # ...set the title of the whole figure
634        ax.set_title(
635            f'Center Location ({self.determination}/{self.refinement})')
636        # ...add initial center (after CenterDetermination)
637        ax.scatter(x1, y1,
638                   label=labeld, color='red', marker='x', s=60, lw=1)
639        # ...add initial circle (after CenterDetermination)
640        c0 = plt.Circle((x1, y1), r1,
641                        color='red', fill=False, label='detected', lw=1)
642        ax.add_patch(c0)    
643        # ...add final center coordinates (after CenterRefinement)
644        ax.scatter(x2, y2,
645                   label=labelr, color='springgreen', marker='x', lw=1, s=60)
646        # ...add final cirlce (after CenterRefinement)
647        c1 = plt.Circle((x2,y2), r2,
648                        color='springgreen', fill=False, label='refined', lw=1)
649        ax.add_patch(c1)
650        # ...move legend to the top right next to the image
651        ax.legend(loc='upper left', frameon=False, #fontsize=10,
652                  handler_map={Circle: HandlerCircle()}, ncol=1,
653                  bbox_to_anchor=(.98, 1.01), 
654                  bbox_transform=ax.transAxes)
655        # ...set xlim/ylim if we want to see only the central square
656        if csquare is not None:
657            ax.set_xlim(xmin,xmax)  # the xmin/xmax were pre-calculated above
658            ax.set_ylim(ymin,ymax)  # the ymin/ymax were pre-calculated above
659        # ...do not hide axis decorations = labels, spines, ticks...
660        ax.axis('on')
661        # ...show the plot
662        plt.show(block=False)

CenterLocator object - determine and refine a diffractogram center.

Parameters
  • input_image (str, path, or numpy.array): The input image representing a 2D diffraction pattern, either as a file path or a NumPy array.
  • determination (str or None, optional, default is None): The method used for the initial center determination. Options include:
    • 'manual': Manual detection - user defines 3 points on selected diffraction ring.
    • 'hough': Auto-detection - Hough transform for circle detection.
    • 'intensity': Auto-detection - intensity center in central region.
  • refinement (str or None, optional, default is None): The method used for the final center refinement. Options include:
    • 'manual': Manual adjustment - user adjust the position of the selected diffration ring.
    • 'sum': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring with maximal sum of intensities.
    • 'var': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring with minimal variance of intensities.
  • in_file (str, optional, default is None): Filename of the text file for saving the center coordinates.
  • out_file (str, optional, default is None): Filename of the text file for loading the previously saved center coordinates.
  • heq (bool, optional, default is False): Flag to indicate whether to perform histogram equalization on the input image. The equalization is done internally, the image on the screen remains unchanged.
  • icut (float, optional, default is None): Cut-off intensity level for processing the image.
  • cmap (str, optional, default is 'gray'): Colormap to be used for displaying the image.
  • csquare (int, optional, default is 50): Size of the central square, within which we will search the intensity center.
  • cintensity (float, optional, default is 0.8): Threshold intensity for finding the intensity center. Pixels with a (relative) intensity lower than cintensity are ignored.
  • messages (bool, optional, default is False): Flag to enable or disable informational messages during processing.
  • print_sums (bool, optional, default is False): If True, prints the sum of intensity values for the refined circle after each adjustment, relevant only for manual methods of center determination and refinement.
  • final_print (bool, optional, default is True): If True, print determined and refined coordinates to stdout.
Returns
  • None: The center coordinates are stored in instance variables (x1,y1) for the determined center and (x2,y2) for the refined center. Look at the initial example at the top of this module to see how to use CenterLocator class.
Technical notes
  • The class initializes (and runs) two sub-classes (= processes), CenterDetermination and CenterRefinement.
  • The two sub-classes/processes are hidden to common user, altough they could be run separately.
def output(self): 
277    def output(self):
278        """
279        Return the final results of center determination and refinement. 
280        
281        Returns
282        -------
283        x1 : float
284            x-coordinate of the center from *determination* method
285        y1 : float
286            y-coordinate of the center from *determination* method
287        x2 : float
288            x-coordinate of the center from *refinement* method
289        y2 : float
290            y-coordinate of the center from *refinement* method
291            
292        Technical note
293        --------------
294        * The function always returns four parameters.
295        * In most cases, the output are four coordinates (x1,y1,x2,y2).
296        * If the *refinement* method was None, the output is (x1,y1,x1,y1);
297          i.e. the *determined* and *refined* center coordinates are the same.
298        """
299        
300        # (1) Refinement method was not None => prepare (x1,y1,x2,y2)
301        if self.center2.ret == 1:
302            # Convert to float
303            if type(self.x1) != float:
304                self.x1, self.y1, self.x2, self.y2 = \
305                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1, self.y1, 
306                                                self.x2, self.y2)]
307        # (2) Refinement method was None => prepare (x1,y1) = (x2,y2)                      
308        else:
309            # Convert to float
310            if type(self.x1) != float:
311                self.x1, self.y1 = \
312                    [float(value) for value in (self.x1,self.y1)]
313            # Define x2,y2 = x1,y1
314            self.x2 = self.x1
315            self.y2 = self.y1
316            
317        # (3) Return (rounded) values of center coordinates
318        return (np.round(self.x1,1), np.round(self.y1,1), 
319                np.round(self.x2,1), np.round(self.y2,1))

Return the final results of center determination and refinement.

Returns
  • x1 (float): x-coordinate of the center from determination method
  • y1 (float): y-coordinate of the center from determination method
  • x2 (float): x-coordinate of the center from refinement method
  • y2 (float): y-coordinate of the center from refinement method
Technical note
  • The function always returns four parameters.
  • In most cases, the output are four coordinates (x1,y1,x2,y2).
  • If the refinement method was None, the output is (x1,y1,x1,y1); i.e. the determined and refined center coordinates are the same.

339        None

341        Returns

def load_results(self): 
366    def load_results(self):
367        '''
368        Load results from a specified text file.
369    
370        This method reads the coordinates from a text file defined by the 
371        `out_file` attribute. It extracts pairs of coordinates (x1, y1) and 
372        (x2, y2) from each line in the file. The extracted values are stored in 
373        lists, allowing for the retrieval of multiple results.The most recent 
374        values of x1, y1, x2, and y2 can be stored as instance variables
375        for easy access.
376    
377        Parameters
378        ----------
379        None
380    
381        Returns
382        -------
383        None
384    
385        Notes
386        -----
387        - The results are expected to be in the format:
388            x1: <value>, y1: <value>
389            x2: <value>, y2: <value>
390        - If multiple sets of coordinates are found, they are stored in lists,
391        and only the last set can be accessed as instance variables.
392        '''        
393        
394        if self.in_file is not None and os.path.isfile(self.in_file):
395            with open(self.in_file, 'r') as f:
396                lines = f.readlines()
397                
398                # Initialize lists to hold multiple values
399                x1_values = []
400                y1_values = []
401                x2_values = []
402                y2_values = []
403    
404                for line in lines:
405                    # Strip and split each line to get the coordinates
406                    parts = line.strip().split(',')
407                    if len(parts) == 2:
408                        # Extract x1 and y1 or x2 and y2 based on line content
409                        if 'x1' in parts[0]:
410                            x1 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
411                            y1 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
412                            x1_values.append(x1)
413                            y1_values.append(y1)
414                        elif 'x2' in parts[0]:
415                            x2 = float(parts[0].split(':')[1].strip())
416                            y2 = float(parts[1].split(':')[1].strip())
417                            x2_values.append(x2)
418                            y2_values.append(y2)
419    
420                # Store the last set of values as instance variables 
421                self.x1 = x1_values
422                self.y1 = y1_values
423                self.x2 = x2_values
424                self.y2 = y2_values
425    
426                # Store the last loaded values:
427                if x1_values and y1_values and x2_values and y2_values:
428                    self.x1 = x1_values[-1]
429                    self.y1 = y1_values[-1]
430                    self.x2 = x2_values[-1]
431                    self.y2 = y2_values[-1]
432    
433        else:
434            print("Error reading text file with center coordinates!")

Load results from a specified text file.

This method reads the coordinates from a text file defined by the out_file attribute. It extracts pairs of coordinates (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) from each line in the file. The extracted values are stored in lists, allowing for the retrieval of multiple results.The most recent values of x1, y1, x2, and y2 can be stored as instance variables for easy access.

Parameters
  • None
Returns
  • None
Notes
  • The results are expected to be in the format: x1: , y1: x2: , y2:
  • If multiple sets of coordinates are found, they are stored in lists, and only the last set can be accessed as instance variables.
def get_circle_pixels(self, xc, yc, radius, num_points=360): 
437    def get_circle_pixels(self, xc, yc, radius, num_points=360):
438        '''         
439        Get coordinates of pixels defining circle border
440    
441        Parameters
442        ----------
443        self.image_path : str
444            direct path to a image with diffraction patterns
445        xc : float64
446            x-coordinate of the detected center
447        yc : float64
448            y-coordinate of the detected center
449        radius : float64
450            radius of the detected center
451        num_points : float64 
452            number of border points. The default is 360
453        
454        Returns
455        -------
456        x : array of float64
457            x-coordinates of pixels from circle border
458        y : array of float64
459            y-coordinates of pixels from circle border
460            
461        '''
462        
463        # Generate angles from 0 to 2*pi
464        theta = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, num=num_points)  
465                
466        # Calculate x,y-coordinates of points on the actual circle border
467        x_actual = xc + radius * np.cos(theta)
468        y_actual = yc + radius * np.sin(theta)
469        
470        return x_actual, y_actual

  • yc (float64): y-coordinate of the detected center
  • radius (float64): radius of the detected center
  • num_points (float64): number of border points. The default is 360
Returns
  • x (array of float64): x-coordinates of pixels from circle border
  • y (array of float64): y-coordinates of pixels from circle border
def intensity_sum(self, image, px, py, pr): 
473    def intensity_sum(self, image, px, py, pr):
474        ''' 
475        Summation of intensity values of pixels of a diffraction pattern.
476
477        Parameters
478        ----------
479        image : array of uint8
480            image from which the diffraction pattern has been detected.
481        px : float64
482            x-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
483        py : float64
484            y-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.
485        pr : float64
486            radius of the diffraction pattern.
487
488        Returns
489        -------
490        s : float64
491            intensity sum
492
493        '''
494        # Extract pixels on the circle border
495        pxc, pyc = self.get_circle_pixels(px, py, pr)
496        pxc = np.array(pxc, dtype=int)
497        pyc = np.array(pyc, dtype=int)
498        
499        # Calculate sum using the filtered values
500        s = np.sum(image[pyc, pxc])/len(pxc)
501
502        return s

  • py (float64): y-coordinate of the center of the diffraction pattern.

def visualize_results(self, csquare=None): 
557    def visualize_results(self, csquare=None):
558        '''
559        Visualize diffractogram and its center after
560        center determination + refinement.
561    
562        Parameters
563        ----------
564        csquare : int, optional, default is None
565            If csquare argument is given,
566            only the central square of the diffractogram will be plotted;
567            the size of the central square will be equal to csquare argument.
568    
569        Returns
570        -------
571        None
572            The output is the image of the diffractogram
573            showing also the central coordinates and refinement ring.
574        '''
575        
576        # (0) Collect center coordinates and radii
577        # x1,y1,r1 = coordinates and radius of the determined circle/ring
578        # x2,y2,r2 = coordinates and radius of the refined circle/ring
579        x1, y1 = (self.x1, self.y1)
580        r1 = self.center1.r
581        x2, y2 = (self.x2, self.y2)
582        r2  = self.center2.rr
583        
584        # (1) Prepare the image of the diffractogram
585        # ...copy diffractogram image
586        image = np.copy(self.to_refine)
587        # ...cut image intensity if required
588        if self.icut is not None:
589            im = np.where(image > self.icut, self.icut, image)
590        else:
591            im = np.copy(image)
592            
593        # (2) Calculate intensity sum or intensity variance
594        if self.refinement == "var":
595            # Refinement was based on minimizing the intensity variance
596            dvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x1, y1, r1)
597            rvar = self.intensity_variance(image, x2, x2, r2)
598            labeld = (
599                f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]'
600                + '\n' + f'int-var: {dvar:.1f}')
601            labelr = (
602                f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]'
603                + '\n' + f'int-var: {rvar:.1f}')
604        else:
605            # All other cases: manual refinement or maximixing intensity sum
606            dsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x1, y1, r1)
607            rsum = self.intensity_sum(image, x2, x2, r2)
608            labeld = (
609                f'd-center: [{x1:.1f}, {y1:.1f}]'
610                + '\n' + f'int-sum: {dsum:.1f}')
611            labelr = (
612                f'r-center: [{x2:.1f}, {y2:.1f}]'
613                + '\n' + f'int-sum: {rsum:.1f}')
614            
615        # (3) Calculate xy-limits if we want to see only the central square
616        # (if csquare argument was given, we will plot only the central square
617        # (to achieve this, we pre-calculate params for ax.set_xlim/set_ylim
618        # (the precalculated parameters will be used below during plotting
619        if csquare is not None:
620            xmin,xmax = (0, image.shape[0])
621            ymin,ymax = (0, image.shape[1])
622            edge = (xmax-csquare) // 2
623            xmin = xmin + edge
624            xmax = xmax - edge
625            ymin = ymin + edge
626            ymax = ymax - edge
627    
628        # (4) Final plot: show the diffractogram + refinement results
629        # ...prepare figure
630        fig, ax = plt.subplots()
631        # ...show diffraction pattern
632        ax.imshow(im, cmap=self.cmap, origin="upper")
633        # ...set the title of the whole figure
634        ax.set_title(
635            f'Center Location ({self.determination}/{self.refinement})')
636        # ...add initial center (after CenterDetermination)
637        ax.scatter(x1, y1,
638                   label=labeld, color='red', marker='x', s=60, lw=1)
639        # ...add initial circle (after CenterDetermination)
640        c0 = plt.Circle((x1, y1), r1,
641                        color='red', fill=False, label='detected', lw=1)
642        ax.add_patch(c0)    
643        # ...add final center coordinates (after CenterRefinement)
644        ax.scatter(x2, y2,
645                   label=labelr, color='springgreen', marker='x', lw=1, s=60)
646        # ...add final cirlce (after CenterRefinement)
647        c1 = plt.Circle((x2,y2), r2,
648                        color='springgreen', fill=False, label='refined', lw=1)
649        ax.add_patch(c1)
650        # ...move legend to the top right next to the image
651        ax.legend(loc='upper left', frameon=False, #fontsize=10,
652                  handler_map={Circle: HandlerCircle()}, ncol=1,
653                  bbox_to_anchor=(.98, 1.01), 
654                  bbox_transform=ax.transAxes)
655        # ...set xlim/ylim if we want to see only the central square
656        if csquare is not None:
657            ax.set_xlim(xmin,xmax)  # the xmin/xmax were pre-calculated above
658            ax.set_ylim(ymin,ymax)  # the ymin/ymax were pre-calculated above
659        # ...do not hide axis decorations = labels, spines, ticks...
660        ax.axis('on')
661        # ...show the plot
662        plt.show(block=False)
