class CenterDetermination: 
 666class CenterDetermination:
 667    '''
 668    CenterDetermination object - initial detection of a diffractogram center.
 669
 670    This class is responsible for identifying the center coordinates of 
 671    a 2D diffraction pattern image using various detection methods specified 
 672    by the user. It initializes with the input image and other parameters
 673    that influence the center detection process.
 674
 675    Parameters
 676    ----------
 677    parent : CenterLocator
 678        Reference to the parent CenterLocator object, allowing access 
 679        to shared attributes and methods.
 680    input_image : str, path, or numpy.array
 681        The input image representing a 2D diffraction pattern, provided as 
 682        a file path or a NumPy array.
 683    determination : str or None, optional, default is None
 684        The method used for the initial center determination.
 685        Options include:
 686        - 'manual': Manual detection - user defines 3 points
 687          on selected diffraction ring.
 688        - 'hough': Auto-detection - Hough transform for circle detection.
 689        - 'intensity': Auto-detection - intensity center in central region.
 690    in_file : str, optional
 691        Filename of the text file from which to load previously saved 
 692        center coordinates.
 693    out_file : str, optional
 694        Filename of the text file to which the detected center coordinates 
 695        will be saved.
 696    heq : bool, optional
 697        Flag to indicate whether to perform histogram equalization on the 
 698        input image. Default is False.
 699    icut : float, optional
 700        Cut-off intensity level for processing the image. Default is None.
 701    cmap : str, optional
 702        Colormap to be used for displaying the image. Default is 'gray'.
 703    csquare : int, optional
 704        Size of the square for processing. Default is 50.
 705    cintensity : float, optional
 706        Threshold intensity for detecting features in the image. Default is
 707        0.8.
 708    messages : bool, optional
 709        Flag to enable or disable informational messages during processing. 
 710        Default is False.
 711    print_sums : bool, optional
 712        If True, prints the sum of intensity values for the detected circle
 713        after each adjustment, relevant only for manual detection methods.
 714
 715
 716    Returns
 717    -------
 718    None
 719
 720    Notes
 721    -----
 722    - The class preprocesses the input image and then applies the specified 
 723      center detection method.
 724    - The detected center coordinates are stored in instance variables
 725      `x`, `y`, and `r`, representing the center's x-coordinate, 
 726      y-coordinate, and radius, respectively.
 727    '''
 728    
 729    def __init__(self, parent,
 730                 input_image,
 731                 determination = None, 
 732                 in_file = None,
 733                 out_file = None,
 734                 heq = False, 
 735                 icut = None,
 736                 cmap = 'gray',
 737                 csquare=50,
 738                 cintensity=0.8,
 739                 messages = False,
 740                 print_sums = False):
 741        
 742        ######################################################################
 743        # PRIVATE FUNCTION: Initialize CenterLocator object.
 744        # The parameters are described above in class definition.
 745        ######################################################################
 746        
 747        ## (0) Initialize input attributes
 748        self.parent = parent
 749        
 750        ## (1) Initialize new attributes
 751        self.step=0.5
 752        
 753        ## (2) Run functions
 754        # (2a) Preprocess data
 755        self.preprocess(preInit=1)
 756        
 757        # (2b) Center detection methods
 758        if determination.lower() == "manual":
 759            self.x, self.y, self.r = self.detection_3points()
 760        elif determination.lower() == "hough":
 761            self.x, self.y, self.r = self.detection_Hough()
 762        elif determination.lower() == "intensity":
 763            self.x, self.y, self.r = self.detection_intensity(
 764                self.parent.csquare, 
 765                self.parent.cintensity
 766                )
 767                
 768        else: 
 769            print("Selected determination method does not exist.")
 770            sys.exit()
 771
 772
 773    ## Functions::
 774    def preprocess(self,preInit=0,preHough=0,preManual=0,
 775                   preVar=0,preSum=0,preInt=0):  
 776        """ FOR AUTOMATIC METHODS OPTIMIZATION AND MORE UNIVERSAL SOLUTIONS
 777        Function for input image preprocessing based on the methods 
 778        defined in the class initialization - self.detection_method, 
 779        self.correction_method.
 780
 781        Parameters
 782        ----------
 783        preInit : bool, optional
 784            Perform preprocessing of the input image (when using icut or heq). 
 785            This is called automatically every time, if no preprocessing
 786            specified, the detection and refinement will be performed on 
 787            original image. The default is 0.
 788        preHough : bool, optional
 789            Perform preprocessing for automatic detection via Hough transform. 
 790            
 791
 792        Returns
 793        -------
 794        manu : NumPy array
 795            Pre-processed image for the manual detection method
 796        edges : array of bool
 797            Detected edges via Canny detector for automatic Hough transform
 798        """
 799        
 800        # Flags
 801        control_print = 1
 802        
 803        # Load original image
 804        if len(self.parent.image.shape)!=2:
 805            self.parent.image = np.mean(self.parent.image,axis=2)
 806            
 807        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
 808        
 809        ### After initialization: perform an image enhancement if specified
 810        if preInit == 1:
 811            # Enhance diffraction pattern to make it more visible
 812            if self.parent.heq == 1:
 813                if self.parent.messages:
 814                    print("Histogram equalized.")
 815                image = sk.exposure.equalize_adapthist(image)
 816
 817                
 818            # # Edit contrast with a user-predefined parameter
 819            # if self.parent.icut is not None:
 820            #     if self.parent.messages:
 821            #         print("Contrast enhanced.")
 822            #     image = np.where(image > self.parent.icut, 
 823            #                      self.parent.icut, 
 824            #                      image)
 825                
 826
 827            self.parent.to_refine = image
 828            return
 829        
 830        ### Hough transform: perform pre-processing necessary for the detection
 831        if preHough == 1:           
 832            if self.parent.heq == 0:
 833                csq = self.central_square(self.parent.to_refine, csquare=80)   
 834                
 835                # Beam stopper present in image
 836                if np.median(csq)<100 and np.median(csq) > 0:
 837                    if self.parent.messages:
 838                        print('Beamstopper removed.')
 839                    max_indices=np.where(self.parent.to_refine>np.median(csq))
 840        
 841                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
 842                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
 843        
 844                    self.parent.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0    
 845                    
 846                    max_indices = \
 847                        np.where(self.parent.to_refine < 0.8*np.median(csq))
 848                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
 849                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
 850        
 851                    self.parent.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0   
 852                    
 853                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
 854                    edges = sk.feature.canny(self.parent.to_refine, 
 855                            sigma=0.2, 
 856                            low_threshold=2.5*np.median(self.parent.to_refine), 
 857                            high_threshold=3*np.median(self.parent.to_refine))
 858                    
 859                    # Dilate the edges to connect them
 860                    selem = sk.morphology.disk(5)
 861                    dilated_edges = sk.morphology.dilation(edges, selem)
 862                    
 863                    # Erode the dilated edges to reduce thickness and smooth the contour
 864                    connected_edges=sk.morphology.erosion(dilated_edges,selem)
 865
 866                    if control_print == 1:
 867                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
 868                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.parent.image, origin="upper")
 869                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
 870                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.parent.to_refine, origin="upper")
 871                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
 872                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
 873                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
 874                        ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges, origin="upper")
 875                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
 876                        plt.tight_layout()
 877                        plt.show(block=False)
 878                        
 879                # No beam stopper in image
 880                else:
 881                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
 882                    print('No beamstopper.')
 883                    edges = sk.feature.canny(self.to_refine, 
 884                                             sigma=0.2, 
 885                                             low_threshold=80, 
 886                                             high_threshold=100)
 887                    
 888                    # Dilate the edges to connect them
 889                    selem = sk.morphology.disk(10)
 890                    dilated_edges = sk.morphology.dilation(edges, selem)
 891                    
 892                    # Erode the dilated edges to reduce thickness and smooth the contour
 893                    connected_edges=sk.morphology.erosion(dilated_edges,selem)
 894                    connected_edges = sk.morphology.remove_small_objects(
 895                        connected_edges, 
 896                        min_size=100)
 897                    
 898                    if control_print == 1:
 899                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
 900                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
 901                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
 902                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
 903                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
 904                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper",)
 905                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
 906                        ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges,origin="upper")
 907                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
 908                        plt.tight_layout()
 909                        plt.show(block=False)
 910                
 911            elif self.heq == 1: 
 912                # Central square extraction
 913                csq = self.central_square(self.to_refine, csquare=80)   
 914
 915                # Beam stopper present in image
 916                if 0.4 <= np.median(csq) <= 0.6:
 917                    
 918                    max_indices = \
 919                        np.where(self.to_refine > 2*np.median(self.to_refine))
 920    
 921                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
 922                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
 923    
 924                    self.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0 
 925                                                     
 926                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
 927                    edges = sk.feature.canny(
 928                        self.to_refine, 
 929                        sigma=0.2, 
 930                        low_threshold=1.5*np.median(self.to_refine), 
 931                        high_threshold=3*np.median(self.to_refine))
 932
 933                    
 934                    if control_print == 1:
 935                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
 936                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
 937                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
 938                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
 939                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
 940                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
 941                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
 942                      #  ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges)
 943                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
 944                        plt.tight_layout()
 945                        plt.show(block=False)
 946                    
 947                # No beam stopper in image
 948                else:
 949                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
 950                    edges = sk.feature.canny(
 951                        self.to_refine, 
 952                        sigma=0.2, 
 953                        low_threshold=2.5*np.median(self.to_refine), 
 954                        high_threshold=3*np.median(self.to_refine))
 955
 956                    
 957                    if control_print == 1:
 958                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
 959                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
 960                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
 961                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
 962                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
 963                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
 964                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
 965                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
 966                        plt.tight_layout()
 967                        plt.show(block=False)
 968            
 969            return edges
 970        
 971    
 972    def detection_intensity(self, csquare, cintensity, plot_results=0):
 973        '''
 974        Find center of intensity/mass of an array.
 975        
 976        Parameters
 977        ----------
 978        arr : 2D-numpy array
 979            The array, whose intensity center will be determined.
 980        csquare : int, optional, default is 20
 981            The size/edge of the square in the (geometrical) center.
 982            The intensity center will be searched only within the central square.
 983            Reasons: To avoid other spots/diffractions and
 984            to minimize the effect of possible intensity assymetry around center. 
 985        cintensity : float, optional, default is 0.8
 986            The intensity fraction.
 987            When searching the intensity center, we will consider only
 988            pixels with intensity > max.intensity.
 989            
 990        Returns
 991        -------
 992        xc,yc : float,float
 993            XY-coordinates of the intensity/mass center of the array.
 994            Round XY-coordinates if you use them for image/array calculations.
 995        '''  
 996        
 997        # (1) Get image/array size
 998        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
 999        
1000                
1001        arr = np.copy(image)
1002        xsize,ysize = arr.shape
1003        
1004        # (2) Calculate borders around the central square
1005        xborder = (xsize - csquare) // 2
1006        yborder = (ysize - csquare) // 2
1007        
1008        # (3) Create the central square,
1009        # from which the intensity center will be detected
1010        arr2 = arr[xborder:-xborder,yborder:-yborder].copy()
1011        
1012        # (4) In the central square,
1013        # set all values below cintenstity to zero
1014        arr2 = np.where(arr2>np.max(arr2)*cintensity, arr2, 0)
1015        
1016        # (5) Determine the intensity center from image moments
1017        # see image moments in...
1018        # skimage: https://scikit-image.org/docs/dev/api/skimage.measure.html
1019        # wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_moment -> Centroid
1020        # ---
1021        # (a) Calculate 1st central moments of the image
1022        M = moments(arr2,1)
1023        # (b) Calculate the intensity center = centroid according to www-help
1024        (self.x, self.y) = (M[1,0]/M[0,0], M[0,1]/M[0,0])
1025        # (c) We have centroid of the central square
1026        # but we have to recalculate it to the whole image
1027        (self.x, self.y) = (self.x + xborder, self.y + yborder)
1028        # (d) Radius of a diffraction ring is hardcoded to 100 here
1029        self.r = 100
1030        
1031        # (6) User information (if required)
1032        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
1033            self.parent.dText = "Center Determination (IntensityCenter): ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1034
1035
1036        # (7) Plot results (if required)
1037        if plot_results == 1:
1038           self.visualize_center(self.x, self.y, self.r) 
1039                
1040        # (8) Return the results:
1041        # a) XY-coordinates of the center
1042        # b) radius of the circle/diff.ring,
1043        #    from which the center was determined
1044        # ! radius of the circle is just hardcoded here - see TODO note above
1045        return(self.x, self.y, self.r)
1046    
1047
1048    def detection_Hough(self, plot_results=0):
1049        '''        
1050        Perform Hough transform to detect center of diffraction patterns.
1051        This is a method to automatically detect circular diffraction patterns
1052        
1053        Parameters
1054        ----------
1055        plot_results : int, binary
1056            Plot the pattern determined by pixels selected by the user.
1057            Default is 1. To cancel visualization, set plot_results = 0.
1058
1059        Returns
1060        -------
1061        self.x : float64
1062            x-coordinate of the detected center
1063        self.y : float64
1064            y-coordinate of the detected center
1065        self.r : float64
1066            radius of the detected center
1067                                    
1068        '''
1069        ## Image preprocessing
1070        im = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1071        
1072        # if the brightness of the image is small enough, pixel values greater
1073        # than 50 will be set to 0 -- removal of the beam stopper influence
1074        
1075        if self.parent.heq == 0:
1076            if sum(sum(im)) < 150000:
1077                    max_indices = np.where(im > 50)
1078        
1079                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
1080                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
1081        
1082                    im[row_idx, col_idx] = 0    
1083                
1084            # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1085            edges = sk.feature.canny(im, 
1086                                     sigma=0.2, 
1087                                     low_threshold=80, 
1088                                     high_threshold=100)
1089        elif self.heq == 1:
1090            if sum(sum(im)) > 40000:
1091                max_indices = np.where(im > 50)
1092
1093                row_idx = max_indices[0]
1094                col_idx = max_indices[1]
1095
1096                im[row_idx, col_idx] = 0    
1097            
1098            # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1099            edges = sk.feature.canny(im, 
1100                                     sigma=0.2, 
1101                                     low_threshold=0.80, 
1102                                     high_threshold=1)
1103        
1104        
1105        # Define the radii range for the concentric circles
1106        # (set empirically based on the available pictures)
1107        min_radius = 40
1108        max_radius = 200
1109        radius_step = 10
1110        radii = np.arange(min_radius, max_radius + radius_step, radius_step)
1111
1112        ### Perform the Hough transform to detect circles
1113        # Circle detection involves converting edge pixels into parameter space, 
1114        # where each point represents a possible circle center and radius. 
1115        # The circles are then identified as peaks in the parameter space, 
1116        # enabling accurate detection of circular shapes in the image.
1117        hough_res = hough_circle(edges, radii)
1118
1119        # Extract the circle peaks
1120        _, self.x, self.y, self.r = hough_circle_peaks(hough_res, 
1121                                                            radii, 
1122                                                            total_num_peaks=1)
1123        
1124        
1125        # User information:
1126        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
1127            self.parent.dText = "Center Determination (HoughTransform) : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1128        
1129        self.x, self.y, self.r = \
1130            float(self.x[0]), float(self.y[0]), float(self.r[0])
1131
1132        # (7) Plot results (if required)
1133        if plot_results == 1:
1134           self.visualize_center(self.x, self.y, self.r) 
1135           
1136        # Return results, convert coordinates to float
1137        return self.x, self.y, self.r
1138
1139   
1140    def detection_3points(self, plot_results=0):
1141        '''         
1142        In the input image, select manually 3 points defining a circle using
1143        a key press event 
1144            - press '1' to select a point
1145                
1146        If the user is not satisfied with the point selection, it can be
1147        deleted using a key press event:
1148            - press '2' to delete the most recent
1149            - press '3' to delete the point closest to the cursor
1150        
1151        If the user is satisified with the points selected, the rest 
1152        of the program will be executed 
1153            - press 'd' to proceed >DONE<
1154        
1155        Coordinates of the center and radius will be calculated automatically
1156        using method self.calculate_circle()
1157        
1158        In addition, the user will be able to manually adjust the original
1159        center position by using pre-defined keys.
1160        
1161        Parameters
1162        ----------
1163        plot_results : int, binary
1164            Plot the pattern determined by pixels selected by the user.
1165            Default is 1. To cancel visualization, set plot_results = 0.
1166        
1167        Returns
1168        -------
1169        self.x : float64
1170            x-coordinate of the detected center
1171        self.y : float64
1172            y-coordinate of the detected center
1173        self.r : float64
1174            radius of the detected center
1175            (if available, othervise returns None)
1176                                    
1177        '''
1178        
1179        # Load image
1180        im = self.parent.to_refine
1181        
1182        # Edit contrast with a user-predefined parameter
1183        if self.parent.icut is not None:
1184            if self.parent.messages:
1185                print("Contrast enhanced.")
1186            im = np.where(im > self.parent.icut, 
1187                              self.parent.icut, 
1188                              im)
1189            
1190        # Create a figure and display the image
1191        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 12))
1192        
1193        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
1194        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
1195        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
1196 
1197        plt.title("Select 3 points defining one of diffraction circles", 
1198                  fontsize = 20)
1199        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
1200        ax.axis('off')
1201
1202        # User information:
1203        instructions = dedent(
1204            """
1205            CenterDetermination :: ThreePoints (semi-automated method)
1206            Select 3 points to define a diffraction circle using keys:
1207              - '1' : define a point at current cursor position
1208              - '2' : delete the last point
1209              - '3' : delete the point closest to the cursor
1210              - 'd' : done = finished = go to the next step
1211            Close the figure to terminate. No center will be detected.
1212            """)
1213
1214        if self.parent.messages:
1215            print(instructions)
1216       
1217        # Enable interactive mode
1218        # (figure is updated after every plotting command
1219        # (so that calling figure.show() is not necessary
1220        plt.ion()
1221 
1222        # Initialize the list of coordinates
1223        self.coords = [] 
1224        
1225        # Initialize all flags and counters
1226        calculate_circle_flag = False          # press 'd' event
1227        termination_flag = False               # close window event
1228        point_counter = 0                      # number of selected points
1229        
1230        ### Define the event handler for figure close event
1231        def onclose(event):
1232            nonlocal termination_flag
1233            termination_flag = True
1234            if self.parent.messages:
1235                print('Execution terminated.')
1236                print("------------------------------------------------------------")
1237
1238 
1239        # Connect the event handler to the figure close event
1240        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('close_event', onclose)
1241        
1242        
1243        ### Define the callback function for key press events
1244        def onkeypress(event):
1245            # nonlocal to modify the flag variable in the outer scope
1246            nonlocal calculate_circle_flag, point_counter, termination_flag
1247            
1248            # Store the zoom level
1249            current_xlim = ax.get_xlim()
1250            current_ylim = ax.get_ylim()
1251 
1252            ## Delete points -- the closest to the cursor
1253            if event.key == '3':
1254                point_counter -= 1
1255                if len(self.coords) > 0:
1256                    pointer_x, pointer_y = event.xdata, event.ydata
1257                    distances = [
1258                        np.sqrt((x - pointer_x)**2 + (y - pointer_y)**2)
1259                        for x, y in self.coords]
1260                    closest_index = np.argmin(distances)
1261                    del self.coords[closest_index]
1262    
1263                    ## Redraw the image without the deleted point
1264                    ax.clear()
1265                    ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
1266                              origin="upper")
1267                    for x, y in self.coords:
1268                        ax.scatter(x, y, 
1269                                   c='r', marker='x', 
1270                                   s=self.parent.marker_size)
1271
1272                    my_plot_title = (
1273                        "Select 3 points to define "
1274                        "one of diffraction circles.")
1275                    plt.title(my_plot_title, fontsize=20)
1276                    
1277                    # Retore the previous zoom level
1278                    ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
1279                    ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
1280                    ax.axis('off')
1281                    
1282                    fig.canvas.draw()
1283                else:
1284                    print("No points to delete.")
1285    
1286            # Delete recent point (last added) -- independent on the cursor
1287            if event.key == '2':
1288                # Check if there are points to delete
1289                if point_counter > 0:  
1290                    point_counter -= 1
1291                    if len(self.coords) > 0:
1292                        # Delete the last point in the list
1293                        del self.coords[-1]
1294    
1295                        # Redraw the image without the deleted point
1296                        ax.clear()
1297                        ax.imshow(im, cmap=self.parent.cmap,
1298                                  origin="upper")
1299                        for x, y in self.coords:
1300                            ax.scatter(x, y,
1301                                       c='r', marker='x', 
1302                                       s=self.parent.marker_size)
1303
1304                        my_plot_title = (
1305                            "Select 3 points to define "
1306                            "one of diffraction circles.")
1307                        plt.title(my_plot_title)
1308                        
1309                        # Retore the previous zoom level
1310                        ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
1311                        ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
1312                        ax.axis('off')
1313
1314                        fig.canvas.draw()
1315                else:
1316                    print("No points to delete.")
1317                    
1318            ## Select points 
1319            elif event.key == '1':
1320                # Only allow selecting up to three points
1321                if point_counter < 3:  
1322                    # Save the coordinates of the clicked point
1323                    new_point = (event.xdata, event.ydata)
1324                    
1325                    if new_point in self.coords:
1326                        # Do not allow multiple selection of one point
1327                        print("The selected point already exists.")
1328                    else:
1329                        # Add selected point
1330                        self.coords.append(new_point)
1331    
1332                        # Visualize the selected point on the image
1333                        ax.scatter(event.xdata, event.ydata, 
1334                                   c='r', marker='x', 
1335                                   s=self.parent.marker_size)
1336
1337                        # Restore the previous zoom level
1338                        ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
1339                        ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
1340                        ax.axis('off')
1341
1342                        fig.canvas.draw()
1343    
1344                        point_counter += 1
1345
1346    
1347                if len(self.coords) == 3:
1348                    # Turn off interactive mode
1349                    plt.ioff()
1350    
1351
1352    
1353            # Calculate circle or terminate
1354            elif event.key == 'd':
1355                if len(self.coords) == 3:
1356                    calculate_circle_flag = True
1357 
1358                else:
1359                    print("Select exactly 3 points to calculate the circle.")
1360                    fig.canvas.draw()
1361    
1362        # Connect the callback function to the key press event
1363        cid0 = fig.canvas.mpl_connect('key_press_event', onkeypress)
1364
1365        # Show the plot
1366        plt.tight_layout()
1367        ax.axis('off')
1368
1369        plt.show(block=False)
1370      
1371        # Wait for 'd' key event or close the figure if no points are selected
1372        while not calculate_circle_flag and not termination_flag:
1373 
1374            try:
1375                plt.waitforbuttonpress(timeout=0.1)
1376                # Store the zoom level
1377                current_xlim = ax.get_xlim()
1378                current_ylim = ax.get_ylim()
1379 
1380                # Plot detected diffraction pattern
1381                if calculate_circle_flag:
1382 
1383                    self.calculate_circle(plot_results=0)
1384                    
1385                    ax.clear()
1386                    ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
1387                              origin="upper")
1388                    # Retore the previous zoom level
1389                    ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
1390                    ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
1391                 
1392                    circle = plt.Circle(
1393                        (self.x, self.y), self.r, color='r', fill=False)
1394                    ax.add_artist(circle)
1395        
1396                    # Plot center point
1397                    center, = ax.plot(self.x, self.y, 'rx', markersize=12)
1398                    plt.title('Manually adjust the position of the center using keys.')
1399        
1400                    # Display the image
1401                    plt.draw()
1402                    ax.axis('off')
1403
1404                    plt.show(block = False)
1405
1406            except KeyboardInterrupt:
1407                print("Execution manually interrupted by user.")
1408                break
1409            except ValueError as e:
1410                print("ValueError:", e)
1411                break
1412           
1413        # If the termination_flag is True, stop the code
1414        if termination_flag: 
1415             print("No points selected. Returned None values.")
1416             sys.exit()
1417             return None, None, None
1418        
1419        # Disconnect key press events
1420        fig.canvas.mpl_disconnect(cid0) 
1421        
1422        # local variables save
1423        self.center = center
1424        
1425        self.backip = [self.x, self.y, self.r]
1426        # Manually adjust the calculated center coordinates
1427        self.x, self.y, self.r = self.adjustment_3points(fig, circle, center)
1428
1429        # Return the results:
1430        # a) XY-coordinates of the center
1431        # b) radius of the circle/diff.ring,
1432        #    from which the center was determined
1433        return(self.x, self.y, self.r)

1436    def adjustment_3points(self, fig, circle, center, plot_results=0) -> tuple:
1437        '''
1438        Adjustment of the center position calculated from 3 points.
1439        Interactive refinement using keys:
1440
1441        The user can change the position of the center of the diffraction
1442        pattern and also the radius of the detected pattern using keys:
1443            - left / right / top / down arrows : move left / right / top / down
1444            - '+' : increase radius
1445            - '-' : decrease radius
1446            - 'd' : done, termination of the refinement
1447
1448        If the interactive figure is closed without any modifications,
1449        the function returns input variables and the proccess terminates.
1450        
1451        Parameters
1452        ----------
1453        fig : figure.Figure object
1454            interactive figure in which a diffraction pattern has been
1455            manually detected.
1456        circle : patches.Circle object
1457            circle defined via 3 points manually delected
1458        center : tuple
1459            calculated center of the input circle.
1460        plot_results : boolean
1461            visualize results. The default is 1 (plot detected center).
1462
1463        Returns
1464        -------
1465        xy : tuple
1466            x,y-coordinates of the center of the diffraction pattern.
1467        r : integer
1468            radius of the diffraction pattern.
1469
1470        '''            
1471        # Remove default left / right arrow key press events
1472        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].remove('left')
1473        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].remove('right')
1474        
1475        if self.parent.messages:
1476            instructions = dedent(
1477            """
1478            CenterDetermination :: ThreePoints (interactive adjustment)
1479            Use these keys:
1480              - '←' : move left
1481              - '→' : move right
1482              - '↑' : move up
1483              - '↓' : move down
1484              - '+' : increase circle radius
1485              - '-' : decrease circle radius
1486              - 'b' : increase step size
1487              - 'l' : decrease step size
1488              - 'd' : refinement done
1489                  
1490            DISCLAIMER: For the purpose of the center position adjustment, 
1491                        the default shortcuts for arrows were removed.
1492            """)
1493            print(instructions)
1494        
1495        if self.parent.print_sums:
1496            print("Intensity sums during refinement:")
1497            
1498        # Initialize variables and flags
1499        self.backip = np.array((self.x, self.y))
1500        xy = np.array((self.x, self.y))
1501        r = np.copy(self.r)
1502        termination_flag = False
1503        
1504        plt.title("Manually adjust the center position.", fontsize=20)
1505
1506        plt.ion()
1507          
1508        ### Define the event handler for figure close event
1509        def onclose(event):
1510            nonlocal termination_flag
1511            termination_flag = True
1512
1513        # Connect the event handler to the figure close event
1514        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('close_event', onclose)
1515        
1516        # Define the callback function for key press events
1517        def onkeypress2(event):
1518            # Use nonlocal to modify the center position in the outer scope
1519            nonlocal xy, r, termination_flag
1520        
1521            # OTHER KEYS USED IN INTERACTIVE FIGURES
1522            #   event.key == '1': select a point in self.detection_3points()
1523            #   event.key == '2': delete the last point in self.detection...
1524            #   event.key == '3': delete a point in self.detection...
1525            #   event.key == '+': increase circle radius
1526            #   event.key == '-': decrease circle radius           
1527            #   event.key == 'b': increase the step size (big step size)
1528            #   event.key == 'l': decrease the step size (little step size)
1529            #   event.key == 'd': proceed in self.detection_3points()
1530        
1531            if event.key in ['up', 'down', 'left', 'right', '+', '-']:                    
1532                if event.key in ['+', '-']:
1533                    r += 1 if event.key == '+' else -1
1534                else:
1535                    # Perform shifts normally
1536                    if event.key == 'up':
1537                        xy[1] -= self.step
1538                    elif event.key == 'down':
1539                        xy[1] += self.step
1540                    elif event.key == 'left':
1541                        xy[0] -= self.step
1542                    elif event.key == 'right':
1543                        xy[0] += self.step
1544                    
1545                    # Print sum only for arrow keys
1546                    if self.parent.print_sums:
1547                        s = self.parent.intensity_sum(self.parent.to_refine, 
1548                                                      xy[0], xy[1], r)
1549                        print(f'{s:.2f}')
1550            
1551            # Terminate the interactive refinement with 'd' key
1552            if event.key == 'd':
1553                termination_flag = True
1554        
1555            # Change step size 
1556            if event.key == 'b':
1557                self.step = self.step * 5
1558        
1559            if event.key == 'l':
1560                self.step = self.step / 5
1561                if self.step < 0.5:
1562                    self.step = 0.5
1563        
1564            # Update the plot with the new center position
1565            circle.set_center((xy[0], xy[1]))  # circle
1566            circle.set_radius(r)               # radius
1567            center.set_data([xy[0]], [xy[1]])  # center
1568        
1569            plt.title("Manually adjust the center position.", fontsize=20)
1570        
1571            # Update the plot
1572            plt.draw()
1573
1574                
1575        # Disconnect the on_key_press1 event handler from the figure
1576        fig.canvas.mpl_disconnect(fig.canvas.manager.key_press_handler_id)
1577        
1578        # Connect the callback function to the key press event
1579        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('key_press_event', onkeypress2)
1580
1581        # Enable interaction mode
1582        plt.ion() 
1583               
1584        # Wait for 'd' key press or figure closure
1585        while not termination_flag:
1586            try:
1587                plt.waitforbuttonpress(timeout=0.1)
1588            except KeyboardInterrupt:
1589                # If the user manually closes the figure, terminate the loop
1590                termination_flag = True
1591                
1592        # Turn off interactive mode
1593        plt.ioff()
1594        
1595        # Display the final figure with the selected center position and radius
1596        plt.tight_layout()
1597
1598        plt.show(block=False)
1599        
1600        # If the termination_flag is True, stop the code
1601        if termination_flag: 
1602            plt.close()  # Close the figure
1603
1604        # User information:
1605        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
1606            self.parent.dText = "Center Determination (ThreePoints)    : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1607        
1608    
1609        return xy[0], xy[1], r
1610    
1611       
1612    def calculate_circle(self, plot_results:int)->tuple[
1613            float,float,float,tuple[float,float], plt.Circle]:
1614        ''' 
1615        Calculates coordinates of the center and radius of a circle defined via
1616        3 points determined by the user. Plots the calculated circle, detected 
1617        points and marks the center.
1618        
1619        Parameters
1620        ----------
1621        plot_results : int, binary
1622            Plot the calculated center and circle. To cancel visualization, 
1623            set plot_results = 0.
1624        self.coords : array of float64
1625            Coordinates of 3 manually selected points
1626        
1627        Returns
1628        -------
1629        self.x : float64
1630            x-coordinate of the detected center
1631        self.y : float64
1632            y-coordinate of the detected center
1633        self.r : float64
1634            radius of the detected center
1635                                    
1636        '''
1637        # Extract the coordinates of the points        
1638        x = [self.coords[0][0], self.coords[1][0], self.coords[2][0]]
1639        y = [self.coords[0][1], self.coords[1][1], self.coords[2][1]]
1640        
1641        # Compute the radius and center coordinates of the circle
1642            # a: the squared length of the side between the second 
1643            #    and third points (x[1], y[1]) and (x[2], y[2]).
1644            # b: the squared length of the side between the first 
1645            #    and third points (x[0], y[0]) and (x[2], y[2]).
1646            # c: the squared length of the side between the first 
1647            #    and second points (x[0], y[0]) and (x[1], y[1]).
1648            # s: the twice the signed area of the triangle formed by 3 points
1649            
1650        c = (x[0]-x[1])**2 + (y[0]-y[1])**2
1651        a = (x[1]-x[2])**2 + (y[1]-y[2])**2
1652        b = (x[2]-x[0])**2 + (y[2]-y[0])**2
1653        s = 2*(a*b + b*c + c*a) - (a*a + b*b + c*c) 
1654        
1655        # coordinates of the center
1656        self.x = (a*(b+c-a)*x[0] + b*(c+a-b)*x[1] + c*(a+b-c)*x[2]) / s
1657        self.y = (a*(b+c-a)*y[0] + b*(c+a-b)*y[1] + c*(a+b-c)*y[2]) / s 
1658        
1659        # radius
1660        ar = a**0.5
1661        br = b**0.5
1662        cr = c**0.5 
1663        self.r = ar*br*cr/((ar+br+cr)*(-ar+br+cr)*(ar-br+cr)*(ar+br-cr))**0.5
1664        
1665        # # Print results
1666        # if self.parent.messages:
1667        #     print("CenterEstimator :: manual center detection")
1668        #     print(f"Center coordinates: {self.x:.2f} {self.y:.2f}")
1669                    
1670        if plot_results==1:
1671            # Create and manage the figure
1672            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1673            manager = plt.get_current_fig_manager()
1674            manager.window.showMaximized()
1675            ax.imshow(self.parent.image, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
1676                      origin="upper")
1677            
1678            # Plot center and points
1679            center, = plt.plot(self.x, self.y, 
1680                     'rx', 
1681                     label='Center', 
1682                     markersize=12)
1683            plt.scatter(x,y, 
1684                        marker='x', 
1685                        color='palevioletred', 
1686                        label = 'Circle points')
1687            plt.title('Circle found using 3 manually detected points')
1688            
1689            # Circle visualization
1690            circle = plt.Circle((self.x,self.y), 
1691                                self.r, 
1692                                color='palevioletred', 
1693                                fill=False,
1694                                label = 'pattern')
1695            ax.add_artist(circle)
1696            
1697            # Set the aspect ratio to equal to have a circular shape
1698            plt.axis('equal')
1699            
1700            plt.legend(loc='lower center', 
1701                       ncol=2, 
1702                       bbox_to_anchor=(0.5,-0.1), 
1703                       mode='expand', 
1704                       frameon=False)
1705            plt.axis('off')
1706            plt.tight_layout()
1707            plt.show(block=False)
1708
1709        
1710        self.center = (self.x, self.y)
1711        self.circle = plt.Circle((self.x,self.y),self.r)
1712        
1713
1714        return self.x, self.y, self.r, self.center, self.circle
1715
1716
1717    def get_radius(
1718            self, im:np.ndarray, x:float, y:float, disp:bool=False) -> float:
1719        """
1720        Calculate the radius of a circle based on intensity profiles along 
1721        horizontal and vertical axes.
1722    
1723        Parameters
1724        ----------
1725        im : np.ndarray
1726            The 2D image array containing the circle.
1727        x : float
1728            The x-coordinate of the circle's center.
1729        y : float
1730            The y-coordinate of the circle's center.
1731        disp : bool, optional
1732            If True, visualizes the detected intensity profiles and peaks 
1733            (default is False).
1734    
1735        Returns
1736        -------
1737        float
1738            The estimated radius of the circle. Defaults to 100 if no valid 
1739            radius is detected.
1740        """
1741        
1742        def match_peaks(arr):
1743            """
1744            Finds the most similar values across the left and right halves of 
1745            an array, omitting the highest value. If exactly two peaks are 
1746            detected, they are returned as the best pair.
1747            """
1748            if len(arr) < 2:  # Not enough values to compare
1749                if self.parent.messages:
1750                    print("Not enough values to find similar pairs.")
1751                return None, None
1752    
1753            # Special case: if there are exactly 2 peaks, return them
1754            if len(arr) == 2:
1755                if self.parent.messages:
1756                    print("Exactly two peaks detected. Returning them as the best pair.")
1757                return 0, 1
1758    
1759            # Find the index of the highest value
1760            center_idx = np.argmax(arr)
1761    
1762            # Split into left and right halves, excluding the highest value
1763            left = arr[:center_idx]
1764            right = arr[center_idx + 1:]
1765            left_indices = np.arange(center_idx)
1766            right_indices = np.arange(center_idx + 1, len(arr))
1767    
1768            if len(left) == 0 or len(right) == 0:  # Check for empty halves
1769                if self.parent.messages:
1770                    print("One of the halves is empty.")
1771                return None, None
1772    
1773            # Initialize variables for tracking the smallest difference
1774            smallest_diff = np.inf
1775            best_pair = (None, None)
1776    
1777            # Compare each value in the left with every value in the right
1778            for i, l_val in enumerate(left):
1779                for j, r_val in enumerate(right):
1780                    diff = abs(l_val - r_val)
1781                    if diff < smallest_diff:
1782                        smallest_diff = diff
1783                        best_pair = (left_indices[i], right_indices[j])
1784    
1785            return best_pair
1786    
1787        self.xpeaks, self.ypeaks = None, None
1788        self.xyvals, self.yyvals = None, None
1789    
1790        x_line = im[int(x), :]
1791        y_line = im[:, int(y)]
1792    
1793        # Define threshold for peak detection
1794        x_thr = 0.5 * max(x_line)
1795        y_thr = 0.5 * max(y_line)
1796    
1797        # Find peaks with dynamic height thresholds
1798        self.xpeaks, _ = find_peaks(x_line, 
1799                                    height=x_thr, 
1800                                    prominence=1, 
1801                                    distance=30)
1802        self.xyvals = x_line[self.xpeaks]
1803        self.ypeaks, _ = find_peaks(y_line, 
1804                                    height=y_thr, 
1805                                    prominence=1, 
1806                                    distance=30)
1807        self.yyvals = y_line[self.ypeaks]
1808    
1809        # Define half the length of the image
1810        half_length_x = x_line.shape[0] / 2
1811        half_length_y = y_line.shape[0] / 2
1812    
1813        # Check the additional condition for xpeaks
1814        if len(self.xpeaks) == 2 and (
1815            (self.xpeaks[0]<half_length_x and self.xpeaks[1]<half_length_x) or
1816            (self.xpeaks[0]>half_length_x and self.xpeaks[1]>half_length_x)):
1817            if self.parent.messages:
1818                print("xpeaks condition met: Both peaks are on the same side of the center.")
1819            self.pairX = None
1820        else:
1821            self.pairX = match_peaks(self.xyvals)
1822    
1823        # Check the additional condition for ypeaks
1824        if len(self.ypeaks) == 2 and (
1825            (self.ypeaks[0]<half_length_y and self.ypeaks[1]<half_length_y) or
1826            (self.ypeaks[0]>half_length_y and self.ypeaks[1]>half_length_y)):
1827            if self.parent.messages:
1828                print("ypeaks condition met: Both peaks are on the same side of the center.")
1829            self.pairY = None
1830        else:
1831            self.pairY = match_peaks(self.yyvals)
1832    
1833        # Determine radius based on available pairs
1834        if self.pairX is None or None in self.pairX:
1835            rx_x = None
1836        else:
1837            x1 = self.xpeaks[self.pairX[0]]
1838            x2 = self.xpeaks[self.pairX[1]]
1839            rx_x = abs(x1 - x2) / 2
1840    
1841        if self.pairY is None or None in self.pairY:
1842            rx_y = None
1843        else:
1844            y1 = self.ypeaks[self.pairY[0]]
1845            y2 = self.ypeaks[self.pairY[1]]
1846            rx_y = abs(y1 - y2) / 2
1847    
1848        if rx_x is not None and rx_y is not None:
1849            rx = np.mean([rx_x, rx_y])
1850        elif rx_x is not None:
1851            rx = rx_x
1852        elif rx_y is not None:
1853            rx = rx_y
1854        else:
1855            if self.parent.messages:
1856                print("No valid pairs detected for radius calculation.")
1857            return 100  # Default radius or error handling
1858    
1859        if disp:
1860            # Plot xline with peaks
1861            plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
1862    
1863            # Plot for xline
1864            plt.subplot(2, 1, 1)
1865            plt.plot(x_line, label='xline')
1866            plt.plot(self.xpeaks, self.xyvals, "ro", label='Peaks')
1867            plt.title('Peaks in xline')
1868            plt.xlabel('Index')
1869            plt.ylabel('Value')
1870            plt.legend()
1871    
1872            # Plot for yline
1873            plt.subplot(2, 1, 2)
1874            plt.plot(y_line, label='yline')
1875            plt.plot(self.ypeaks, self.yyvals, "ro", label='Peaks')  
1876            plt.title('Peaks in yline')
1877            plt.xlabel('Index')
1878            plt.ylabel('Value')
1879            plt.legend()
1880    
1881            plt.tight_layout()
1882            plt.show()
1883    
1884        return rx
1885
1886        
1887    def visualize_center(self, x: float, y: float, r: float) -> None:
1888        '''         
1889        Visualize detected diffraction patterns and mark the center.
1890        
1891        Parameters
1892        ----------
1893        tit : string
1894            name of the method used for circle detection
1895        x : float64
1896            x-coordinate of the detected center
1897        y : float64
1898            y-coordinate of the detected center
1899        r : float64
1900            radius of the detected center
1901        
1902        Returns
1903        -------
1904        None.
1905                            
1906        '''
1907        # Load image
1908        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1909    
1910        if self.parent.icut is not None:
1911            im = np.where(image > self.parent.icut, self.parent.icut, image)
1912        else:
1913            im = np.copy(image)
1914            
1915        # Create a figure and display the image
1916        fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1917        
1918        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
1919        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
1920        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
1921 
1922        plt.title("Detected center")
1923        ax.axis('off')
1924
1925        # Plot center point
1926        ax.scatter(x,y,
1927                label= f'center:  [{x:.1f}, {y:.1f}]',
1928                marker='x', color="red", s=60)
1929
1930        plt.legend(loc='upper right')
1931        
1932        # Display the image
1933        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
1934        plt.axis('off')
1935        plt.tight_layout()
1936        plt.show(block=False)

CenterDetermination object - initial detection of a diffractogram center.

This class is responsible for identifying the center coordinates of a 2D diffraction pattern image using various detection methods specified by the user. It initializes with the input image and other parameters that influence the center detection process.

Parameters
  • parent (CenterLocator): Reference to the parent CenterLocator object, allowing access to shared attributes and methods.
  • input_image (str, path, or numpy.array): The input image representing a 2D diffraction pattern, provided as a file path or a NumPy array.
  • determination (str or None, optional, default is None): The method used for the initial center determination. Options include:
    • 'manual': Manual detection - user defines 3 points on selected diffraction ring.
    • 'hough': Auto-detection - Hough transform for circle detection.
    • 'intensity': Auto-detection - intensity center in central region.
  • in_file (str, optional): Filename of the text file from which to load previously saved center coordinates.
  • out_file (str, optional): Filename of the text file to which the detected center coordinates will be saved.
  • heq (bool, optional): Flag to indicate whether to perform histogram equalization on the input image. Default is False.
  • icut (float, optional): Cut-off intensity level for processing the image. Default is None.
  • cmap (str, optional): Colormap to be used for displaying the image. Default is 'gray'.
  • csquare (int, optional): Size of the square for processing. Default is 50.
  • cintensity (float, optional): Threshold intensity for detecting features in the image. Default is 0.8.
  • messages (bool, optional): Flag to enable or disable informational messages during processing. Default is False.
  • print_sums (bool, optional): If True, prints the sum of intensity values for the detected circle after each adjustment, relevant only for manual detection methods.
Returns
  • None
Notes
  • The class preprocesses the input image and then applies the specified center detection method.
  • The detected center coordinates are stored in instance variables x, y, and r, representing the center's x-coordinate, y-coordinate, and radius, respectively.
def preprocess( self, preInit=0, preHough=0, preManual=0, preVar=0, preSum=0, preInt=0): 
774    def preprocess(self,preInit=0,preHough=0,preManual=0,
775                   preVar=0,preSum=0,preInt=0):  
776        """ FOR AUTOMATIC METHODS OPTIMIZATION AND MORE UNIVERSAL SOLUTIONS
777        Function for input image preprocessing based on the methods 
778        defined in the class initialization - self.detection_method, 
779        self.correction_method.
780
781        Parameters
782        ----------
783        preInit : bool, optional
784            Perform preprocessing of the input image (when using icut or heq). 
785            This is called automatically every time, if no preprocessing
786            specified, the detection and refinement will be performed on 
787            original image. The default is 0.
788        preHough : bool, optional
789            Perform preprocessing for automatic detection via Hough transform. 
790            
791
792        Returns
793        -------
794        manu : NumPy array
795            Pre-processed image for the manual detection method
796        edges : array of bool
797            Detected edges via Canny detector for automatic Hough transform
798        """
799        
800        # Flags
801        control_print = 1
802        
803        # Load original image
804        if len(self.parent.image.shape)!=2:
805            self.parent.image = np.mean(self.parent.image,axis=2)
806            
807        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
808        
809        ### After initialization: perform an image enhancement if specified
810        if preInit == 1:
811            # Enhance diffraction pattern to make it more visible
812            if self.parent.heq == 1:
813                if self.parent.messages:
814                    print("Histogram equalized.")
815                image = sk.exposure.equalize_adapthist(image)
816
817                
818            # # Edit contrast with a user-predefined parameter
819            # if self.parent.icut is not None:
820            #     if self.parent.messages:
821            #         print("Contrast enhanced.")
822            #     image = np.where(image > self.parent.icut, 
823            #                      self.parent.icut, 
824            #                      image)
825                
826
827            self.parent.to_refine = image
828            return
829        
830        ### Hough transform: perform pre-processing necessary for the detection
831        if preHough == 1:           
832            if self.parent.heq == 0:
833                csq = self.central_square(self.parent.to_refine, csquare=80)   
834                
835                # Beam stopper present in image
836                if np.median(csq)<100 and np.median(csq) > 0:
837                    if self.parent.messages:
838                        print('Beamstopper removed.')
839                    max_indices=np.where(self.parent.to_refine>np.median(csq))
840        
841                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
842                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
843        
844                    self.parent.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0    
845                    
846                    max_indices = \
847                        np.where(self.parent.to_refine < 0.8*np.median(csq))
848                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
849                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
850        
851                    self.parent.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0   
852                    
853                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
854                    edges = sk.feature.canny(self.parent.to_refine, 
855                            sigma=0.2, 
856                            low_threshold=2.5*np.median(self.parent.to_refine), 
857                            high_threshold=3*np.median(self.parent.to_refine))
858                    
859                    # Dilate the edges to connect them
860                    selem = sk.morphology.disk(5)
861                    dilated_edges = sk.morphology.dilation(edges, selem)
862                    
863                    # Erode the dilated edges to reduce thickness and smooth the contour
864                    connected_edges=sk.morphology.erosion(dilated_edges,selem)
865
866                    if control_print == 1:
867                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
868                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.parent.image, origin="upper")
869                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
870                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.parent.to_refine, origin="upper")
871                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
872                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
873                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
874                        ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges, origin="upper")
875                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
876                        plt.tight_layout()
877                        plt.show(block=False)
878                        
879                # No beam stopper in image
880                else:
881                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
882                    print('No beamstopper.')
883                    edges = sk.feature.canny(self.to_refine, 
884                                             sigma=0.2, 
885                                             low_threshold=80, 
886                                             high_threshold=100)
887                    
888                    # Dilate the edges to connect them
889                    selem = sk.morphology.disk(10)
890                    dilated_edges = sk.morphology.dilation(edges, selem)
891                    
892                    # Erode the dilated edges to reduce thickness and smooth the contour
893                    connected_edges=sk.morphology.erosion(dilated_edges,selem)
894                    connected_edges = sk.morphology.remove_small_objects(
895                        connected_edges, 
896                        min_size=100)
897                    
898                    if control_print == 1:
899                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
900                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
901                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
902                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
903                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
904                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper",)
905                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
906                        ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges,origin="upper")
907                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
908                        plt.tight_layout()
909                        plt.show(block=False)
910                
911            elif self.heq == 1: 
912                # Central square extraction
913                csq = self.central_square(self.to_refine, csquare=80)   
914
915                # Beam stopper present in image
916                if 0.4 <= np.median(csq) <= 0.6:
917                    
918                    max_indices = \
919                        np.where(self.to_refine > 2*np.median(self.to_refine))
920    
921                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
922                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
923    
924                    self.to_refine[row_idx, col_idx] = 0 
925                                                     
926                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
927                    edges = sk.feature.canny(
928                        self.to_refine, 
929                        sigma=0.2, 
930                        low_threshold=1.5*np.median(self.to_refine), 
931                        high_threshold=3*np.median(self.to_refine))
932
933                    
934                    if control_print == 1:
935                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
936                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
937                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
938                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
939                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
940                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
941                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
942                      #  ax[1,1].imshow(connected_edges)
943                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
944                        plt.tight_layout()
945                        plt.show(block=False)
946                    
947                # No beam stopper in image
948                else:
949                    # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
950                    edges = sk.feature.canny(
951                        self.to_refine, 
952                        sigma=0.2, 
953                        low_threshold=2.5*np.median(self.to_refine), 
954                        high_threshold=3*np.median(self.to_refine))
955
956                    
957                    if control_print == 1:
958                        fig, ax = plt.subplots(nrows=2, ncols=2)
959                        ax[0,0].imshow(self.image, origin="upper")
960                        ax[0,0].set_title("Original image")
961                        ax[0,1].imshow(self.to_refine, origin="upper")
962                        ax[0,1].set_title("Hough pre-processed")
963                        ax[1,0].imshow(edges, origin="upper")
964                        ax[1,0].set_title("Edges")
965                        ax[1,1].set_title("Connected edges")
966                        plt.tight_layout()
967                        plt.show(block=False)

969            return edges

def detection_intensity(self, csquare, cintensity, plot_results=0): 
 972    def detection_intensity(self, csquare, cintensity, plot_results=0):
 973        '''
 974        Find center of intensity/mass of an array.
 975        
 976        Parameters
 977        ----------
 978        arr : 2D-numpy array
 979            The array, whose intensity center will be determined.
 980        csquare : int, optional, default is 20
 981            The size/edge of the square in the (geometrical) center.
 982            The intensity center will be searched only within the central square.
 983            Reasons: To avoid other spots/diffractions and
 984            to minimize the effect of possible intensity assymetry around center. 
 985        cintensity : float, optional, default is 0.8
 986            The intensity fraction.
 987            When searching the intensity center, we will consider only
 988            pixels with intensity > max.intensity.
 989            
 990        Returns
 991        -------
 992        xc,yc : float,float
 993            XY-coordinates of the intensity/mass center of the array.
 994            Round XY-coordinates if you use them for image/array calculations.
 995        '''  
 996        
 997        # (1) Get image/array size
 998        image = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
 999        
1000                
1001        arr = np.copy(image)
1002        xsize,ysize = arr.shape
1003        
1004        # (2) Calculate borders around the central square
1005        xborder = (xsize - csquare) // 2
1006        yborder = (ysize - csquare) // 2
1007        
1008        # (3) Create the central square,
1009        # from which the intensity center will be detected
1010        arr2 = arr[xborder:-xborder,yborder:-yborder].copy()
1011        
1012        # (4) In the central square,
1013        # set all values below cintenstity to zero
1014        arr2 = np.where(arr2>np.max(arr2)*cintensity, arr2, 0)
1015        
1016        # (5) Determine the intensity center from image moments
1017        # see image moments in...
1018        # skimage: https://scikit-image.org/docs/dev/api/skimage.measure.html
1019        # wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_moment -> Centroid
1020        # ---
1021        # (a) Calculate 1st central moments of the image
1022        M = moments(arr2,1)
1023        # (b) Calculate the intensity center = centroid according to www-help
1024        (self.x, self.y) = (M[1,0]/M[0,0], M[0,1]/M[0,0])
1025        # (c) We have centroid of the central square
1026        # but we have to recalculate it to the whole image
1027        (self.x, self.y) = (self.x + xborder, self.y + yborder)
1028        # (d) Radius of a diffraction ring is hardcoded to 100 here
1029        self.r = 100
1030        
1031        # (6) User information (if required)
1032        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
1033            self.parent.dText = "Center Determination (IntensityCenter): ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1034
1035
1036        # (7) Plot results (if required)
1037        if plot_results == 1:
1038           self.visualize_center(self.x, self.y, self.r) 
1039                
1040        # (8) Return the results:
1041        # a) XY-coordinates of the center
1042        # b) radius of the circle/diff.ring,
1043        #    from which the center was determined
1044        # ! radius of the circle is just hardcoded here - see TODO note above
1045        return(self.x, self.y, self.r)

Find center of intensity/mass of an array.

Parameters
  • arr (2D-numpy array): The array, whose intensity center will be determined.
  • csquare (int, optional, default is 20): The size/edge of the square in the (geometrical) center. The intensity center will be searched only within the central square. Reasons: To avoid other spots/diffractions and to minimize the effect of possible intensity assymetry around center.
  • cintensity (float, optional, default is 0.8): The intensity fraction. When searching the intensity center, we will consider only pixels with intensity > max.intensity.
Returns
  • xc,yc (float,float): XY-coordinates of the intensity/mass center of the array. Round XY-coordinates if you use them for image/array calculations.
def detection_Hough(self, plot_results=0): 
1048    def detection_Hough(self, plot_results=0):
1049        '''        
1050        Perform Hough transform to detect center of diffraction patterns.
1051        This is a method to automatically detect circular diffraction patterns
1052        
1053        Parameters
1054        ----------
1055        plot_results : int, binary
1056            Plot the pattern determined by pixels selected by the user.
1057            Default is 1. To cancel visualization, set plot_results = 0.
1058
1059        Returns
1060        -------
1061        self.x : float64
1062            x-coordinate of the detected center
1063        self.y : float64
1064            y-coordinate of the detected center
1065        self.r : float64
1066            radius of the detected center
1067                                    
1068        '''
1069        ## Image preprocessing
1070        im = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)
1071        
1072        # if the brightness of the image is small enough, pixel values greater
1073        # than 50 will be set to 0 -- removal of the beam stopper influence
1074        
1075        if self.parent.heq == 0:
1076            if sum(sum(im)) < 150000:
1077                    max_indices = np.where(im > 50)
1078        
1079                    row_idx = max_indices[0]
1080                    col_idx = max_indices[1]
1081        
1082                    im[row_idx, col_idx] = 0    
1083                
1084            # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1085            edges = sk.feature.canny(im, 
1086                                     sigma=0.2, 
1087                                     low_threshold=80, 
1088                                     high_threshold=100)
1089        elif self.heq == 1:
1090            if sum(sum(im)) > 40000:
1091                max_indices = np.where(im > 50)
1092
1093                row_idx = max_indices[0]
1094                col_idx = max_indices[1]
1095
1096                im[row_idx, col_idx] = 0    
1097            
1098            # Detect edges using the Canny edge detector
1099            edges = sk.feature.canny(im, 
1100                                     sigma=0.2, 
1101                                     low_threshold=0.80, 
1102                                     high_threshold=1)
1103        
1104        
1105        # Define the radii range for the concentric circles
1106        # (set empirically based on the available pictures)
1107        min_radius = 40
1108        max_radius = 200
1109        radius_step = 10
1110        radii = np.arange(min_radius, max_radius + radius_step, radius_step)
1111
1112        ### Perform the Hough transform to detect circles
1113        # Circle detection involves converting edge pixels into parameter space, 
1114        # where each point represents a possible circle center and radius. 
1115        # The circles are then identified as peaks in the parameter space, 
1116        # enabling accurate detection of circular shapes in the image.
1117        hough_res = hough_circle(edges, radii)
1118
1119        # Extract the circle peaks
1120        _, self.x, self.y, self.r = hough_circle_peaks(hough_res, 
1121                                                            radii, 
1122                                                            total_num_peaks=1)
1123        
1124        
1125        # User information:
1126        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
1127            self.parent.dText = "Center Determination (HoughTransform) : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
1128        
1129        self.x, self.y, self.r = \
1130            float(self.x[0]), float(self.y[0]), float(self.r[0])
1131
1132        # (7) Plot results (if required)
1133        if plot_results == 1:
1134           self.visualize_center(self.x, self.y, self.r) 
1135           
1136        # Return results, convert coordinates to float
1137        return self.x, self.y, self.r

Perform Hough transform to detect center of diffraction patterns. This is a method to automatically detect circular diffraction patterns

Returns
