  • self.y (float64): y-coordinate of the detected center
  • self.r (float64): radius of the detected center
def detection_3points(self, plot_results=0): 
1140    def detection_3points(self, plot_results=0):
1141        '''         
1142        In the input image, select manually 3 points defining a circle using
1143        a key press event 
1144            - press '1' to select a point
1145                
1146        If the user is not satisfied with the point selection, it can be
1147        deleted using a key press event:
1148            - press '2' to delete the most recent
1149            - press '3' to delete the point closest to the cursor
1150        
1151        If the user is satisified with the points selected, the rest 
1152        of the program will be executed 
1153            - press 'd' to proceed >DONE<
1154        
1155        Coordinates of the center and radius will be calculated automatically
1156        using method self.calculate_circle()
1157        
1158        In addition, the user will be able to manually adjust the original
1159        center position by using pre-defined keys.
1160        
1161        Parameters
1162        ----------
1163        plot_results : int, binary
1164            Plot the pattern determined by pixels selected by the user.
1165            Default is 1. To cancel visualization, set plot_results = 0.
1166        
1167        Returns
1168        -------
1169        self.x : float64
1170            x-coordinate of the detected center
1171        self.y : float64
1172            y-coordinate of the detected center
1173        self.r : float64
1174            radius of the detected center
1175            (if available, othervise returns None)
1176                                    
1177        '''
1178        
1179        # Load image
1180        im = self.parent.to_refine
1181        
1182        # Edit contrast with a user-predefined parameter
1183        if self.parent.icut is not None:
1184            if self.parent.messages:
1185                print("Contrast enhanced.")
1186            im = np.where(im > self.parent.icut, 
1187                              self.parent.icut, 
1188                              im)
1189            
1190        # Create a figure and display the image
1191        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 12))
1192        
1193        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
1194        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
1195        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
1196 
1197        plt.title("Select 3 points defining one of diffraction circles", 
1198                  fontsize = 20)
1199        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
1200        ax.axis('off')
1201
1202        # User information:
1203        instructions = dedent(
1204            """
1205            CenterDetermination :: ThreePoints (semi-automated method)
1206            Select 3 points to define a diffraction circle using keys:
1207              - '1' : define a point at current cursor position
1208              - '2' : delete the last point
1209              - '3' : delete the point closest to the cursor
1210              - 'd' : done = finished = go to the next step
1211            Close the figure to terminate. No center will be detected.
1212            """)
1213
1214        if self.parent.messages:
1215            print(instructions)
1216       
1217        # Enable interactive mode
1218        # (figure is updated after every plotting command
1219        # (so that calling figure.show() is not necessary
1220        plt.ion()
1221 
1222        # Initialize the list of coordinates
1223        self.coords = [] 
1224        
1225        # Initialize all flags and counters
1226        calculate_circle_flag = False          # press 'd' event
1227        termination_flag = False               # close window event
1228        point_counter = 0                      # number of selected points
1229        
1230        ### Define the event handler for figure close event
1231        def onclose(event):
1232            nonlocal termination_flag
1233            termination_flag = True
1234            if self.parent.messages:
1235                print('Execution terminated.')
1236                print("------------------------------------------------------------")
1237
1238 
1239        # Connect the event handler to the figure close event
1240        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('close_event', onclose)
1241        
1242        
1243        ### Define the callback function for key press events
1244        def onkeypress(event):
1245            # nonlocal to modify the flag variable in the outer scope
1246            nonlocal calculate_circle_flag, point_counter, termination_flag
1247            
1248            # Store the zoom level
1249            current_xlim = ax.get_xlim()
1250            current_ylim = ax.get_ylim()
1251 
1252            ## Delete points -- the closest to the cursor
1253            if event.key == '3':
1254                point_counter -= 1
1255                if len(self.coords) > 0:
1256                    pointer_x, pointer_y = event.xdata, event.ydata
1257                    distances = [
1258                        np.sqrt((x - pointer_x)**2 + (y - pointer_y)**2)
1259                        for x, y in self.coords]
1260                    closest_index = np.argmin(distances)
1261                    del self.coords[closest_index]
1262    
1263                    ## Redraw the image without the deleted point
1264                    ax.clear()
1265                    ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
1266                              origin="upper")
1267                    for x, y in self.coords:
1268                        ax.scatter(x, y, 
1269                                   c='r', marker='x', 
1270                                   s=self.parent.marker_size)
1271
1272                    my_plot_title = (
1273                        "Select 3 points to define "
1274                        "one of diffraction circles.")
1275                    plt.title(my_plot_title, fontsize=20)
1276                    
1277                    # Retore the previous zoom level
1278                    ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
1279                    ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
1280                    ax.axis('off')
1281                    
1282                    fig.canvas.draw()
1283                else:
1284                    print("No points to delete.")
1285    
1286            # Delete recent point (last added) -- independent on the cursor
1287            if event.key == '2':
1288                # Check if there are points to delete
1289                if point_counter > 0:  
1290                    point_counter -= 1
1291                    if len(self.coords) > 0:
1292                        # Delete the last point in the list
1293                        del self.coords[-1]
1294    
1295                        # Redraw the image without the deleted point
1296                        ax.clear()
1297                        ax.imshow(im, cmap=self.parent.cmap,
1298                                  origin="upper")
1299                        for x, y in self.coords:
1300                            ax.scatter(x, y,
1301                                       c='r', marker='x', 
1302                                       s=self.parent.marker_size)
1303
1304                        my_plot_title = (
1305                            "Select 3 points to define "
1306                            "one of diffraction circles.")
1307                        plt.title(my_plot_title)
1308                        
1309                        # Retore the previous zoom level
1310                        ax.set_xlim(current_xlim)
1311                        ax.set_ylim(current_ylim)
1312                        ax.axis('off')
1313
1314                        fig.canvas.draw()
1315                else:
1316                    print("No points to delete.")
1317                    
1318            ## Select points 
1319            elif event.key == '1':
1320                # Only allow selecting up to three points
1321                if point_counter < 3:  
1322                    # Save the coordinates of the clicked point
1323                    new_point = (event.xdata, event.ydata)
1324                    
1325                    if new_point in self.coords:
1326                        # Do not allow multiple selection of one point
1327                        print("The selected point already exists.")
1328                    else:
1329                        # Add selected point
1330                        self.coords.append(new_point)
1331    
1332                        # Visualize the selected point on the image

1343

1345

In the input image, select manually 3 points defining a circle using a key press event - press '1' to select a point

If the user is not satisfied with the point selection, it can be deleted using a key press event: - press '2' to delete the most recent - press '3' to delete the point closest to the cursor

If the user is satisified with the points selected, the rest of the program will be executed - press 'd' to proceed >DONE<

Coordinates of the center and radius will be calculated automatically using method self.calculate_circle()

In addition, the user will be able to manually adjust the original center position by using pre-defined keys.

Parameters
  • plot_results (int, binary): Plot the pattern determined by pixels selected by the user. Default is 1. To cancel visualization, set plot_results = 0.
Returns
  • self.x (float64): x-coordinate of the detected center
  • self.y (float64): y-coordinate of the detected center
  • self.r (float64): radius of the detected center (if available, othervise returns None)

Adjustment of the center position calculated from 3 points. Interactive refinement using keys:

The user can change the position of the center of the diffraction pattern and also the radius of the detected pattern using keys: - left / right / top / down arrows : move left / right / top / down - '+' : increase radius - '-' : decrease radius - 'd' : done, termination of the refinement

If the interactive figure is closed without any modifications, the function returns input variables and the proccess terminates.

Parameters
  • fig (figure.Figure object): interactive figure in which a diffraction pattern has been manually detected.
  • circle (patches.Circle object): circle defined via 3 points manually delected
  • center (tuple): calculated center of the input circle.
  • plot_results (boolean): visualize results. The default is 1 (plot detected center).
Returns
  • xy (tuple): x,y-coordinates of the center of the diffraction pattern.
  • r (integer): radius of the diffraction pattern.
def calculate_circle( self, plot_results: int) -> tuple[float, float, float, tuple[float, float], matplotlib.patches.Circle]: 
1612    def calculate_circle(self, plot_results:int)->tuple[
1613            float,float,float,tuple[float,float], plt.Circle]:
1614        ''' 
1615        Calculates coordinates of the center and radius of a circle defined via
1616        3 points determined by the user. Plots the calculated circle, detected 
1617        points and marks the center.
1618        
1619        Parameters
1620        ----------
1621        plot_results : int, binary
1622            Plot the calculated center and circle. To cancel visualization, 
1623            set plot_results = 0.
1624        self.coords : array of float64
1625            Coordinates of 3 manually selected points
1626        
1627        Returns
1628        -------
1629        self.x : float64
1630            x-coordinate of the detected center
1631        self.y : float64
1632            y-coordinate of the detected center
1633        self.r : float64
1634            radius of the detected center
1635                                    
1636        '''
1637        # Extract the coordinates of the points        
1638        x = [self.coords[0][0], self.coords[1][0], self.coords[2][0]]
1639        y = [self.coords[0][1], self.coords[1][1], self.coords[2][1]]
1640        
1641        # Compute the radius and center coordinates of the circle
1642            # a: the squared length of the side between the second 
1643            #    and third points (x[1], y[1]) and (x[2], y[2]).
1644            # b: the squared length of the side between the first 
1645            #    and third points (x[0], y[0]) and (x[2], y[2]).
1646            # c: the squared length of the side between the first 
1647            #    and second points (x[0], y[0]) and (x[1], y[1]).
1648            # s: the twice the signed area of the triangle formed by 3 points
1649            
1650        c = (x[0]-x[1])**2 + (y[0]-y[1])**2
1651        a = (x[1]-x[2])**2 + (y[1]-y[2])**2
1652        b = (x[2]-x[0])**2 + (y[2]-y[0])**2
1653        s = 2*(a*b + b*c + c*a) - (a*a + b*b + c*c) 
1654        
1655        # coordinates of the center
1656        self.x = (a*(b+c-a)*x[0] + b*(c+a-b)*x[1] + c*(a+b-c)*x[2]) / s
1657        self.y = (a*(b+c-a)*y[0] + b*(c+a-b)*y[1] + c*(a+b-c)*y[2]) / s 
1658        
1659        # radius
1660        ar = a**0.5
1661        br = b**0.5
1662        cr = c**0.5 
1663        self.r = ar*br*cr/((ar+br+cr)*(-ar+br+cr)*(ar-br+cr)*(ar+br-cr))**0.5
1664        
1665        # # Print results
1666        # if self.parent.messages:
1667        #     print("CenterEstimator :: manual center detection")
1668        #     print(f"Center coordinates: {self.x:.2f} {self.y:.2f}")
1669                    
1670        if plot_results==1:
1671            # Create and manage the figure
1672            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1673            manager = plt.get_current_fig_manager()
1674            manager.window.showMaximized()
1675            ax.imshow(self.parent.image, cmap = self.parent.cmap,
1676                      origin="upper")
1677            
1678            # Plot center and points
1679            center, = plt.plot(self.x, self.y, 
1680                     'rx', 
1681                     label='Center', 
1682                     markersize=12)
1683            plt.scatter(x,y, 
1684                        marker='x', 
1685                        color='palevioletred', 
1686                        label = 'Circle points')
1687            plt.title('Circle found using 3 manually detected points')
1688            
1689            # Circle visualization
1690            circle = plt.Circle((self.x,self.y), 
1691                                self.r, 
1692                                color='palevioletred', 
1693                                fill=False,
1694                                label = 'pattern')
1695            ax.add_artist(circle)
1696            
1697            # Set the aspect ratio to equal to have a circular shape
1698            plt.axis('equal')
1699            
1700            plt.legend(loc='lower center', 
1701                       ncol=2, 
1702                       bbox_to_anchor=(0.5,-0.1), 
1703                       mode='expand', 
1704                       frameon=False)
1705            plt.axis('off')
1706            plt.tight_layout()
1707            plt.show(block=False)
1708
1709        
1710        self.center = (self.x, self.y)
1711        self.circle = plt.Circle((self.x,self.y),self.r)
1712        
1713
1714        return self.x, self.y, self.r, self.center, self.circle

Calculates coordinates of the center and radius of a circle defined via 3 points determined by the user. Plots the calculated circle, detected points and marks the center.

Parameters
  • plot_results (int, binary): Plot the calculated center and circle. To cancel visualization, set plot_results = 0.
  • self.coords (array of float64): Coordinates of 3 manually selected points
Returns
  • self.x (float64): x-coordinate of the detected center
  • self.y (float64): y-coordinate of the detected center
  • self.r (float64): radius of the detected center
def get_radius(self, im: numpy.ndarray, x: float, y: float, disp: bool = False) -> float: 
1717    def get_radius(
1718            self, im:np.ndarray, x:float, y:float, disp:bool=False) -> float:
1719        """
1720        Calculate the radius of a circle based on intensity profiles along 
1721        horizontal and vertical axes.
1722    
1723        Parameters
1724        ----------
1725        im : np.ndarray
1726            The 2D image array containing the circle.
1727        x : float
1728            The x-coordinate of the circle's center.
1729        y : float
1730            The y-coordinate of the circle's center.
1731        disp : bool, optional
1732            If True, visualizes the detected intensity profiles and peaks 
1733            (default is False).
1734    
1735        Returns
1736        -------
1737        float
1738            The estimated radius of the circle. Defaults to 100 if no valid 
1739            radius is detected.
1740        """
1741        
1742        def match_peaks(arr):
1743            """
1744            Finds the most similar values across the left and right halves of 
1745            an array, omitting the highest value. If exactly two peaks are 
1746            detected, they are returned as the best pair.
1747            """
1748            if len(arr) < 2:  # Not enough values to compare
1749                if self.parent.messages:
1750                    print("Not enough values to find similar pairs.")
1751                return None, None
1752    
1753            # Special case: if there are exactly 2 peaks, return them
1754            if len(arr) == 2:
1755                if self.parent.messages:
1756                    print("Exactly two peaks detected. Returning them as the best pair.")
1757                return 0, 1
1758    
1759            # Find the index of the highest value
1760            center_idx = np.argmax(arr)
1761    
1762            # Split into left and right halves, excluding the highest value
1763            left = arr[:center_idx]
1764            right = arr[center_idx + 1:]
1765            left_indices = np.arange(center_idx)
1766            right_indices = np.arange(center_idx + 1, len(arr))
1767    
1768            if len(left) == 0 or len(right) == 0:  # Check for empty halves
1769                if self.parent.messages:
1770                    print("One of the halves is empty.")
1771                return None, None
1772    
1773            # Initialize variables for tracking the smallest difference
1774            smallest_diff = np.inf
1775            best_pair = (None, None)
1776    
1777            # Compare each value in the left with every value in the right
1778            for i, l_val in enumerate(left):
1779                for j, r_val in enumerate(right):
1780                    diff = abs(l_val - r_val)
1781                    if diff < smallest_diff:
1782                        smallest_diff = diff
1783                        best_pair = (left_indices[i], right_indices[j])
1784    
1785            return best_pair
1786    
1787        self.xpeaks, self.ypeaks = None, None
1788        self.xyvals, self.yyvals = None, None
1789    
1790        x_line = im[int(x), :]
1791        y_line = im[:, int(y)]
1792    
1793        # Define threshold for peak detection
1794        x_thr = 0.5 * max(x_line)
1795        y_thr = 0.5 * max(y_line)
1796    
1797        # Find peaks with dynamic height thresholds
1798        self.xpeaks, _ = find_peaks(x_line, 
1799                                    height=x_thr, 
1800                                    prominence=1, 
1801                                    distance=30)
1802        self.xyvals = x_line[self.xpeaks]
1803        self.ypeaks, _ = find_peaks(y_line, 
1804                                    height=y_thr, 
1805                                    prominence=1, 
1806                                    distance=30)
1807        self.yyvals = y_line[self.ypeaks]
1808    
1809        # Define half the length of the image
1810        half_length_x = x_line.shape[0] / 2
1811        half_length_y = y_line.shape[0] / 2
1812    
1813        # Check the additional condition for xpeaks
1814        if len(self.xpeaks) == 2 and (
1815            (self.xpeaks[0]<half_length_x and self.xpeaks[1]<half_length_x) or
1816            (self.xpeaks[0]>half_length_x and self.xpeaks[1]>half_length_x)):
1817            if self.parent.messages:
1818                print("xpeaks condition met: Both peaks are on the same side of the center.")
1819            self.pairX = None
1820        else:
1821            self.pairX = match_peaks(self.xyvals)
1822    
1823        # Check the additional condition for ypeaks
1824        if len(self.ypeaks) == 2 and (
1825            (self.ypeaks[0]<half_length_y and self.ypeaks[1]<half_length_y) or
1826            (self.ypeaks[0]>half_length_y and self.ypeaks[1]>half_length_y)):
1827            if self.parent.messages:
1828                print("ypeaks condition met: Both peaks are on the same side of the center.")
1829            self.pairY = None
1830        else:
1831            self.pairY = match_peaks(self.yyvals)
1832    
1833        # Determine radius based on available pairs
1834        if self.pairX is None or None in self.pairX:
1835            rx_x = None
1836        else:
1837            x1 = self.xpeaks[self.pairX[0]]
1838            x2 = self.xpeaks[self.pairX[1]]
1839            rx_x = abs(x1 - x2) / 2
1840    
1841        if self.pairY is None or None in self.pairY:
1842            rx_y = None
1843        else:
1844            y1 = self.ypeaks[self.pairY[0]]
1845            y2 = self.ypeaks[self.pairY[1]]
1846            rx_y = abs(y1 - y2) / 2
1847    
1848        if rx_x is not None and rx_y is not None:
1849            rx = np.mean([rx_x, rx_y])
1850        elif rx_x is not None:
1851            rx = rx_x
1852        elif rx_y is not None:
1853            rx = rx_y
1854        else:
1855            if self.parent.messages:
1856                print("No valid pairs detected for radius calculation.")
1857            return 100  # Default radius or error handling
1858    
1859        if disp:
1860            # Plot xline with peaks
1861            plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
1862    
1863            # Plot for xline
1864            plt.subplot(2, 1, 1)
1865            plt.plot(x_line, label='xline')
1866            plt.plot(self.xpeaks, self.xyvals, "ro", label='Peaks')
1867            plt.title('Peaks in xline')
1868            plt.xlabel('Index')
1869            plt.ylabel('Value')
1870            plt.legend()
1871    
1872            # Plot for yline
1873            plt.subplot(2, 1, 2)
1874            plt.plot(y_line, label='yline')
1875            plt.plot(self.ypeaks, self.yyvals, "ro", label='Peaks')  
1876            plt.title('Peaks in yline')
1877            plt.xlabel('Index')
1878            plt.ylabel('Value')
1879            plt.legend()
1880    
1881            plt.tight_layout()
1882            plt.show()
1883    
1884        return rx

Calculate the radius of a circle based on intensity profiles along horizontal and vertical axes.

  • x (float): The x-coordinate of the circle's center.

def visualize_center(self, x: float, y: float, r: float) -> None:

1909    
1910        if self.parent.icut is not None:
1911            im = np.where(image > self.parent.icut, self.parent.icut, image)
1912        else:
1913            im = np.copy(image)
1914            
1915        # Create a figure and display the image
1916        fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1917        
1918        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
1919        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
1920        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
1921 
1922        plt.title("Detected center")
1923        ax.axis('off')
1924
1925        # Plot center point
1926        ax.scatter(x,y,
1927                label= f'center:  [{x:.1f}, {y:.1f}]',
1928                marker='x', color="red", s=60)
1929
1930        plt.legend(loc='upper right')
1931        
1932        # Display the image
1933        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
1934        plt.axis('off')
1935        plt.tight_layout()
1936        plt.show(block=False)

class CenterRefinement: 
1940class CenterRefinement:
1941    '''
1942    CenterRefinement object - final refinement of a diffractogram center.
1943
1944    This class is responsible for refining the center coordinates of a 
1945    diffraction pattern based on the selected refinement method. It 
1946    initializes with the input image and other parameters that influence 
1947    the refinement process.
1948
1949    Parameters
1950    ----------
1951    parent : CenterLocator
1952        Reference to the parent CenterLocator object, allowing access to 
1953        shared attributes and methods.
1954    input_image : str, path, or numpy.array
1955        The input image representing a 2D diffraction pattern, provided as 
1956        a file path or a NumPy array.
1957    refinement : str or None, optional, default is None
1958        The method used for the final center refinement.
1959        Options include:
1960        - 'manual': Manual adjustment - user adjust the position
1961          of the selected diffration ring.
1962        - 'sum': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring
1963          with maximal sum of intensities.
1964        - 'var': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring
1965          with minimal variance of intensities.
1966    out_file : str, optional
1967        Filename of the text file to which the refined center coordinates 
1968        will be saved.
1969    heq : bool, optional
1970        Flag to indicate whether to perform histogram equalization on the
1971        input image. Default is False.
1972    icut : float, optional
1973        Cut-off intensity level for processing the image. Default is None.
1974    cmap : str, optional
1975        Colormap to be used for displaying the image. Default is 'gray'.
1976    messages : bool, optional
1977        Flag to enable or disable informational messages during processing. 
1978        Default is False.
1979    print_sums : bool, optional
1980        If True, prints the sum of intensity values for the refined circle 
1981        after each adjustment, relevant only for manual refinement methods.
1982
1983    Returns
1984    -------
1985    None
1986
1987    Notes
1988    -----
1989    - The class refines the detected center coordinates based on the 
1990      specified refinement method.
1991    - The refined coordinates are stored in instance variables
1992      `xx`, `yy`, and `rr`, representing the refined center's x-coordinate, 
1993      y-coordinate, and radius, respectively.
1994    - If an unsupported refinement method is specified, the class will print 
1995      an error message and exit.
1996    '''
1997    
1998    def __init__(self, parent,
1999                 input_image, 
2000                 refinement = None,
2001                 in_file = None,
2002                 out_file = None,
2003                 heq = False, 
2004                 icut = None,
2005                 cmap = 'gray',
2006                 messages = False,
2007                 print_sums = False):

2009        ######################################################################
2010        # PRIVATE FUNCTION: Initialize CenterLocator object.
2011        # The parameters are described above in class definition.
2012        ######################################################################
2013        
2014        ## (0) Initialize input attributes
2015        self.parent = parent
2016        
2017        ## (1) Initialize new attributes
2018        self.step=0.5
2019        
2020        ## (2) Run functions
2021        if refinement is not None:
2022            self.ret = 1
2023            par_short = self.parent.center1
2024        
2025            if refinement == "manual":
2026                # Manual refinement method
2027                if parent.determination == 'manual':
2028                    self.xx, self.yy, self.rr = \
2029                        par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r
2030                    par_short.x, par_short.y = \
2031                        par_short.backip[0], par_short.backip[1]
2032                    if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
2033                        self.parent.rText = \
2034                            "Center Refinement (Interactive)       : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
2035                elif parent.determination == 'intensity':
2036                    self.yy, self.xx, self.rr = self.ref_interactive(
2037                        par_short.y, par_short.x, par_short.r)
2038                else:
2039                    self.yy, self.xx, self.rr = self.ref_interactive(
2040                        par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r)
2041        
2042            elif refinement == "var":
2043                # Intensity variance refinement
2044                self.xx, self.yy, self.rr = self.ref_var(
2045                    par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r)
2046        
2047            elif refinement == "sum":
2048                # Intensity sum refinement
2049                self.xx, self.yy, self.rr = self.ref_sum(
2050                    par_short.x, par_short.y, par_short.r)
2051        
2052            else:
2053                print("Selected refinement method is not supported.")
2054                sys.exit()
2055                        
2056        else: 
2057            self.ret = 2

2060    def ref_interactive(self, px, py, pr):
2061        ''' 
2062        Manual refinement of the detected diffraction pattern via one of 
2063        the methods provided in the class CircleDetection.
2064        
2065        The user can change the position of the center of the diffraction
2066        pattern and also the radius of the detected pattern using keys:
2067            - left / right / top / down arrows : move left / right / top / down
2068            - '+' : increase radius
2069            - '-' : decrease radius
2070            - 'b'/'l' : increase/decrease step size")
2071            - 'd' : done, termination of the refinement
2072
2073        If the interactive figure is closed without any modifications,
2074        the function returns input variables and the proccess terminates.
2075        
2076        The results are shown in a figure when the refinement is successful.

2094            new radius of the circular diffraction pattern
2095        '''
2096        
2097        # Load original image
2098        im = np.copy(self.parent.to_refine)

2101        if self.parent.icut is not None:
2102            if self.parent.messages:
2103                print("Contrast enhanced.")

2105                              self.parent.icut, 
2106                              im)
2107            
2108

2112        termination_flag = False

2116            instructions = dedent("""
2117            
2118            Interactive refinement. Use these keys:
2119                  - '←' : move left
2120                  - '→' : move right
2121                  - '↑' : move up
2122                  - '↓' : move down
2123                  - '+' : increase circle radius
2124                  - '-' : decrease circle radius
2125                  - 'b' : increase step size
2126                  - 'l' : decrease step size
2127                  - 'd' : refinement done
2128                  
2129            DISCLAIMER: For the purpose of the center shift, the default
2130            shortcuts for left and right arrows were removed.
2131            """)
2132            print(instructions)
2133        
2134        if self.parent.print_sums:
2135            print("Intensity sums during refinement:")
2136            
2137        # Create a figure and display the image
2138        fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12, 12))
2139        
2140        # Allow using arrows to move back and forth between view ports
2141        plt.rcParams['keymap.back'].append('left')
2142        plt.rcParams['keymap.forward'].append('right')
2143        
2144        circle = plt.Circle(
2145            (px, py), pr, color='r', fill=False)
2146        ax.add_artist(circle)
2147
2148        # Plot center point
2149        center, = ax.plot(px, py, 'rx', markersize=12)
2150                    
2151
2152        plt.title('Manually adjust the center position.', 
2153                  fontsize=20)
2154
2155        ax.imshow(im, cmap = self.parent.cmap, origin="upper")
2156        ax.axis('off')
2157        
2158        # Enable interactive mode
2159        plt.ion()
2160        
2161
2162        # Display the image
2163        # fig.set_size_inches(self.fig_width, self.fig_height)
2164        plt.show(block=False)
2165        
2166        ### Define the event handler for figure close event
2167        def onclose(event):
2168            nonlocal termination_flag
2169            termination_flag = True
2170 
2171        # Connect the event handler to the figure close event
2172        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('close_event', onclose)
2173
2174        # Define the callback function for key press events
2175        def onkeypress2(event):
2176            # Use nonlocal to modify the center position in the outer scope
2177            nonlocal xy, r, termination_flag
2178        
2179            # OTHER KEYS USED IN INTERACTIVE FIGURES
2180            #   event.key == '1': select a point in self.detection_3points()
2181            #   event.key == '2': delete the last point in self.detection...
2182            #   event.key == '3': delete a point in self.detection...
2183            #   event.key == '+': increase circle radius
2184            #   event.key == '-': decrease circle radius           
2185            #   event.key == 'b': increase the step size (big step size)
2186            #   event.key == 'l': decrease the step size (little step size)
2187            #   event.key == 'd': proceed in self.detection_3points()
2188        
2189            if event.key in ['up', 'down', 'left', 'right', '+', '-']:                    
2190                if event.key in ['+', '-']:
2191                    r += 1 if event.key == '+' else -1
2192                else:
2193                    # Perform shifts normally
2194                    if event.key == 'up':
2195                        xy[1] -= self.step
2196                    elif event.key == 'down':
2197                        xy[1] += self.step
2198                    elif event.key == 'left':
2199                        xy[0] -= self.step
2200                    elif event.key == 'right':
2201                        xy[0] += self.step
2202                    
2203                    # Print sum only for arrow keys
2204                    if self.parent.print_sums:
2205                        s = self.parent.intensity_sum(self.parent.to_refine, 
2206                                                      xy[0], xy[1], r)
2207                        print(f'{s:.2f}')
2208            
2209            # Terminate the interactive refinement with 'd' key
2210            if event.key == 'd':
2211                termination_flag = True
2212        
2213            # Change step size 
2214            if event.key == 'b':
2215                self.step = self.step * 5
2216        
2217            if event.key == 'l':
2218                self.step = self.step / 5
2219                if self.step < 0.5:
2220                    self.step = 0.5
2221        
2222            # Update the plot with the new center position
2223            circle.set_center((xy[0], xy[1]))  # circle
2224            circle.set_radius(r)               # radius
2225            center.set_data([xy[0]], [xy[1]])  # center
2226        
2227            plt.title("Manually adjust the center position.", fontsize=20)
2228        
2229            # Update the plot
2230            plt.draw()
2231
2232            
2233        # Disconnect the on_key_press1 event handler from the figure
2234        fig.canvas.mpl_disconnect(fig.canvas.manager.key_press_handler_id)
2235        
2236        # Connect the callback function to the key press event
2237        fig.canvas.mpl_connect('key_press_event', onkeypress2)
2238
2239        # Enable interaction mode
2240        plt.ion() 
2241               
2242        # Wait for 'd' key press or figure closure
2243        while not termination_flag:
2244            try:
2245                plt.waitforbuttonpress(timeout=0.1)
2246            except KeyboardInterrupt:
2247                # If the user manually closes the figure, terminate the loop
2248                termination_flag = True
2249         
2250        # Turn off interactive mode
2251        plt.ioff()
2252

2254        plt.tight_layout()
2255
2256        plt.show(block=False)

2259        if termination_flag: 
2260            plt.close()  # Close the figure

2263        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
2264            self.parent.rText = "Center Refinement (Interactive)       : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
2265
2266        return xy[0], xy[1], r

2269    def ref_var(self, px, py, pr, plot_results=0):
2270        '''         
2271        Adjust center coordinates of a detected circular diffraction pattern.
2272        The center adjustment is based on variance minimization.
2273        
2274        The 8-neighbourhood pixels (x) of the current center (o) 
2275        will be tested regarding the minimization:
2276    
2277        - x x x : (px - dx, py + dy) (px, py + dy) ( px + dx, py + dy)
2278    
2279        - x o x : (px - dx, py)      (px, py)      (px + dx, py)
2280    
2281        - x x x : (px - dx, py - dy) (px, py - dy) (px + dx, py - dy)
2282        
2283
2284        Parameters
2285        ----------
2286        self.image : array of uint8
2287            Input image in which the diffraction pattern is to be found
2288        px : float64
2289            x-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted
2290        py : float64
2291            y-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted
2292        pr : float64
2293            radius of the detected center
2294        plot_results : integer (default = 1)
2295            Plot Detected center. The default is 1.
2296        
2297        Returns
2298        -------
2299        px : array of int32
2300           corrected x-coordinates of pixels from circle border
2301        py : array of int32
2302            corrected y-coordinates of pixels from circle border
2303        pr : array of int32
2304            radius of the detected center
2305            
2306        '''
2307        
2308        # Store input for plot
2309        bckup = [np.copy(px), np.copy(py), np.copy(pr)]
2310        
2311        # Load image
2312        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
2313
2314        # Starting values to be modified 
2315        init_var = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, px, py, pr)
2316        min_intensity_var = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, px, py, pr)
2317        best_center = (np.copy(px), np.copy(py))
2318        best_radius = np.copy(pr)
2319    
2320        # Convergence criterion for termination of gradient optimization 
2321        # (1) small positive value that serves as a threshold to determine 
2322        #     when the optimization process has converged
2323        convergence_threshold = 0.1*min_intensity_var
2324        
2325        # (2) maximum number of iterations of optimization
2326        max_iterations = 10
2327        
2328        # (3) keep track of the number of consecutive iterations where there 
2329        #     is no improvement in the objective function beyond 
2330        #     the convergence threshold
2331        no_improvement_count = 0
2332    
2333    
2334        # iterative refinement of the center of a circle while keeping
2335        # the radius constant.
2336        step = 0.3
2337        neighbors = [(float(dx), float(dy))
2338            for dx in np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)
2339            for dy in np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)]
2340        
2341        for iteration in range(max_iterations):    
2342            # Refine center while keeping radius constant
2343            curr = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, 
2344                                      best_center[0], 
2345                                      best_center[1], 
2346                                      best_radius) 
2347            # Store intensity sums of the current center's neighborhood
2348            curr_intensity_var = []
2349            for dx, dy in neighbors:
2350                nx, ny = best_center[0] + dx, best_center[1] + dy
2351                # Check if the point is within the expanded search radius
2352                curr_intensity_var.append(
2353                    self.parent.intensity_variance(image, nx, ny, best_radius))
2354            
2355            # Find the minimum value coordinates within curr_intensity_var
2356            cx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmin(curr_intensity_var),
2357                                     [len(curr_intensity_var),1])
2358                    
2359            # Check for improvement of criterion -- in each iteration just once,
2360            # as the algorithm checks the neighbourhood of the best center (in
2361            # each iteration, the center is updated if possible)
2362            if min(curr_intensity_var) <= min_intensity_var:                           
2363                min_intensity_var = max(curr_intensity_var)
2364                
2365                # Calculate the new best coordinates of the center
2366                n = neighbors[cx]
2367                (nx, ny) = tuple(map(lambda x, y: float(x) + float(y), 
2368                                     best_center, n))
2369                best_center = px, py = (np.copy(nx), np.copy(ny))
2370                
2371            # Update maximum intensity sum 
2372            min_intensity_var = self.parent.intensity_var(image, 
2373                                                    best_center[0], 
2374                                                    best_center[1], 
2375                                                    best_radius) 
2376            
2377            # Refine radius if necessary while keeping the center position 
2378            # constant. It iterates through different radius adjustments to find
2379            # a radius that maximizes the intensity sum of pixels
2380            
2381            radi_intensity_var = []
2382            radii = np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)
2383            for dr in radii:
2384                new_radius = best_radius + dr
2385                radi_intensity_var.append(self.parent.intensity_var(image, 
2386                                                             best_center[0], 
2387                                                             best_center[1], 
2388                                                             new_radius))
2389                
2390            # Find the minimum value coordinates within curr_var
2391            rx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmin(radi_intensity_var),
2392                                      [len(radi_intensity_var),1])
2393            
2394            # Check for improvement of criterion
2395            if max(radi_intensity_var) < min_intensity_var:
2396                min_intensity_var = max(radi_intensity_var)
2397                
2398                n = radii[rx]
2399                nr = best_radius+n
2400                
2401                best_radius = pr = np.copy(nr)
2402
2403            
2404            # Check for convergence and improvement (termination conditions)
2405            impr = abs(min_intensity_var - curr)
2406            if impr < convergence_threshold:
2407                no_improvement_count += 1
2408                if no_improvement_count == 5:
2409                    break
2410        
2411        # Avoid incorrect/redundant refinement
2412        ## (1) swapped coordinates
2413        if ((bckup[0] > bckup[1] and not best_center[0] > best_center[1])
2414            or  (bckup[0] < bckup[1] and not best_center[0] < best_center[1])):
2415            best_center = best_center[::-1]
2416        
2417        ## (2) worsened final maximum intensity sum than the initial one
2418        if np.round(init_var,-2) < np.round(min_intensity_var,-2):
2419            print("Refinement redundant.")
2420            best_center = np.copy(bckup)
2421    
2422        # Print results
2423        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
2424            self.parent.rText = "Center Refinement (IntensityVar)      : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
2425                                  
2426        return best_center[0], best_center[1], best_radius
2427    
2428    
2429    def ref_sum(self, px, py, pr, plot_results=0):
2430        ''' 
2431        Adjust center position based on gradient optimization method
2432        via maximization of intensity sum.
2433        
2434        The 8-neighbourhood pixels (x) of the current center (o) 
2435        will be tested regarding the maximization:
2436    
2437        - x x x : (px - dx, py + dy) (px, py + dy) ( px + dx, py + dy)
2438    
2439        - x o x : (px - dx, py)      (px, py)      (px + dx, py)
2440    
2441        - x x x : (px - dx, py - dy) (px, py - dy) (px + dx, py - dy)
2442        
2443    
2444        Parameters
2445        ----------
2446        px : float64
2447            x-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted.
2448        py : float64
2449            y-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted.
2450        pr : float64
2451            radius of the detected center.
2452        plot_results : int, optional
2453            Plot Detected center. 
2454            The default is 1.
2455    
2456        Returns  
2457        -------
2458        best_center[0] : float64
2459            Adjusted x-coordinate of the center.
2460        best_center[1] : float64
2461            Adjusted y-coordinate of the center.
2462        best_radius : float64
2463            The adjusted radius of the circular diffraction pattern.
2464        '''
2465        # Store input for plot via self.visualize_refinement()
2466        bckup = [np.copy(px), np.copy(py), np.copy(pr)]
2467
2468        # Image in which the center is refined
2469        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
2470
2471        # Starting values to be modified 
2472        init_sum = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, px, py, pr)
2473        max_intensity_sum = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, px, py, pr)
2474        best_center = (np.copy(px), np.copy(py))
2475        best_radius = np.copy(pr)
2476        
2477        # Convergence criterion for termination of gradient optimization 
2478        # (1) small positive value that serves as a threshold to determine 
2479        #     when the optimization process has converged
2480        convergence_threshold = 0.05*max_intensity_sum
2481        
2482        # (2) maximum number of iterations of optimization
2483        max_iterations = 100
2484        
2485        # (3) keep track of the number of consecutive iterations where there 
2486        #     is no improvement in the objective function beyond 
2487        #     the convergence threshold
2488        no_improvement_count = 0
2489         
2490        # iterative refinement of the center of a circle while keeping
2491        # the radius constant.
2492        step = 0.2
2493        neighbors = [(float(dx), float(dy))
2494            for dx in np.arange(-1.0, 1.0 + step, step)
2495            for dy in np.arange(-1.0, 1.0 + step, step)]
2496
2497        for iteration in range(max_iterations):    
2498            # Refine center while keeping radius constant
2499            curr = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
2500                                      best_center[0], 
2501                                      best_center[1], 
2502                                      best_radius)
2503            
2504            # Store intensity sums of the current center's neighborhood
2505            curr_intensity_sum = []
2506            for dx, dy in neighbors:
2507                nx, ny = best_center[0] + dx, best_center[1] + dy
2508                # Check if the point is within the expanded search radius
2509                curr_intensity_sum.append(self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
2510                                                        nx, ny, 
2511                                                        best_radius))
2512            
2513            # Find the maximum value coordinates within curr_sum
2514            cx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(curr_intensity_sum),
2515                                     [len(curr_intensity_sum),1])
2516                    
2517            # Check for improvement of criterion -- in each iteration just once,
2518            # as the algorithm checks the neighbourhood of the best center (in
2519            # each iteration, the center is updated if possible)
2520            if max(curr_intensity_sum) > max_intensity_sum:                           
2521                max_intensity_sum = max(curr_intensity_sum)
2522                
2523                # Calculate the new best coordinates of the center
2524                n = neighbors[cx]
2525                (nx, ny) = tuple(map(lambda x, y: float(x) + float(y), 
2526                                     best_center, n))
2527                best_center = px, py = (np.copy(nx), np.copy(ny))
2528    
2529            # Update maximum intensity sum 
2530            max_intensity_sum = self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
2531                                                    best_center[0], 
2532                                                    best_center[1], 
2533                                                    best_radius)
2534
2535        
2536            # Refine radius if necessary while keeping the center position 
2537            # constant. It iterates through different radius adjustments to find
2538            # a radius that maximizes the intensity sum of pixels
2539            
2540            radi_intensity_sum = []
2541            radii = np.arange(-1.0, 1.0 + step, step)
2542            for dr in radii:
2543                new_radius = best_radius + dr
2544                radi_intensity_sum.append(self.parent.intensity_sum(image, 
2545                                                            best_center[0], 
2546                                                            best_center[1], 
2547                                                            new_radius))
2548                
2549            # Find the maximum value coordinates within curr_sum
2550            rx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(radi_intensity_sum),
2551                                      [len(radi_intensity_sum),1])
2552
2553            # Check for improvement of criterion
2554            if max(radi_intensity_sum) > max_intensity_sum:
2555                max_intensity_sum = max(radi_intensity_sum)
2556                
2557                n = radii[rx]
2558                nr = best_radius+n
2559                
2560                best_radius = pr = np.copy(nr)
2561                
2562            
2563            # Check for convergence and improvement (termination conditions)
2564            impr = abs(max_intensity_sum - curr)
2565            if impr < convergence_threshold:
2566                no_improvement_count += 1
2567                if no_improvement_count == 25:
2568                    break
2569                
2570
2571        
2572        # Avoid incorrect/redundant refinement
2573        # ## (1) swapped coordinates
2574        # if ((bckup[0] > bckup[1] and not best_center[0] > best_center[1])
2575        #     or  (bckup[0] < bckup[1] and not best_center[0] < best_center[1])):
2576        #     best_center = best_center[::-1]
2577        
2578        ## (2) worsened final maximum intensity sum than the initial one
2579        if np.round(init_sum,-2) > np.round(max_intensity_sum,-2):
2580            print("Refinement redundant.")
2581            best_center = np.copy(bckup)
2582    
2583        # Print results
2584        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
2585            self.parent.rText = \
2586                "Center Refinement (IntensitySum)      : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
2587                
2588        return best_center[0], best_center[1], best_radius

CenterRefinement object - final refinement of a diffractogram center.

This class is responsible for refining the center coordinates of a diffraction pattern based on the selected refinement method. It initializes with the input image and other parameters that influence the refinement process.

Parameters
  • parent (CenterLocator): Reference to the parent CenterLocator object, allowing access to shared attributes and methods.
  • input_image (str, path, or numpy.array): The input image representing a 2D diffraction pattern, provided as a file path or a NumPy array.
  • refinement (str or None, optional, default is None): The method used for the final center refinement. Options include:
    • 'manual': Manual adjustment - user adjust the position of the selected diffration ring.
    • 'sum': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring with maximal sum of intensities.
    • 'var': Auto-refinement - find a diffraction ring with minimal variance of intensities.
  • out_file (str, optional): Filename of the text file to which the refined center coordinates will be saved.
  • heq (bool, optional): Flag to indicate whether to perform histogram equalization on the input image. Default is False.
  • icut (float, optional): Cut-off intensity level for processing the image. Default is None.
  • cmap (str, optional): Colormap to be used for displaying the image. Default is 'gray'.
  • messages (bool, optional): Flag to enable or disable informational messages during processing. Default is False.
  • print_sums (bool, optional): If True, prints the sum of intensity values for the refined circle after each adjustment, relevant only for manual refinement methods.
Returns
  • None
Notes
  • The class refines the detected center coordinates based on the specified refinement method.
  • The refined coordinates are stored in instance variables xx, yy, and rr, representing the refined center's x-coordinate, y-coordinate, and radius, respectively.
  • If an unsupported refinement method is specified, the class will print an error message and exit.

Manual refinement of the detected diffraction pattern via one of the methods provided in the class CircleDetection.

The user can change the position of the center of the diffraction pattern and also the radius of the detected pattern using keys: - left / right / top / down arrows : move left / right / top / down - '+' : increase radius - '-' : decrease radius - 'b'/'l' : increase/decrease step size") - 'd' : done, termination of the refinement

If the interactive figure is closed without any modifications, the function returns input variables and the proccess terminates.

The results are shown in a figure when the refinement is successful.

Parameters
  • px (float64): x-coordinate of the center
  • py (float64): y-coordinate of the center
  • pr (float64): radius of the circular diffraction pattern
Returns
  • x (float64): new x-coordinate of the center
  • y (float64): new y-coordinate of the center

def ref_var(self, px, py, pr, plot_results=0): 
2269    def ref_var(self, px, py, pr, plot_results=0):
2270        '''         
2271        Adjust center coordinates of a detected circular diffraction pattern.
2272        The center adjustment is based on variance minimization.
2273        
2274        The 8-neighbourhood pixels (x) of the current center (o) 
2275        will be tested regarding the minimization:
2276    
2277        - x x x : (px - dx, py + dy) (px, py + dy) ( px + dx, py + dy)
2278    
2279        - x o x : (px - dx, py)      (px, py)      (px + dx, py)
2280    
2281        - x x x : (px - dx, py - dy) (px, py - dy) (px + dx, py - dy)
2282        
2283
2284        Parameters
2285        ----------
2286        self.image : array of uint8
2287            Input image in which the diffraction pattern is to be found
2288        px : float64
2289            x-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted
2290        py : float64
2291            y-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted
2292        pr : float64
2293            radius of the detected center
2294        plot_results : integer (default = 1)
2295            Plot Detected center. The default is 1.
2296        
2297        Returns
2298        -------
2299        px : array of int32
2300           corrected x-coordinates of pixels from circle border
2301        py : array of int32
2302            corrected y-coordinates of pixels from circle border
2303        pr : array of int32
2304            radius of the detected center
2305            
2306        '''
2307        
2308        # Store input for plot
2309        bckup = [np.copy(px), np.copy(py), np.copy(pr)]
2310        
2311        # Load image
2312        image = np.copy(self.parent.image)
2313
2314        # Starting values to be modified 
2315        init_var = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, px, py, pr)
2316        min_intensity_var = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, px, py, pr)
2317        best_center = (np.copy(px), np.copy(py))
2318        best_radius = np.copy(pr)
2319    
2320        # Convergence criterion for termination of gradient optimization 
2321        # (1) small positive value that serves as a threshold to determine 
2322        #     when the optimization process has converged
2323        convergence_threshold = 0.1*min_intensity_var
2324        
2325        # (2) maximum number of iterations of optimization
2326        max_iterations = 10
2327        
2328        # (3) keep track of the number of consecutive iterations where there 
2329        #     is no improvement in the objective function beyond 
2330        #     the convergence threshold
2331        no_improvement_count = 0
2332    
2333    
2334        # iterative refinement of the center of a circle while keeping
2335        # the radius constant.
2336        step = 0.3
2337        neighbors = [(float(dx), float(dy))
2338            for dx in np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)
2339            for dy in np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)]
2340        
2341        for iteration in range(max_iterations):    
2342            # Refine center while keeping radius constant
2343            curr = self.parent.intensity_variance(image, 
2344                                      best_center[0], 
2345                                      best_center[1], 
2346                                      best_radius) 
2347            # Store intensity sums of the current center's neighborhood
2348            curr_intensity_var = []
2349            for dx, dy in neighbors:
2350                nx, ny = best_center[0] + dx, best_center[1] + dy
2351                # Check if the point is within the expanded search radius
2352                curr_intensity_var.append(
2353                    self.parent.intensity_variance(image, nx, ny, best_radius))
2354            
2355            # Find the minimum value coordinates within curr_intensity_var
2356            cx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmin(curr_intensity_var),
2357                                     [len(curr_intensity_var),1])
2358                    
2359            # Check for improvement of criterion -- in each iteration just once,
2360            # as the algorithm checks the neighbourhood of the best center (in
2361            # each iteration, the center is updated if possible)
2362            if min(curr_intensity_var) <= min_intensity_var:                           
2363                min_intensity_var = max(curr_intensity_var)
2364                
2365                # Calculate the new best coordinates of the center
2366                n = neighbors[cx]
2367                (nx, ny) = tuple(map(lambda x, y: float(x) + float(y), 
2368                                     best_center, n))
2369                best_center = px, py = (np.copy(nx), np.copy(ny))
2370                
2371            # Update maximum intensity sum 
2372            min_intensity_var = self.parent.intensity_var(image, 
2373                                                    best_center[0], 
2374                                                    best_center[1], 
2375                                                    best_radius) 
2376            
2377            # Refine radius if necessary while keeping the center position 
2378            # constant. It iterates through different radius adjustments to find
2379            # a radius that maximizes the intensity sum of pixels
2380            
2381            radi_intensity_var = []
2382            radii = np.arange(-1, 1 + step, step)
2383            for dr in radii:
2384                new_radius = best_radius + dr
2385                radi_intensity_var.append(self.parent.intensity_var(image, 
2386                                                             best_center[0], 
2387                                                             best_center[1], 
2388                                                             new_radius))
2389                
2390            # Find the minimum value coordinates within curr_var
2391            rx, _ = np.unravel_index(np.argmin(radi_intensity_var),
2392                                      [len(radi_intensity_var),1])
2393            
2394            # Check for improvement of criterion
2395            if max(radi_intensity_var) < min_intensity_var:
2396                min_intensity_var = max(radi_intensity_var)
2397                
2398                n = radii[rx]
2399                nr = best_radius+n
2400                
2401                best_radius = pr = np.copy(nr)
2402
2403            
2404            # Check for convergence and improvement (termination conditions)
2405            impr = abs(min_intensity_var - curr)
2406            if impr < convergence_threshold:
2407                no_improvement_count += 1
2408                if no_improvement_count == 5:
2409                    break
2410        
2411        # Avoid incorrect/redundant refinement
2412        ## (1) swapped coordinates
2413        if ((bckup[0] > bckup[1] and not best_center[0] > best_center[1])
2414            or  (bckup[0] < bckup[1] and not best_center[0] < best_center[1])):
2415            best_center = best_center[::-1]
2416        
2417        ## (2) worsened final maximum intensity sum than the initial one
2418        if np.round(init_var,-2) < np.round(min_intensity_var,-2):
2419            print("Refinement redundant.")
2420            best_center = np.copy(bckup)
2421    
2422        # Print results
2423        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
2424            self.parent.rText = "Center Refinement (IntensityVar)      : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
2425                                  
2426        return best_center[0], best_center[1], best_radius

The 8-neighbourhood pixels (x) of the current center (o) will be tested regarding the minimization:

  • x x x : (px - dx, py + dy) (px, py + dy) ( px + dx, py + dy)

  • x o x : (px - dx, py) (px, py) (px + dx, py)

  • x x x : (px - dx, py - dy) (px, py - dy) (px + dx, py - dy)

2552
2553            # Check for improvement of criterion
2554            if max(radi_intensity_sum) > max_intensity_sum:
2555                max_intensity_sum = max(radi_intensity_sum)
2556                
2557                n = radii[rx]
2558                nr = best_radius+n
2559                
2560                best_radius = pr = np.copy(nr)
2561                
2562            
2563            # Check for convergence and improvement (termination conditions)
2564            impr = abs(max_intensity_sum - curr)
2565            if impr < convergence_threshold:
2566                no_improvement_count += 1
2567                if no_improvement_count == 25:
2568                    break
2569                
2570
2571        
2572        # Avoid incorrect/redundant refinement
2573        # ## (1) swapped coordinates
2574        # if ((bckup[0] > bckup[1] and not best_center[0] > best_center[1])
2575        #     or  (bckup[0] < bckup[1] and not best_center[0] < best_center[1])):
2576        #     best_center = best_center[::-1]
2577        
2578        ## (2) worsened final maximum intensity sum than the initial one
2579        if np.round(init_sum,-2) > np.round(max_intensity_sum,-2):
2580            print("Refinement redundant.")
2581            best_center = np.copy(bckup)
2582    
2583        # Print results
2584        if (self.parent.messages or self.parent.final_print):
2585            self.parent.rText = \
2586                "Center Refinement (IntensitySum)      : ({:.3f}, {:.3f})"
2587                
2588        return best_center[0], best_center[1], best_radius

Adjust center position based on gradient optimization method via maximization of intensity sum.

The 8-neighbourhood pixels (x) of the current center (o) will be tested regarding the maximization:

  • x x x : (px - dx, py + dy) (px, py + dy) ( px + dx, py + dy)

  • x o x : (px - dx, py) (px, py) (px + dx, py)

  • x x x : (px - dx, py - dy) (px, py - dy) (px + dx, py - dy)

Parameters
  • px (float64): x-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted.
  • py (float64): y-coordinate of the detected center to be adjusted.
  • pr (float64): radius of the detected center.
  • plot_results (int, optional): Plot Detected center. The default is 1.
Returns

best_center[0] : float64 Adjusted x-coordinate of the center. best_center[1] : float64 Adjusted y-coordinate of the center. best_radius : float64 The adjusted radius of the circular diffraction pattern.

class IntensityCenter: 
2655class IntensityCenter: 
2656    '''
2657    Simple center determination for a symmetric diffractogram.
2658    
2659    * The center is determined as a center of intensity.
2660    * This works well for simple, symmetric diffraction patters, which are:
2661      (i) without beamstopper, (ii) pre-centered, and (iii) powder-like.
2662    * A real-life example of a simple symmetric diffractogram:
2663      a good powder electron diffraction pattern from STEMDIFF software.
2664    * This class is a legacy from previous EDIFF versions;
2665      it is kept mostly for backward compatibility.
2666      The functions in this class can be (and should be)
2667      replaced by a simple call of ediff.center.CenterLocator object.
2668      
2669    >>> # Center determination in a simple symmetric diffraction pattern
2670    >>> # (center = just center_of_intensity, no refinement
2671    >>>
2672    >>> # (1) Old way = this (old, legacy) IntensityCenter class:
2673    >>> xc,yc = ediff.center.IntensityCenter.center_of_intensity(
2674    >>>     arr, csquare=30, cintensity=0.8)
2675    >>>
2676    >>> # (2) New way = newer (and more universal) CenterLocator class:
2677    >>> xc,yc = ediff.center.CenterLocator(
2678    >>>     arr, detection_method='intensity', csquare=30, cintensity=0.8)
2679    '''
2680    
2681    @staticmethod
2682    def center_of_intensity(arr, csquare=20, cintensity=0.8):
2683        '''
2684        Find center of intensity/mass of an array.
2685        
2686        Parameters
2687        ----------
2688        arr : 2D-numpy array
2689            The array, whose intensity center will be determined.
2690        csquare : int, optional, default is 20
2691            The size/edge of the square in the (geometrical) center.
2692            The intensity center is searched only within the central square.
2693            Reasons: To avoid other spots/diffractions and
2694            to minimize the effect of an intensity assymetry around center. 
2695        cintensity : float, optional, default is 0.8
2696            The intensity fraction.
2697            When searching the intensity center, we will consider only
2698            pixels with intensity > max.intensity.
2699            
2700        Returns
2701        -------
2702        xc,yc : float,float
2703            XY-coordinates of the intensity/mass center of the array.
2704            Round XY-coordinates if you use them for image/array calculations.    
2705        '''
2706        # Get image/array size
2707        xsize,ysize = arr.shape
2708        # Calculate borders around the central square
2709        xborder = (xsize - csquare) // 2
2710        yborder = (ysize - csquare) // 2
2711        # Create central square = cut off the borders
2712        arr2 = arr[xborder:-xborder,yborder:-yborder].copy()
2713        # In the central square, set all values below cintenstity to zero
2714        arr2 = np.where(arr2>np.max(arr2)*cintensity, arr2, 0)
2715        # Calculate 1st central moments of the image
2716        M = sk.measure.moments(arr2,1)
2717        # Calculate the intensity center = centroid according to www-help
2718        (xc,yc) = (M[1,0]/M[0,0], M[0,1]/M[0,0])
2719        # We have centroid of the central square => recalculate to whole image
2720        (xc,yc) = (xc+xborder,yc+yborder)
2721        
2722        ## Return the final center
2723        return(xc,yc)

Simple center determination for a symmetric diffractogram.

  • The center is determined as a center of intensity.
  • This works well for simple, symmetric diffraction patters, which are: (i) without beamstopper, (ii) pre-centered, and (iii) powder-like.
  • A real-life example of a simple symmetric diffractogram: a good powder electron diffraction pattern from STEMDIFF software.
  • This class is a legacy from previous EDIFF versions; it is kept mostly for backward compatibility. The functions in this class can be (and should be) replaced by a simple call of CenterLocator object.
>>> # Center determination in a simple symmetric diffraction pattern
>>> # (center = just center_of_intensity, no refinement
>>>
>>> # (1) Old way = this (old, legacy) IntensityCenter class:
>>> xc,yc = IntensityCenter.center_of_intensity(
>>>     arr, csquare=30, cintensity=0.8)
>>>
>>> # (2) New way = newer (and more universal) CenterLocator class:
>>> xc,yc = CenterLocator(
>>>     arr, detection_method='intensity', csquare=30, cintensity=0.8)

Find center of intensity/mass of an array.

Parameters
  • arr (2D-numpy array): The array, whose intensity center will be determined.
  • csquare (int, optional, default is 20): The size/edge of the square in the (geometrical) center. The intensity center is searched only within the central square. Reasons: To avoid other spots/diffractions and to minimize the effect of an intensity assymetry around center.
  • cintensity (float, optional, default is 0.8): The intensity fraction. When searching the intensity center, we will consider only pixels with intensity > max.intensity.
Returns
  • xc,yc (float,float): XY-coordinates of the intensity/mass center of the array. Round XY-coordinates if you use them for image/array calculations.
